sorting.note: Each plant entry includes a 'category' field for annotation. Plants are sorted by category, then alphabetically by typeName within each category.

description: Also known as: Chinese evergreen. Low-light tolerant aroids with variegated foliage in shades of green, silver, pink, or red.
commonExamples: Aglaonema commutatum (Chinese evergreen), A. pictum, A. 'Silver Bay', A. 'Maria', A. 'Red Siam', A. 'Pink Star'
careTips: Water when top 1-2 inches of soil feels dry. Keep slightly more moist than other low-light plants but avoid soggy soil. Bright indirect light maintains variegation; low light is tolerated but may reduce color. Maintain 50-60% humidity. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced liquid fertilizer (20-20-20) diluted to half strength. Wipe leaves monthly with damp cloth to remove dust and improve photosynthesis. Repot every 2-3 years in spring when roots fill container. Prune yellowing leaves at base. Watch for spider mites in dry conditions. Toxic to pets.

description: Aglaonema cultivar with pink-splashed variegation on green leaves; bright indirect light enhances color.
commonExamples: Aglaonema 'Pink Star'
careTips: Water when top 1-2 inches of soil feels dry. Bright indirect light maintains pink variegation. Medium humidity (50-60%) preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall at half strength. Toxic to pets.

description: Striking Aglaonema cultivar with deep pink or red variegation on dark green leaves, low-light tolerant like other Chinese evergreens.
commonExamples: Aglaonema 'Red Valentine'
careTips: Water when top 1-2 inches of soil feels dry. Keep slightly more moist than succulents but avoid soggy soil. Low to bright indirect light maintains red coloration. Medium humidity (50-60%) preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Wipe leaves monthly to remove dust. Toxic to pets.

description: Colorful Aglaonema with pink, cream, and green variegation; compact growth habit.
commonExamples: Aglaonema 'Sparkling Sarah'
careTips: Water when top 1-2 inches of soil feels dry. Bright indirect light maintains variegation. Medium humidity preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall. Toxic to pets.

description: Finely textured tropical shrub with lacy, compound leaves; can be pruned into tree form. Sensitive to drafts and dry air.
commonExamples: Polyscias fruticosa (Ming aralia, Parsley aralia)
careTips: Water when top 1-2 inches of soil is dry. Keep moderately moist but never soggy—prone to root rot. Bright indirect light preferred; tolerates light shade. Medium to high humidity (50-65%) helps prevent leaf drop. Avoid cold drafts and temps below 18°C. Fertilize monthly spring through fall. Mildly toxic to pets.

description: Variegated form of the cast iron plant with cream or white stripes on narrow leaves; equally indestructible and low-light tolerant.
commonExamples: Aspidistra elatior 'Variegata' (Variegated cast iron plant)
careTips: Water when top 1-2 inches of soil is dry. Extremely forgiving of neglect. Tolerates very low light; brighter indirect light maintains variegation. Low humidity is fine. Fertilize 2-3 times per year at quarter strength. Repot only when severely root-bound. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Also known as: Barroom plant. Extremely low-light tolerant foliage plant in the Asparagaceae family, named for its ability to survive neglect. Includes various cultivars like variegated and speckled varieties.
commonExamples: Aspidistra elatior (Cast iron plant, Barroom plant), A. elatior 'Variegata' (Variegated cast iron plant), A. elatior 'Milky Way' (speckled variety)
careTips: Water when top 1-2 inches of soil is dry. Extremely forgiving of inconsistent watering and low light conditions. Avoid overwatering which causes root rot. Tolerates very low light but grows faster in bright indirect light. Low humidity is fine. Fertilize 2-3 times per year during growing season with balanced fertilizer at quarter strength. Repot only when severely root-bound (every 5-7 years). Remove dead or yellowing leaves at base by cutting at soil level. Dust leaves occasionally. One of the most indestructible houseplants.

description: Compact, bushy cultivar of dumb cane with variegated leaves; smaller than standard varieties, ideal for tabletops.
commonExamples: Dieffenbachia 'Compacta' (Compact dumb cane)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Low to bright indirect light; avoid direct sun. Medium humidity preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall. Wipe leaves to remove dust. Toxic to pets and humans—causes mouth irritation; handle with care.

description: Also known as: Corn plant. Corn plant with broad, arching leaves, can grow quite tall. Includes the popular 'Janet Craig' (Deremensis Group) and 'Massangeana' cultivars.
commonExamples: Dracaena fragrans 'Massangeana' (Corn plant), D. fragrans 'Janet Craig' (Deremensis Group), D. fragrans 'Compacta' (dwarf form)
careTips: Water when top half of soil is dry. Use filtered, distilled, or rainwater to prevent brown leaf tips from fluoride and chlorine. Bright indirect to medium light preferred. Maintain 40-50% humidity. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer diluted to half strength. Wipe leaves monthly to remove dust. Repot every 2-3 years when roots fill container. Prune brown tips and remove yellowing lower leaves. Sensitive to drafts and temperature fluctuations. Toxic to pets.

description: Also known as: Limelight dracaena. Bright lime-green cultivar of Dracaena deremensis; adds vivid color to low-light spaces.
commonExamples: Dracaena deremensis 'Limelight' (Limelight dracaena)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Use filtered water to avoid brown tips. Medium to bright indirect light maintains lime color; low light may dull it. Medium humidity fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall. Toxic to pets.

description: Also known as: Dragon tree, Madagascar dragon tree. Dragon tree with thin, arching leaves with red edges, very low-maintenance.
commonExamples: Dracaena marginata (Dragon tree, Madagascar dragon tree)
careTips: Water when top half of soil is dry. Use filtered, distilled, or rainwater to prevent brown leaf tips from fluoride and chlorine. Bright indirect light maintains red edge coloration. Low to medium humidity is fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Repot every 2-3 years. Trim brown tips with clean scissors. Remove lower leaves as they yellow. Very low-maintenance once established.

description: Compact dracaena with yellow-edged leaves in a spiral arrangement; slow-growing and compact.
commonExamples: Dracaena reflexa 'Song of India' (Song of India, Song of Jamaica)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect light maintains yellow margins. Use filtered water to prevent brown tips. Medium humidity fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall. Toxic to pets.

description: Also known as: Deremensis Group. Stripe-edged dracaena with green and white or cream variegation; upright growth habit.
commonExamples: Dracaena fragrans (Deremensis Group) 'Warneckei' (Striped dracaena, Warneckii)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Use filtered or distilled water to prevent brown leaf tips. Low to bright indirect light. Medium humidity fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall. Toxic to pets.

description: Delicate-looking shrub with fine, serrated leaflets; young plants have coppery new growth. Sensitive to changes in light and humidity.
commonExamples: Plerandra elegantissima (syn. Schefflera elegantissima; False aralia, Thread leaf)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Avoid soggy soil. Bright indirect light preferred; low light causes leaf drop. Moderate to high humidity helps. Avoid drafts and sudden temperature changes. Fertilize monthly spring through fall. Mildly toxic to pets.

description: Classic indoor tree with arching branches and glossy, pointed leaves; can grow quite tall. Sensitive to relocation and drafts.
commonExamples: Ficus benjamina (Weeping fig, Benjamin fig)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect light preferred. Avoid moving once established—leaf drop often follows. Medium humidity preferred; mist if leaves drop. Fertilize monthly spring through fall. Toxic to pets.

description: Variegated rubber plant cultivar with striking cream, green, and pink-edged leaves, more colorful than the standard rubber plant while retaining its easy-care nature.
commonExamples: Ficus elastica 'Tineke' (Variegated rubber plant, Tineke rubber plant)
careTips: Water when top 2-5 cm of soil is dry; reduce in winter. Bright indirect light essential to maintain variegation—too little light causes green reversion. Medium humidity fine. Well-draining potting mix. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Wipe large leaves with damp cloth to remove dust. Prune to control height and encourage branching. Rotate regularly for even growth. Toxic to pets (milky latex sap).

description: Also known as: Sensation peace lily. Large cultivar of peace lily with broad, glossy leaves; can reach 4–6 feet. Low-light tolerant and shows need for water by drooping.
commonExamples: Spathiphyllum 'Sensation' (Sensation peace lily)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry; plant will droop when thirsty. Low to bright indirect light. Medium humidity preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall. Wipe leaves to remove dust. Toxic to pets and humans—causes mouth irritation.

description: Also known as: Rainbow edge peperomia. Compact peperomia with tricolor leaves—green, cream, and pink edges; upright growth habit.
commonExamples: Peperomia clusiifolia 'Ginny' (Rainbow edge peperomia, Tricolor peperomia)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Avoid overwatering—succulent leaves store water. Bright indirect light maintains variegation. Medium humidity fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall at half strength. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Upright, non-vining philodendron with glossy, broad leaves; compact and bushy growth habit.
commonExamples: Philodendron 'Congo', P. 'Congo Rojo', P. 'Rojo Congo'
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Low to bright indirect light. Medium humidity fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall. Wipe leaves to remove dust. Mildly toxic to pets.

description: Also known as: Gray baby tears. Tiny-leaved trailing plant with blue-green foliage; ideal for terrariums or small hanging pots.
commonExamples: Pilea glauca (unresolved name; possibly P. libanensis) (Silver sparkle, Gray baby tears)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Keep evenly moist. Bright indirect light preferred. High humidity helps—good for terrariums. Fertilize monthly spring through fall at half strength. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Extremely easy-care trailing aroids in the Araceae family, excellent for beginners, includes many variegated varieties.
commonExamples: Epipremnum aureum (Golden pothos), E. 'Marble Queen', E. 'Neon', E. 'N'Joy', E. 'Manjula', Scindapsus pictus (Satin pothos)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Very forgiving of neglect and inconsistent watering. Bright indirect light maintains variegation; tolerates low light but may lose variegation. Medium humidity is fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Prune to control length and encourage bushiness. Repot every 1-2 years. Excellent for beginners. Toxic to pets. One of the most popular houseplants.

description: Pothos variety with silvery-blue, elongated leaves; develops fenestrations when mature. Same easy care as golden pothos.
commonExamples: Epipremnum pinnatum 'Cebu Blue' (Cebu blue pothos)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect light enhances blue sheen. Medium humidity fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall. Can develop split leaves with age. Toxic to pets.

description: Also known as: Green pothos. Solid green pothos with no variegation; most tolerant of low light and the hardiest pothos variety.
commonExamples: Epipremnum aureum 'Jade' (Jade pothos, Green pothos)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Tolerates very low light better than variegated varieties. Medium humidity fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall. Very forgiving. Toxic to pets.

description: Also known as: African spear. Snake plant with cylindrical, spear-like leaves; often braided when young. Same drought tolerance as flat-leaf varieties.
commonExamples: Dracaena angolensis (syn. Sansevieria cylindrica; African spear, Cylindrical snake plant)
careTips: Water when soil is completely dry (every 2-4 weeks). Very drought tolerant. Low to bright indirect light. Low humidity fine. Fertilize 2-3 times per year. Toxic to pets.

description: Also known as: Golden hahnii. Dwarf snake plant with rosette-forming leaves; compact, ideal for small spaces and tabletops.
commonExamples: Dracaena trifasciata 'Hahnii' (Bird's nest snake plant, Golden hahnii)
careTips: Water when soil is completely dry (every 2-4 weeks). Drought tolerant. Low to bright indirect light. Low humidity fine. Fertilize 2-3 times per year. Toxic to pets.

description: Snake plant with silvery-gray, broad leaves; subtle banding. Same easy care as other Dracaena trifasciata varieties.
commonExamples: Dracaena trifasciata 'Moonshine' (Moonshine snake plant)
careTips: Water when soil is completely dry (every 2-4 weeks). Drought tolerant. Low to bright indirect light. Low humidity fine. Fertilize 2-3 times per year. Toxic to pets.

description: Compact umbrella plant with palmate leaves, easier to manage indoors than the larger schefflera.
commonExamples: Schefflera arboricola (Dwarf umbrella plant, Hawaiian elf schefflera), S. arboricola 'Variegata'
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect light preferred. Medium humidity fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall. Prune to maintain shape. More compact than standard schefflera. Toxic to pets.

description: Large schefflera with compound leaves radiating from a central point; can grow into a small indoor tree.
commonExamples: Schefflera actinophylla (Umbrella plant, Octopus tree)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect light preferred. Medium humidity fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall. Prune to control size. Toxic to pets.

description: Unique pothos cultivar with curled and twisted leaves that give a compact, textured appearance. Same easy care as standard pothos but with distinctive ruffled foliage.
commonExamples: Epipremnum aureum 'Shangri La' (Godzilla pothos, Sleeping pothos)
careTips: Water when top 1-2 inches of soil is dry. Tolerates low to bright indirect light. Very low maintenance. Curled leaves may unfurl with more light. Average humidity is fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall. Mildly toxic to pets.

description: Also known as: Mother-in-law's tongue. Extremely low-maintenance succulents in the Asparagaceae family with upright sword-like leaves. Includes various cultivars with different leaf shapes and patterns.
commonExamples: Dracaena trifasciata (syn. Sansevieria trifasciata; Mother-in-law's tongue), D. trifasciata 'Laurentii', D. trifasciata 'Moonshine', D. trifasciata 'Black Gold', Dracaena angolensis (syn. Sansevieria cylindrica; cylindrical snake plant)
careTips: Water only when soil is completely dry (every 2-8 weeks depending on conditions). Very drought tolerant due to water storage in leaves. Bright indirect to direct light preferred; tolerates low light but grows slowly. Low humidity is fine. Fertilize 2-3 times per year during growing season with succulent fertilizer at quarter strength. Repot only when pot breaks or plant becomes top-heavy (every 5-10 years). Remove dead leaves at base by pulling gently. Divide offsets when repotting. Overwatering is the main cause of death - when in doubt, wait longer. Toxic to pets.

description: Variegated peace lily with white speckling on green leaves; smaller than Sensation, good for tabletops.
commonExamples: Spathiphyllum 'Domino' (Domino peace lily)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry; droops when thirsty. Low to bright indirect light. Medium humidity preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall. Brighter light maintains variegation. Toxic to pets.

description: Also known as: Airplane plant, Ribbon plant. Easy-care trailing plants in the Asparagaceae family that produce plantlets on stolons, excellent air purifiers. Includes various cultivars with different variegation patterns.
commonExamples: Chlorophytum comosum (Spider plant, Airplane plant, Ribbon plant), C. comosum 'Vittatum', C. comosum 'Variegatum', C. comosum 'Bonnie'
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Keep slightly moist but avoid overwatering which causes brown tips. Bright indirect light maintains variegation. Medium humidity (40-50%) preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced liquid fertilizer at half strength. Remove plantlets when they develop roots (2-3 inches long) to propagate or reduce crowding. Trim brown tips with clean scissors. Repot every 1-2 years when roots fill container. Excellent air purifier. Watch for spider mites in dry conditions. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Also known as: Giant yucca. Drought-tolerant plants in the Asparagaceae family with sword-like leaves, can grow into small trees.
commonExamples: Yucca elephantipes (Spineless yucca, Giant yucca), Y. aloifolia (Spanish bayonet, Dagger plant)
careTips: Water when soil is completely dry (every 2-4 weeks). Very drought tolerant. Bright indirect to direct light preferred. Low humidity is fine. Fertilize 2-3 times per year during growing season with balanced fertilizer at quarter strength. Repot every 3-5 years when roots fill container. Remove dead leaves at base. Can grow quite large - provide adequate space. Sharp leaf tips - handle with care.

description: Also known as: Zanzibar gem, Eternity plant. Extremely low-maintenance plant in the Araceae family with glossy leaves and rhizomes that store water, virtually indestructible.
commonExamples: Zamioculcas zamiifolia (ZZ plant, Zanzibar gem, Eternity plant), Z. zamiifolia 'Raven' (Raven ZZ)
careTips: Water when soil is completely dry (every 2-4 weeks). Rhizomes store water making it extremely drought tolerant. Overwatering causes root rot - when in doubt, wait. Low to bright indirect light tolerated; grows faster in brighter light. Low humidity is fine. Fertilize 2-3 times per year during growing season with balanced fertilizer at quarter strength. Repot every 2-3 years when rhizomes fill container. Wipe glossy leaves monthly to remove dust. Virtually indestructible - perfect for beginners. Toxic to pets.

description: Also known as: Raven ZZ plant, Black ZZ. Dark purple-black variety of ZZ plant, same easy-care as standard ZZ, new growth emerges green and darkens with age.
commonExamples: Zamioculcas zamiifolia 'Raven' (Raven ZZ plant, Black ZZ), Z. zamiifolia (standard green ZZ), Z. zamiifolia 'Zenzi' (compact variety)
careTips: Water when soil is completely dry (every 2-4 weeks). Rhizomes store water making it extremely drought tolerant. Overwatering causes root rot. Low to bright indirect light; new growth emerges green and darkens to purple-black with age. Low humidity is fine. Fertilize 2-3 times per year during growing season with balanced fertilizer at quarter strength. Repot every 2-3 years. Wipe glossy leaves monthly. Same easy-care as standard ZZ plant with striking dark foliage.

description: Also known as: Dwarf ZZ plant. Compact cultivar of Zamioculcas zamiifolia with shorter, more tightly clustered dark green leaflets on chunky stems.
commonExamples: Zamioculcas zamiifolia 'Zenzi' (Dwarf ZZ plant)
careTips: Water only when soil is completely dry — the thick rhizomes store water and overwatering causes root rot. Tolerates low light but grows faster in bright indirect light; avoid direct sun. Average room humidity is fine; no misting needed. Fertilize once or twice during the growing season with a balanced liquid fertilizer at half strength. Wipe leaves with a damp cloth to remove dust. Toxic to pets — contains calcium oxalate crystals.

description: Dramatic aroid with arrow-shaped, dark green leaves featuring bold white or silver veining. Parent hybrid of the smaller Alocasia Polly. Despite the name, it is a hybrid, not from the Amazon.
commonExamples: Alocasia × amazonica (African mask plant, Elephant ear), A. × amazonica 'Polly' (compact cultivar)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect light; avoid direct sun which scorches leaves. High humidity (60%+) is important. May go dormant and lose leaves in winter — reduce watering and wait for regrowth. Toxic to pets.

description: Compact Alocasia with velvety black leaves and silver veins; dramatic foliage plant requiring high humidity.
commonExamples: Alocasia reginula (Black velvet)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist, never fully dry. High humidity (60%+) essential—use pebble tray or humidifier. Bright indirect light; avoid direct sun. Warm temps 18-27°C. Fertilize monthly spring through fall. Toxic to pets.

description: Also known as: Mirror plant, Red copper. Alocasia with metallic copper-bronze leaves and pronounced veins; compact, jewel-like foliage.
commonExamples: Alocasia cuprea (Mirror plant, Red copper)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist. High humidity (60%+) required. Bright indirect light; direct sun burns leaves. Warm temps preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall. Toxic to pets.

description: Compact Alocasia with extraordinarily textured, thick leaves featuring deep silvery-green coloring and prominent dark veining that resembles dragon scales.
commonExamples: Alocasia baginda 'Dragon Scale'
careTips: Keep soil lightly moist but never soggy; allow top layer to dry slightly. Bright indirect light—avoid direct sun. High humidity (60%+) essential; struggles in dry indoor air. Very well-draining aroid mix with perlite, bark, and sphagnum. Fertilize monthly spring through fall at quarter strength. May go dormant in winter, losing leaves—reduce watering and keep warm. Sensitive to overwatering. Toxic to pets (calcium oxalate crystals).

description: Also known as: Green velvet. Velvety green Alocasia with prominent white veins; similar to Black Velvet but green. Requires high humidity.
commonExamples: Alocasia micholitziana 'Frydek' (Green velvet)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist. High humidity (60%+) essential. Bright indirect light. Warm temps 18-27°C. Fertilize monthly spring through fall. Toxic to pets.

description: Also known as: Grey dragon. Compact gray-green Alocasia with textured, velvety leaves; dwarf elephant ear.
commonExamples: Alocasia maharani (Grey dragon)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist. Medium to high humidity preferred. Bright indirect light. Fertilize monthly spring through fall. Toxic to pets.

description: Also known as: African mask. Compact hybrid Alocasia with arrow-shaped, dark green leaves and white veins; popular cultivar.
commonExamples: Alocasia × amazonica 'Polly' (African mask, Polly)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist. Medium to high humidity helps. Bright indirect light; avoid direct sun. Fertilize monthly spring through fall. Toxic to pets.

description: Compact Alocasia cultivar from Borneo with rigid, silvery-green leaves featuring deeply etched dark green veins and a textured, almost metallic surface.
commonExamples: Alocasia baginda 'Silver Dragon' (Silver Dragon alocasia)
careTips: Keep soil lightly and evenly moist; water when the top inch dries but do not let the corm sit in water. Bright indirect light is essential — too little light leads to leggy growth and dull coloring. Requires humidity above 60%; a humidifier or terrarium setup is recommended. Use a very chunky, well-aerated mix (orchid bark, perlite, coco coir). Fertilize every 2 weeks in spring and summer with a diluted balanced fertilizer. May enter dormancy in winter — reduce watering if leaves die back. Toxic to pets.

description: Alocasia with unique leaf shape—elongated "tail" like a stingray; large foliage plant.
commonExamples: Alocasia macrorrhiza 'Stingray'
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist. High humidity (60%+) preferred. Bright indirect light. Large plant—provide space. Fertilize monthly spring through fall. Toxic to pets.

description: Alocasia with striped zebra-pattern stems and arrow-shaped leaves; striking tropical aroid.
commonExamples: Alocasia zebrina (Zebra plant)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist. High humidity (60%+) essential. Bright indirect light. Warm temps preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall. Toxic to pets.

description: Also known as: Giant taro. Tropical aroids with large, arrow-shaped leaves (elephant ears), many require high humidity and consistent moisture.
commonExamples: Alocasia × amazonica 'Polly' (hybrid), A. macrorrhizos (Giant taro), A. zebrina (Zebra plant), A. longiloba
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist, never let fully dry. High humidity (60-80%) essential - use pebble tray or humidifier. Bright indirect light preferred; direct sun burns leaves. Maintain warm temperatures (65-80°F). Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Mist leaves daily or use humidifier. Repot annually in spring with well-draining soil. Wipe large leaves monthly. Watch for spider mites. Some species go dormant in winter - reduce watering then.

description: Rosette-forming anthurium with large, wavy, leathery leaves that form a bird's nest shape. Unlike typical anthuriums, grown for dramatic foliage rather than colorful spathes.
commonExamples: Anthurium hookeri (Bird's nest anthurium), A. superbum, A. plowmanii (Ruffled bird's nest anthurium)
careTips: Water when top 1-2 inches of soil is dry. Bright indirect light preferred. High humidity (60%+) for best growth. Chunky, well-draining aroid mix. Large, dramatic plant — leaves can reach 1 meter. Fertilize monthly spring through fall. Toxic to pets.

description: Anthurium with velvety heart-shaped leaves and prominent white veins; grown for foliage, not flowers.
commonExamples: Anthurium clarinervium (Velvet cardboard anthurium)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. High humidity (60%+) preferred. Bright indirect light. Chunky, well-draining mix. Fertilize monthly spring through fall. Toxic to pets.

description: Large velvety Anthurium with dark green leaves and prominent pale veins; dramatic foliage plant native to Colombia.
commonExamples: Anthurium magnificum
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. High humidity (60%+) essential. Bright indirect light. Chunky, well-draining mix. Fertilize monthly spring through fall. Toxic to pets.

description: Anthurium with long, narrow strap-like leaves; unique form among anthuriums.
commonExamples: Anthurium vittarifolium
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist. High humidity (60%+) required. Bright indirect light. Epiphytic—chunky mix. Fertilize monthly spring through fall. Toxic to pets.

description: Majestic collector aroid with elongated, dark velvety leaves up to 1.8m long featuring silvery-white veining. One of the most prized Anthurium species.
commonExamples: Anthurium warocqueanum (Queen Anthurium)
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist but never waterlogged. Bright indirect light — avoid direct sun. Very high humidity (70-80%+) critical; best grown in greenhouse, terrarium, or with humidifier. Extremely well-draining aroid mix with orchid bark, perlite, and sphagnum moss. Fertilize lightly every 2 weeks during growing season. Sensitive to mineral buildup — use filtered or rainwater. Keep above 18°C. Toxic to pets.

description: Also known as: Flamingo flower. Tropical aroids with colorful spathes and glossy foliage, long-lasting blooms.
commonExamples: Anthurium andraeanum (Flamingo flower), A. crystallinum (Crystal anthurium), A. scherzerianum
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Keep consistently moist but not soggy. Bright indirect light encourages blooms. High humidity (60-70%) preferred. Fertilize every 2-3 weeks spring through fall with orchid or high-phosphorus fertilizer to encourage flowering. Remove spent flowers. Repot every 2 years in spring. Wipe glossy leaves monthly. Blooms last 2-3 months. Avoid cold drafts.

description: Tropical plants in the Araceae family with distinctive inflorescences (spathes and spadices), many are popular houseplants.
commonExamples: Monstera deliciosa (Swiss cheese plant), Philodendron, Epipremnum (Pothos), Anthurium, Alocasia, Spathiphyllum (Peace lily)
careTips: Water when top 1-2 inches of soil is dry. Most prefer consistently moist but well-drained soil. Bright indirect light preferred. High humidity (50-60%) beneficial. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Repot when roots fill container. Wipe leaves monthly. Many are excellent air purifiers. Watch for common pests (spider mites, mealybugs).

description: Also known as: Nephthytis. Popular aroid with arrow-shaped leaves that change form as they mature, can trail or climb.
commonExamples: Syngonium podophyllum (Arrowhead plant, Goosefoot plant, Nephthytis)
careTips: Water when top 2 inches of soil is dry. Keep consistently moist but not soggy. Bright indirect light preferred. Medium to high humidity (50-60%) ideal. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Leaves change from arrow-shaped to lobed as they mature. Can trail or climb with support. Prune to maintain shape. Repot every 1-2 years. Wipe leaves monthly. Toxic to pets.

description: Fast-growing, easy-care philodendron with narrow, heart-shaped leaves on long stems. Named after the famous Brazilian landscape architect Roberto Burle Marx.
commonExamples: Philodendron burle-marxii (Burle Marx philodendron)
careTips: Water when top 1-2 inches of soil is dry. Tolerates a range of light from medium to bright indirect. Average humidity is fine. Fast grower that benefits from regular feeding spring through fall. Toxic to pets.

description: Also known as: Angel wings, Heart of Jesus. Tuberous aroid with arrow-shaped leaves in pink, red, white, or green; grown for foliage, goes dormant in winter.
commonExamples: Caladium bicolor (Angel wings, Heart of Jesus)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist during active growth. Bright indirect light preferred; some morning sun enhances color. Medium to high humidity (50-60%). Fertilize monthly spring through fall. Tubers go dormant in fall—reduce watering when leaves yellow. Toxic to pets. Repot tubers in spring.

description: Also known as: Elephant ear. Large, velvety elephant-ear leaves; tropical tuber that can grow very large, prefers moist to wet conditions.
commonExamples: Colocasia esculenta (Taro, Elephant ear)
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist; thrives in wet conditions. Bright indirect to direct light. High humidity (50-60%) preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall. Can be grown in water. Toxic to pets (calcium oxalate crystals). Toxic to humans when raw—cooking required for edible tubers. Repot every 1-2 years when roots fill container.

description: Cane-forming aroids with variegated foliage, toxic sap (handle with care).
commonExamples: Dieffenbachia seguine (Dumb cane), D. amoena (Giant dumb cane), D. 'Tropic Snow'
careTips: Water when top 2 inches of soil is dry. Keep consistently moist but not soggy. Bright indirect light maintains variegation. Medium to high humidity (50-60%) preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Repot every 1-2 years. Wipe large leaves monthly. Toxic sap causes mouth irritation - handle with care and wash hands after touching. Prune leggy stems to encourage bushiness.

description: Also known as: Leopard lily. Classic dumb cane with large, variegated leaves; the species from which many cultivars are derived.
commonExamples: Dieffenbachia seguine (Dumb cane, Leopard lily)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Low to bright indirect light. Medium humidity preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall. Highly toxic to pets and humans—causes severe mouth irritation.

description: Highly variegated pothos with white and green leaves; develops fenestrations when mature. Same care as Cebu Blue.
commonExamples: Epipremnum pinnatum 'Albo Variegatum'
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect light maintains variegation. Medium humidity fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall. Toxic to pets.

description: Also known as: Devil's ivy. Most common pothos variety with green and yellow variegated leaves, extremely easy-care.
commonExamples: Epipremnum aureum 'Golden' (Golden pothos, Devil's ivy)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Very forgiving of neglect and inconsistent watering. Bright indirect light maintains golden variegation; tolerates low light but may lose variegation. Medium humidity is fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Prune to control length and encourage bushiness. Repot every 1-2 years. Excellent for beginners. Toxic to pets.

description: Pothos variety with white and green marbled variegation, requires more light than golden pothos to maintain variegation.
commonExamples: Epipremnum aureum 'Marble Queen' (Marble Queen pothos), E. aureum 'Snow Queen' (more white variegation)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Very forgiving of inconsistent watering. Bright indirect light is essential to maintain white variegation - low light causes reversion to green. Medium humidity is fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Prune to encourage bushiness. Repot every 1-2 years. More light-demanding than golden pothos.

description: Also known as: Swiss cheese vine. Swiss cheese vine with smaller, perforated leaves compared to Monstera deliciosa.
commonExamples: Monstera adansonii (Monkey mask, Swiss cheese vine)
careTips: Water when top 2 inches of soil is dry. Keep consistently moist but not soggy. Bright indirect light preferred. High humidity (60-70%) encourages larger leaves with more fenestrations. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Provide moss pole or trellis for climbing - this encourages larger, more fenestrated leaves. Repot every 1-2 years. Wipe leaves monthly. Can trail or climb.

description: Variegated Monstera with white sections on green leaves; highly sought after. Requires bright light to maintain variegation.
commonExamples: Monstera deliciosa 'Albo Borsigiana'
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect light essential for variegation. Medium humidity preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall. Toxic to pets.

description: Variegated Monstera with yellow-gold splashes on green leaves; similar care to Albo but different coloration.
commonExamples: Monstera deliciosa 'Aurea' (Yellow variegated monstera)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect light maintains yellow variegation. Medium humidity preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall. Toxic to pets.

description: Rare climbing Monstera with dramatically large fenestrations that give leaves a skeleton-like appearance. Formerly classified as Monstera epipremnoides.
commonExamples: Monstera esqueleto (Skeleton monstera, formerly M. epipremnoides)
careTips: Water when top 5cm of soil is dry. Bright indirect light for best fenestration development. High humidity (60-80%) important. Provide sturdy moss pole — leaves grow significantly larger when climbing. Aroid mix with good drainage. Fertilize monthly spring through fall. Protect from cold drafts. Toxic to pets.

description: Climbing Monstera species with elongated, lance-shaped leaves that develop small fenestrations (holes) as they mature, more compact than M. deliciosa.
commonExamples: Monstera lechleriana
careTips: Water when top 2-3 cm of soil is dry. Bright indirect light preferred. Medium to high humidity (50-70%). Chunky, well-draining aroid mix. Fertilize monthly spring through fall at half strength. Provide a moss pole or trellis for climbing—leaves grow larger with support. Regularly check for spider mites. Toxic to pets (calcium oxalate crystals).

description: Climbing Monstera with deeply textured, quilted leaves; no fenestrations. Distinct from M. deliciosa.
commonExamples: Monstera karstenianum (syn. Monstera sp. 'Peru') (Monstera peru)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect light preferred. Medium humidity. Provide moss pole to climb. Fertilize monthly spring through fall. Toxic to pets.

description: Also known as: Silver monstera. Silver-marked Monstera with juvenile leaves that develop fenestrations when mature. Climbing habit.
commonExamples: Monstera siltepecana (Silver monstera)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect light. Medium humidity preferred. Provide support to climb. Fertilize monthly spring through fall. Toxic to pets.

description: Smaller Monstera species with elongated oval leaves featuring cream or yellow variegation (spots and splashes), a climbing vine often confused with Philodendron.
commonExamples: Monstera standleyana, M. standleyana 'Albo Variegata'
careTips: Water when top 2-3 cm of soil is dry. Bright indirect light to maintain variegation. Medium humidity (50%+) fine. Well-draining aroid mix. Fertilize monthly spring through fall at half strength. Provide support for climbing—leaves stay smaller without it. Faster growing than many collector Monsteras. Toxic to pets (calcium oxalate crystals).

description: Tissue-culture variegated Monstera with cream splashes; more stable variegation than Albo. Highly sought after.
commonExamples: Monstera deliciosa 'Thai Constellation'
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect light maintains variegation. Medium humidity preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall. Toxic to pets.

description: Also known as: Lime pothos. Vibrant chartreuse pothos variety with solid bright green-yellow leaves, adds bright color to indoor spaces.
commonExamples: Epipremnum aureum 'Neon' (Neon pothos, Lime pothos), E. aureum 'Neon' variegated (with darker green variegation)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Very easy-care like other pothos varieties. Bright indirect light maintains vibrant chartreuse color; low light causes darkening. Medium humidity is fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Prune to control length. Repot every 1-2 years. Adds bright color to indoor spaces. Toxic to pets.

description: Striking aroid with dark green leaves and white pinstripes, compact growth habit, variegation can revert to solid green.
commonExamples: Philodendron 'Birkin' (Birkin philodendron), may show red variegation as it matures
careTips: Water when top 1-2 inches of soil is dry. Keep consistently moist but not soggy. Bright indirect light maintains white pinstripes; low light may cause reversion to solid green. High humidity (60-70%) preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Repot every 1-2 years. Variegation can revert - prune reverted leaves. May show red variegation as it matures.

description: Climbing aroid with olive-green, heart-shaped leaves splashed with broad silver patches between the veins.
commonExamples: Philodendron brandtianum (Silver leaf philodendron, Brandi philodendron)
careTips: Water when the top 2-3 cm of soil feels dry; reduce frequency in winter. Bright indirect light enhances the silver variegation — tolerates medium light but growth slows. Provide a moss pole or trellis for climbing to encourage larger leaves. Maintain 50-70% humidity for best results. Fertilize monthly in spring and summer with balanced liquid fertilizer at half strength. Toxic to pets — contains calcium oxalate crystals.

description: Rare climbing Philodendron hybrid with ghostly white juvenile leaves that mature to green. Multi-lobed leaves on distinctive red petioles.
commonExamples: Philodendron 'Florida Ghost' (Florida Ghost philodendron)
careTips: Water when top 5cm of soil is dry. Bright indirect light essential — more light produces whiter new leaves. High humidity (60-80%) ideal. Provide a moss pole for climbing support. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Well-draining aroid mix preferred. Toxic to pets.

description: Terrestrial creeping Philodendron with large, velvety heart-shaped leaves featuring prominent white veining. A collector's favorite aroid.
commonExamples: Philodendron gloriosum (Velvet philodendron)
careTips: Water when top 5cm of soil is dry. Bright indirect light; avoid direct sun which scorches velvety leaves. High humidity (60-80%) essential for leaf quality. Creeping rhizome — use a wide, shallow pot rather than deep one. Aroid mix with perlite and orchid bark. Fertilize monthly spring through fall. Sensitive to cold — keep above 18°C. Toxic to pets.

description: Also known as: Philodendron Scandens, Heart-leaf philodendron. Classic trailing aroid with heart-shaped leaves, extremely easy-care and fast-growing.
commonExamples: Philodendron hederaceum (Heart-leaf philodendron, Sweetheart plant), P. hederaceum 'Brasil' (variegated), P. hederaceum 'Lemon Lime'
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Very forgiving of inconsistent care. Bright indirect light preferred; tolerates low light. Medium humidity (40-50%) is fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Fast-growing trailing plant. Prune to control length. Repot every 1-2 years. Excellent air purifier. Toxic to pets.

description: Large, highly variegated Philodendron with cream/white and green leaves; statement plant.
commonExamples: Philodendron 'Jose Buono'
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect light maintains variegation. Medium humidity preferred. Provide moss pole. Fertilize monthly spring through fall. Toxic to pets.

description: Also known as: Silver cloud. Crawling Philodendron with silver-marked, heart-shaped leaves. Similar to gloriosum but more compact.
commonExamples: Philodendron mamei (Silver cloud)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist. Medium to high humidity. Bright indirect light. Shallow pot for crawling. Fertilize monthly spring through fall. Toxic to pets.

description: Also known as: Black gold philodendron. Climbing Philodendron with velvety black-green leaves and gold veins; dramatic foliage, needs support.
commonExamples: Philodendron melanochrysum (Black gold philodendron)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist. High humidity (60%+) essential. Bright indirect light. Moss pole required. Fertilize monthly spring through fall. Toxic to pets.

description: Velvety trailing aroid with heart-shaped leaves that shimmer in light, bronze-green with purple undersides.
commonExamples: Philodendron hederaceum var. hederaceum (Philodendron micans, Velvet philodendron), can trail or climb with support
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Keep slightly more moist than other philodendrons. Bright indirect light enhances velvety sheen and purple undersides. High humidity (60-70%) preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Can trail or climb with support. Repot every 1-2 years. Velvety leaves are delicate - avoid touching. Toxic to pets.

description: Also known as: PPP. Rare aroid with dark green and pink variegated leaves, requires bright light to maintain variegation, can revert to solid green.
commonExamples: Philodendron erubescens 'Pink Princess' (PPP), P. erubescens 'White Princess' (white variegation), P. erubescens 'White Knight'
careTips: Water when top 1-2 inches of soil is dry. Keep consistently moist but well-drained. Bright indirect light is essential to maintain pink variegation - low light causes reversion to solid green. High humidity (70%+) preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Repot every 1-2 years. Variegation is unstable - prune reverted leaves. Rare and expensive - handle with care. Toxic to pets.

description: Crawling philodendron with wavy, elongated leaves and silver veins; grows along the soil surface, not climbing.
commonExamples: Philodendron plowmanii
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist. Medium to high humidity preferred. Bright indirect light. Shallow pot suits crawling habit. Fertilize monthly spring through fall. Toxic to pets.

description: Upright Philodendron with new orange leaves that age to green; compact, self-heading habit.
commonExamples: Philodendron 'Prince of Orange'
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect light. Medium humidity fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall. New growth emerges orange. Toxic to pets.

description: Variegated Philodendron with cream, yellow, orange, and green in leaves; climbing habit.
commonExamples: Philodendron 'Ring of Fire'
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect light maintains variegation. Medium humidity preferred. Provide moss pole. Fertilize monthly spring through fall. Toxic to pets.

description: Also known as: Split-leaf philodendron. Large, deeply lobed Philodendron; can grow into a small tree. Now classified as Thaumatophyllum bipinnatifidum.
commonExamples: Thaumatophyllum bipinnatifidum (syn. Philodendron bipinnatifidum; Split-leaf philodendron)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect light. Medium humidity. Can grow large—provide space. Fertilize monthly spring through fall. Toxic to pets.

description: Also known as: Silver sword. Climbing philodendron with elongated, silvery-green leaves.
commonExamples: Philodendron hastatum (Silver philodendron)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect light preferred; tolerates medium light. Medium humidity (40-50%). Provide moss pole or support for climbing. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Toxic to pets. Repot every 1-2 years when roots fill container.

description: Velvety Philodendron with red undersides and prominent veins; requires high humidity.
commonExamples: Philodendron verrucosum
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist. High humidity (60%+) essential. Bright indirect light. Moss pole for climbing. Fertilize monthly spring through fall. Toxic to pets.

description: Also known as: White Knight, White Wizard. Striking white-and-green variegated climbing Philodendrons. White Knight has purple/burgundy stems; White Wizard has pure green stems. Both produce large, dramatically variegated leaves.
commonExamples: Philodendron 'White Knight' (purple stems), P. 'White Wizard' (green stems)
careTips: Water when top 2 inches of soil feels dry. Bright indirect light essential for variegation — too little light reduces white patches; direct sun burns white sections. Maintain 60%+ humidity. Well-draining aroid mix. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced liquid fertilizer at half strength. Provide moss pole for climbing. Prune all-green leaves to maintain variegation. Slow growers. Toxic to pets.

description: Variegated self-heading philodendron with white splashes on green leaves. Slower growing than White Knight, with a more compact habit and brighter white variegation.
commonExamples: Philodendron 'White Princess' (White Princess philodendron)
careTips: Water when top 1-2 inches of soil is dry. Bright indirect light is essential for variegation; too little light reduces white sectors. High humidity (60%+) preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall at half strength. Toxic to pets.

description: Deeply lobed, compact Philodendron; self-heading, does not climb. Dense foliage habit.
commonExamples: Thaumatophyllum xanadu (syn. Philodendron xanadu)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Low to bright indirect light. Medium humidity fine. Compact growth—good for smaller spaces. Fertilize monthly spring through fall. Toxic to pets.

description: Fast-growing climber with fenestrated leaves; resembles small Monstera but is Rhaphidophora. Easy care.
commonExamples: Rhaphidophora tetrasperma (Mini monstera, Ginny philodendron)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect light. Medium humidity preferred. Provide moss pole—grows fast. Fertilize monthly spring through fall. Toxic to pets.

description: Also known as: Mexican breadfruit. Popular tropical aroid with distinctive split and perforated leaves (fenestrations), develops larger leaves with age.
commonExamples: Monstera deliciosa (Swiss cheese plant, Split-leaf philodendron, Mexican breadfruit), M. adansonii (Monkey mask, Swiss cheese vine)
careTips: Water when top 2 inches of soil is dry. Keep consistently moist but well-drained. Bright indirect light encourages fenestrations (splits) in mature leaves. High humidity (60-70%) preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Provide moss pole or trellis for climbing - this encourages much larger leaves with more fenestrations. Repot every 1-2 years. Wipe large leaves monthly. Toxic to pets.

description: Variegated arrowhead with white and green leaves; trailing or compact depending on pruning. Easy-care aroid.
commonExamples: Syngonium podophyllum 'Albo Variegatum'
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect light maintains variegation. Medium humidity preferred. Prune to control shape. Fertilize monthly spring through fall. Toxic to pets.

description: Also known as: Pink Splash. Pink-toned arrowhead plants with leaves ranging from soft pink to vibrant magenta, including solid and splash-patterned varieties.
commonExamples: Syngonium podophyllum 'Neon Robusta' (bright pink), S. 'Pink Splash' (green with pink speckles), S. 'Pink Perfection', S. 'Confetti'
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect light enhances pink. Medium humidity preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall. Toxic to pets.

description: Arrowhead plant with cream and green variegation; vining or compact depending on pruning. Easy-care aroid.
commonExamples: Syngonium podophyllum 'White Butterfly' (White butterfly, Goosefoot plant)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Low to bright indirect light; more light enhances variegation. Medium humidity preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall. Prune to control shape. Toxic to pets.

description: Vining aroids that trail or climb, easy-care houseplants with excellent air-purifying qualities.
commonExamples: Epipremnum aureum (Pothos, Devil's ivy), Scindapsus pictus (Satin pothos, Silver pothos), Philodendron hederaceum (Heart-leaf philodendron)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is slightly dry. Very forgiving of inconsistent care. Bright indirect to medium light preferred. Medium humidity (40-50%) is fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Prune to control length and encourage bushiness. Repot every 1-2 years. Excellent air purifiers. Easy-care houseplants perfect for beginners. Toxic to pets.

description: Tropical aroids with large arrow-shaped leaves (elephant ears), require high humidity and consistent moisture.
commonExamples: Xanthosoma sagittifolium (Arrowleaf elephant ear), X. violaceum (Blue taro), X. 'Lime Zinger'
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist, never let fully dry. High humidity (60-80%) essential - use pebble tray or humidifier. Bright indirect light preferred; direct sun burns leaves. Maintain warm temperatures (65-80°F). Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Mist leaves daily or use humidifier. Repot annually in spring. Large arrow-shaped leaves. Some species go dormant in winter.

description: Also known as: Lace fern, Plumosa fern. Not a true fern—lacey foliage plant in Asparagaceae; feathery stems. Berries and sap toxic to pets.
commonExamples: Asparagus setaceus (Lace fern, Plumosa fern)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect light preferred. Medium humidity (50%) fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall. Repot every 1-2 years when roots fill container. Avoid berries—toxic to pets.

description: Epiphytic fern with wavy, strap-like fronds emerging from a central rosette, resembles a bird's nest.
commonExamples: Asplenium nidus (Bird's nest fern), A. antiquum, A. 'Crispy Wave'
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist but not soggy. High humidity (60-70%) preferred. Bright indirect light preferred; avoid direct sun. Use distilled or filtered water to prevent leaf browning. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Don't pour water into the central rosette - water around the base. Repot every 2-3 years. Wavy, strap-like fronds.

description: Silver Lady Fern with upright fronds forming a trunk-like base. Tolerates slightly drier air than many ferns.
commonExamples: Blechnum gibbum (Dwarf tree fern)
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist but not soggy. Medium humidity (50-60%) preferred. Bright indirect light. Fertilize monthly spring through fall. Repot every 1-2 years. New fronds emerge from center. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Classic houseplant ferns in the Nephrolepis genus with feathery fronds, prefer high humidity and consistent moisture.
commonExamples: Nephrolepis exaltata (Boston fern), N. cordifolia (Sword fern, Fishbone fern), N. exaltata 'Bostoniensis'
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist, never let fully dry. Mist daily or use humidifier to maintain 50-60% humidity. Bright indirect to medium light preferred; avoid direct sun. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced liquid fertilizer at half strength. Trim dead fronds at base with clean scissors. Repot every 1-2 years in spring when roots fill container. Excellent air purifiers. Brown tips indicate low humidity or inconsistent watering. Keep away from heating vents.

description: Also known as: Round-leafed fern. Compact fern with round, button-like leaflets on arching fronds, more tolerant of dry air than most ferns.
commonExamples: Pellaea rotundifolia (Button fern, Round-leafed fern)
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist but not soggy. Medium to high humidity (50-60%) preferred - more tolerant than most ferns. Bright indirect light preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Repot every 1-2 years. Compact growth habit. Round, button-like leaflets. More forgiving than delicate ferns.

description: Evergreen fern native to western North America with dimorphic fronds—sterile fronds spread outward while fertile fronds grow upright from the center.
commonExamples: Blechnum spicant (Deer fern, Hard fern)
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist but not waterlogged; never let it dry out completely. Low to medium indirect light—avoid direct sun which scorches fronds. High humidity (60%+) essential; mist regularly or use a pebble tray. Use acidic, humus-rich soil with good moisture retention. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with diluted balanced fertilizer. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Non-flowering vascular plants with delicate fronds, many species thrive in high humidity and indirect light.
commonExamples: Nephrolepis exaltata (Boston fern), Adiantum (Maidenhair fern), Pteris (Ribbon fern), Asplenium (Bird's nest fern), Platycerium (Staghorn fern)
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist but not waterlogged. Most ferns prefer high humidity (60-80%) - use pebble tray or humidifier. Bright indirect light preferred; direct sun burns delicate fronds. Mist leaves regularly or use humidifier. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Repot every 1-2 years in spring. Remove dead fronds at base. Many species are sensitive to chemicals in tap water - use filtered or distilled water. Research specific fern species for exact requirements.

description: Deciduous fern with silvery-gray fronds with purple accents, can be grown indoors in containers.
commonExamples: Athyrium niponicum (Japanese painted fern), A. niponicum 'Pictum', A. 'Ghost'
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist but not soggy. High humidity (60-70%) preferred. Bright indirect light preferred; some morning sun enhances coloration. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Goes dormant in winter - reduce watering. Repot every 2-3 years. Silvery-gray fronds with purple accents. Deciduous - fronds die back in winter.

description: Delicate ferns in the Adiantum genus with fan-shaped leaflets, requiring high humidity and consistent moisture.
commonExamples: Adiantum raddianum (Delta maidenhair), A. capillus-veneris (Southern maidenhair), A. pedatum (Northern maidenhair)
careTips: Never let soil dry - keep constantly moist but not waterlogged. High humidity (70%+) essential - use humidifier or pebble tray. Use only distilled or filtered water to prevent leaf browning from minerals. Bright indirect light preferred; avoid direct sun. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with diluted balanced fertilizer (quarter strength). Avoid touching delicate fronds. Repot carefully every 1-2 years in spring. Very challenging plant - requires consistent care.

description: Australian native fern with glossy, lobed fronds; easy-care, tolerant of drier air than most ferns.
commonExamples: Microsorum diversifolium (Kangaroo paw fern)
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist but not soggy. Medium humidity (50-60%) preferred. Bright indirect light. Fertilize monthly spring through fall. Repot every 1-2 years. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Fern with textured, reptilian-pattern fronds; tropical appearance. Medium humidity preferred.
commonExamples: Microsorum musifolium (Crocodile fern)
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist but not soggy. Medium to high humidity (50-60%) preferred. Bright indirect light. Fertilize monthly spring through fall. Repot every 1-2 years. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Compact Boston fern relative with small, round leaflets; lemony scent. More forgiving than standard Boston fern.
commonExamples: Nephrolepis cordifolia 'Duffii' (Lemon button fern)
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist but not soggy. Medium to high humidity (50-60%) preferred. Bright indirect light. Fertilize monthly spring through fall. Repot every 1-2 years. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Also known as: Golden polypody. Epiphytic fern with blue-green fronds and creeping rhizomes; tolerant of lower humidity than most ferns.
commonExamples: Phlebodium aureum (Blue star fern, Golden polypody)
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist but not soggy. Medium humidity (50-60%) fine—more tolerant than most ferns. Bright indirect light. Chunky, well-draining mix. Fertilize monthly spring through fall. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Ferns with divided, often variegated fronds; table fern is common. Non-toxic to pets.
commonExamples: Pteris cretica (Cretan brake fern, Table fern), P. ensiformis (Slender brake), P. vittata (Ladder brake), P. cretica 'Albolineata' (Silver ribbon fern)
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist but not soggy. Medium humidity (50-60%) preferred. Bright indirect light. Fertilize monthly spring through fall. Repot every 1-2 years. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Also known as: Lacy hare's foot fern. Fern with fuzzy rhizomes that resemble rabbit's feet, trailing over the pot edge, more tolerant of dry conditions.
commonExamples: Davallia fejeensis (Rabbit's foot fern, Lacy hare's foot fern), D. trichomanoides
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist but not soggy. Medium to high humidity (50-60%) preferred - more tolerant than most ferns. Bright indirect light preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Don't bury the fuzzy rhizomes - let them trail over pot edge. Repot every 2-3 years. Unique fuzzy rhizomes resemble rabbit's feet.

description: Epiphytic fern with distinctive antler-like fronds, typically mounted on boards or grown in baskets.
commonExamples: Platycerium bifurcatum (Staghorn fern, Elkhorn fern), P. superbum (Giant staghorn), P. grande, P. alcicorne
careTips: Mounted: Soak entire plant weekly for 15-30 minutes. Potted: Keep soil moist but not soggy. High humidity (60-70%) essential. Bright indirect light preferred; avoid direct sun. Fertilize monthly spring through fall by soaking in diluted fertilizer solution. Mount on wood or grow in hanging basket. Shield fronds (brown base fronds) protect roots. Don't remove shield fronds. Unique antler-like appearance.

description: Also known as: Golden cane palm. Feathery palm native to Madagascar with arching fronds, excellent air purifier.
commonExamples: Dypsis lutescens (Areca palm, Butterfly palm, Golden cane palm, Yellow palm)
careTips: Water when top 2 inches of soil is dry. Keep consistently moist but not soggy. Bright indirect light preferred. High humidity (50-60%) beneficial. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Wipe fronds monthly with damp cloth. Repot every 2-3 years when roots fill container. Excellent air purifier. Brown tips indicate low humidity or overwatering. Feathery arching fronds.

description: Also known as: Reed palm. Clumping palm with bamboo-like stems and feathery fronds; ideal for low-light spaces and narrow corners.
commonExamples: Chamaedorea seifrizii (Bamboo palm, Reed palm)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Keep evenly moist but not soggy. Low to bright indirect light tolerated. Medium humidity preferred; mist if air is dry. Fertilize monthly spring through fall at half strength. Repot every 2-3 years. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Chamaedorea palm with pinnate fronds; cold-tolerant, can grow in ground in mild climates. Related to parlor palm.
commonExamples: Chamaedorea radicalis (Radicalis palm)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect light preferred. Medium humidity fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with palm fertilizer. Repot every 1-2 years. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Ancient cycad (not a true palm) with feathery fronds emerging from a woody trunk.
commonExamples: Cycas revoluta (Sago palm, King sago), C. circinalis
careTips: Water when top half of soil is dry. Bright indirect light preferred. Slow-growing; very long-lived. Fertilize 2-3 times per year. Extremely toxic to pets — ingestion is often fatal to dogs and cats, even in small amounts. Also toxic to humans - handle with care.

description: Hardy, slow-growing palm with fan-shaped leaves, very low-maintenance and cold-tolerant.
commonExamples: Chamaerops humilis (European fan palm, Mediterranean fan palm, Dwarf fan palm)
careTips: Water when top 2 inches of soil is dry. Allow to dry slightly between waterings. Bright indirect to direct light preferred. Low to medium humidity is fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with palm fertilizer at half strength. Very slow-growing. Cold-tolerant compared to other palms. Repot every 3-4 years. Low-maintenance palm.

description: Elegant, slow-growing palm native to Lord Howe Island, very low-maintenance and tolerant of low light.
commonExamples: Howea forsteriana (Kentia palm, Sentry palm, Thatch palm)
careTips: Water when top 2 inches of soil is dry. Keep consistently moist but not soggy. Low to bright indirect light tolerated - very adaptable. Medium humidity (40-50%) is fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with palm fertilizer at half strength. Wipe fronds monthly. Repot every 2-3 years. Slow-growing and elegant. Very low-maintenance palm. Brown tips indicate overwatering or low humidity.

description: Slow-growing, clumping palm with fan-shaped leaves, very low-maintenance and tolerant of low light.
commonExamples: Rhapis excelsa (Lady palm, Broadleaf lady palm), R. humilis (Slender lady palm)
careTips: Water when top 2 inches of soil is dry. Keep consistently moist but not soggy. Low to bright indirect light tolerated. Medium humidity (40-50%) is fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with palm fertilizer at half strength. Wipe fronds monthly. Repot every 2-3 years. Slow-growing and clumping habit. Very low-maintenance. Brown tips indicate overwatering.

description: Fast-growing palm with feathery fronds, requires high humidity and consistent moisture.
commonExamples: Ravenea rivularis (Majesty palm, Majestic palm)
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist (water when top inch is dry). Never let fully dry out. High humidity (60%+) essential - use humidifier or pebble tray. Bright indirect light preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with palm fertilizer. Wipe fronds monthly. Repot annually in spring. Fast-growing but requires consistent care. Brown tips indicate low humidity or inconsistent watering.

description: Tropical and subtropical plants in the Arecaceae family with architectural fronds, popular for adding a tropical feel indoors and outdoors.
commonExamples: Chamaedorea elegans (Parlor palm), Dypsis lutescens (Areca palm, Butterfly palm), Howea forsteriana (Kentia palm), Rhapis excelsa (Lady palm)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Do not overwater — root rot is the most common cause of palm death. Bright indirect light preferred; most tolerate lower light. Medium to high humidity (40-60%) preferred — mist regularly or use a humidifier. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with palm-specific fertilizer. Do not cut brown tips — trim just above the brown line. Remove only fully brown fronds. Repot infrequently — palms dislike root disturbance. Watch for spider mites and mealybugs.

description: Also known as: Neanthe Bella Palm, Bella Palm. Small, low-light tolerant palm native to Central America with delicate fronds, perfect for offices and low-light spaces.
commonExamples: Chamaedorea elegans (Parlor palm, Neanthe bella palm, Good luck palm)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Keep slightly moist but avoid overwatering. Low to bright indirect light tolerated - perfect for offices. Medium humidity (40-50%) is fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Repot every 2-3 years. Slow-growing and compact. One of the best low-light palms. Brown tips indicate overwatering or low humidity.

description: Compact date palm with arching fronds; slow-growing. Non-toxic to pets.
commonExamples: Phoenix roebelenii (Pygmy date palm, Dwarf date palm)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect light preferred. Medium humidity fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall. Repot every 1-2 years. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Also known as: Elephant's foot. Succulent in the Asparagaceae family with swollen caudex that stores water (not a true palm), very drought tolerant.
commonExamples: Beaucarnea recurvata (Ponytail palm, Elephant's foot, Bottle palm)
careTips: Water when soil is completely dry (every 2-4 weeks). Caudex (swollen base) stores water making it very drought tolerant. Overwatering causes root rot. Bright indirect to direct light preferred. Low humidity is fine. Fertilize 2-3 times per year during growing season with balanced fertilizer at quarter strength. Repot every 3-5 years. Not a true palm despite the name. Can live for decades.

description: Also known as: Tree houseleek. Succulents in the Crassulaceae family with rosette-forming leaves, some varieties are monocarpic.
commonExamples: Aeonium arboreum (Tree houseleek), A. 'Zwartkop' (Black rose), A. haworthii (Pinwheel aeonium), A. 'Kiwi'
careTips: Water when soil is completely dry (every 2-3 weeks). More water-tolerant than some succulents but still drought tolerant. Bright indirect to direct light preferred. Low humidity is fine. Fertilize 2-3 times per year during growing season with succulent fertilizer. Well-draining soil essential. Some varieties are monocarpic (die after flowering). Repot every 2-3 years. Rosette-forming succulents.

description: Rosette-forming succulent with thick, fleshy leaves often tipped with spines. Extremely drought tolerant. Many species are monocarpic — they bloom once after many years and then die, but produce offsets (pups).
commonExamples: Agave americana (Century plant), A. attenuata (Fox tail agave), A. victoriae-reginae (Queen Victoria agave), A. parryi (Artichoke agave)
careTips: Water deeply but infrequently — every 2-4 weeks depending on season. Full sun to bright direct light. Very low humidity tolerance. Excellent drainage is critical — use cactus/succulent mix. Cold hardiness varies by species. Mildly toxic — sap can cause skin irritation.

description: Also known as: Medicinal aloe. Medicinal succulent with gel-filled leaves, commonly used for skin care.
commonExamples: Aloe vera (Aloe, Medicinal aloe)
careTips: Water when soil is completely dry (every 2-3 weeks). Water deeply but infrequently. Bright indirect to direct light preferred. Low humidity is fine. Fertilize 2-3 times per year during growing season with balanced fertilizer at quarter strength. Remove offsets (pups) when 1/3 size of parent to propagate. Repot every 2-3 years. Gel from leaves has medicinal properties for skin care. Overwatering causes rot. Toxic to pets if ingested. Mildly toxic to humans if ingested; gel is safe for topical skin use.

description: Rosette-forming succulents in the Asphodelaceae family with medicinal properties, many produce offsets (pups) for propagation.
commonExamples: Aloe vera (Medicinal aloe, Burn plant), A. arborescens (Torch aloe, Candelabra aloe), A. polyphylla (Spiral aloe), A. aristata (Lace aloe)
careTips: Water when soil is completely dry (every 2-4 weeks). Water deeply but infrequently. Very drought tolerant. Bright indirect to direct light preferred. Low humidity is fine. Fertilize 2-3 times per year during growing season with balanced fertilizer at quarter strength. Remove offsets (pups) when they're 1/3 the size of parent plant to propagate. Repot every 2-3 years. Many species have medicinal properties.

description: Fuzzy succulent with thick, toothed leaves resembling bear paws, tips turn red in bright light. Native to South Africa.
commonExamples: Cotyledon tomentosa (Bear's paw), C. tomentosa subsp. ladismithiensis (Narrow bear's paw)
careTips: Water when soil is completely dry (every 2-3 weeks). Very sensitive to overwatering - root rot is the main threat. Bright indirect light preferred; tips turn red with more light exposure. Avoid harsh direct midday sun. Low humidity preferred. Fertilize 2-3 times per year with succulent fertilizer at quarter strength. Excellent drainage essential - use cactus/succulent mix. Handle gently - fuzzy leaves are delicate. Repot every 2-3 years. Toxic to pets.

description: Also known as: Donkey's Tail, Lamb's tail. Trailing succulent with delicate, plump blue-green leaves that drop easily if disturbed.
commonExamples: Sedum morganianum (Burro's tail, Donkey's tail, Lamb's tail)
careTips: Water when soil is dry, but more frequently than most succulents. Handle very carefully - leaves drop easily if disturbed. Water at base to avoid wetting leaves. Bright indirect light preferred; direct sun may burn. Medium humidity preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with succulent fertilizer at half strength. Perfect for hanging baskets. Repot carefully every 2-3 years. Very delicate - avoid moving once established.

description: Also known as: Compact jade, Mini jade. Compact jade plant cultivar with smaller leaves; same care as standard jade, ideal for small spaces.
commonExamples: Crassula ovata 'Minor' (Compact jade, Mini jade)
careTips: Water when soil is completely dry (every 2-3 weeks). Bright indirect to direct light. Low humidity fine. Fertilize 2-3 times per year. Toxic to pets.

description: Succulents in the Crassulaceae family with thick fleshy leaves, many form tree-like structures over time.
commonExamples: Crassula ovata (Jade plant, Money tree), C. perforata (String of buttons), C. tetragona (Miniature pine tree), C. arborescens (Silver jade plant)
careTips: Water when soil is completely dry (every 2-3 weeks). Water deeply but infrequently. Reduce watering significantly in winter when growth slows. Bright indirect to direct light preferred. Low humidity is fine. Fertilize 2-3 times per year during growing season with balanced fertilizer at quarter strength. Can be trained as bonsai. Repot every 2-3 years. Many form tree-like structures over time.

description: Rosette-forming succulents with colorful, often powdery leaves, popular in arrangements.
commonExamples: Echeveria elegans, E. 'Perle von Nurnberg', E. agavoides, E. pulidonis
careTips: Water when soil is completely dry (every 1-2 weeks). Water at base to avoid wetting leaves - water on leaves can cause rot. Bright indirect to direct light preferred. Low humidity is fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with succulent fertilizer at half strength. Remove dead lower leaves. Repot every 2-3 years. Popular in succulent arrangements. Powdery coating (farina) protects from sun - don't rub off.

description: Striking succulent with thin, pencil-like branches that turn vibrant red-orange in bright light, though actually a euphorbia, not a true cactus.
commonExamples: Euphorbia tirucalli (Pencil cactus, Firestick plant, Milk bush), E. tirucalli 'Sticks on Fire'
careTips: Water sparingly; allow soil to dry completely between waterings. Strong direct light for best color—full sun produces vibrant red tips. Low humidity preferred. Well-draining sandy or gritty succulent mix. Fertilize lightly once in spring. Handle with extreme care—white milky sap is highly irritating to skin and eyes; wear gloves when pruning. Can grow quite large indoors (up to 2 meters). Toxic to pets and humans (caustic latex sap).

description: Also known as: Cathedral cactus. Candelabra-shaped succulent with green stems and leaves; milky sap is toxic—handle with care.
commonExamples: Euphorbia trigona (African milk tree, Cathedral cactus)
careTips: Water when soil is dry (every 1-2 weeks). Bright indirect light. Low humidity fine. Fertilize 2-3 times per year. Toxic sap—wear gloves, wash hands. Toxic to pets.

description: Diverse genus including many succulent species with milky sap (toxic, handle with care).
commonExamples: Euphorbia trigona (African milk tree), E. milii (Crown of thorns), E. obesa (Baseball plant)
careTips: Water when soil is completely dry (every 2-4 weeks). Very drought tolerant. Bright indirect to direct light preferred. Low humidity is fine. Fertilize 2-3 times per year during growing season with balanced fertilizer at quarter strength. Milky sap is toxic and can cause skin irritation - handle with care and wash hands after touching. Repot every 2-3 years. Diverse genus with many forms. Research specific species for exact requirements.

description: Tongue-shaped succulents closely related to Haworthia and Aloe in the family Asphodelaceae; shade-tolerant and easy-care.
commonExamples: Gasteria bicolor, G. verrucosa, G. 'Little Warty'
careTips: Water when soil is dry (every 1-2 weeks). More frequent than desert succulents. Bright indirect to medium light preferred; tolerates lower light than most succulents. Medium humidity preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Repot every 2-3 years. Shade-tolerant and easy-care. Related to Haworthia.

description: Also known as: Mother-of-pearl plant. Succulents in the Crassulaceae family with rosette-forming leaves, often called ghost plants.
commonExamples: Graptopetalum paraguayense (Ghost plant, Mother-of-pearl plant), G. 'Copper Rose', G. 'Purple Delight'
careTips: Water when soil is completely dry (every 2-3 weeks). Very drought tolerant. Bright indirect to direct light preferred - more light enhances coloration. Low humidity is fine. Fertilize 2-3 times per year during growing season with succulent fertilizer at quarter strength. Well-draining soil essential. Repot every 2-3 years. Rosette-forming with beautiful coloration. Often called ghost plants.

description: Intergeneric hybrid between Graptopetalum and Echeveria, forming compact rosettes with thick, fleshy leaves in pastel hues that intensify with sun stress.
commonExamples: x Graptoveria 'Fred Ives' (Fred Ives), x Graptoveria 'Opalina' (Opalina), x Graptoveria 'Debbie' (Debbie), x Graptoveria 'Bashful' (Bashful)
careTips: Water thoroughly using the soak-and-dry method; allow soil to dry completely between waterings. Provide bright indirect to direct morning light for best coloration — insufficient light causes etiolation. Use a fast-draining cactus or succulent mix with added perlite. Fertilize once in spring and once in mid-summer with a diluted succulent fertilizer. Protect from frost below 5°C. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Small rosette succulents that tolerate lower light than most succulents, perfect for windowsills.
commonExamples: Haworthia cooperi, H. fasciata (Zebra plant), H. attenuata, H. limifolia
careTips: Water when soil is dry (every 1-2 weeks). More frequent than desert succulents. Bright indirect to medium light preferred; tolerates lower light than most succulents. Medium humidity preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Repot every 2-3 years. Perfect for windowsills. Small rosette-forming succulents.

description: Also known as: Money plant, Lucky plant. Classic succulent with thick, glossy green leaves, can live for decades and grow into a small tree.
commonExamples: Crassula ovata (Jade plant, Money plant, Lucky plant)
careTips: Water when soil is completely dry (every 2-3 weeks). Water deeply but infrequently. Bright indirect to direct light preferred - needs good light to maintain compact growth. Low humidity is fine. Fertilize 2-3 times per year during growing season with balanced fertilizer at quarter strength. Can live for decades and grow into small tree. Prune to maintain shape. Repot every 2-3 years. Symbol of good luck. Overwatering causes root rot. Toxic if ingested by pets.

description: Also known as: Flapjack. Succulent with flat, paddle-shaped leaves that blush red at edges in bright light; monocarpic (dies after flowering).
commonExamples: Kalanchoe luciae (Flapjack, Paddle plant)
careTips: Water when soil is dry (every 1-2 weeks). Bright light enhances red edges. Low humidity fine. Fertilize sparingly. Toxic to pets.

description: Stone-like succulents that mimic pebbles in their native habitat, have specific dormancy periods when they should not be watered.
commonExamples: Lithops (Living stones, Pebble plants), various species with different colors and patterns
careTips: Water sparingly in fall when new leaves emerge. Keep dry in summer dormancy and during winter/spring splitting. Very minimal watering even when active (every 2-4 weeks). Bright direct light essential. Low humidity preferred. Fertilize very sparingly during active growth only. Repot every 3-5 years in very well-draining soil. Stone-like appearance mimics pebbles. Very specific care requirements.

description: Also known as: Moonstones. Adorable succulents with plump, egg-shaped leaves in pastel shades of lavender, pink, and blue-grey, often covered in a powdery farina coating.
commonExamples: Pachyphytum oviferum (Moonstones, Sugar almond plant), P. compactum (Little jewel), P. bracteosum (Silverbracts)
careTips: Water only when soil is completely dry; soak and drain method works best. Bright indirect to gentle direct light—too much harsh sun can sunburn delicate leaves. Low humidity preferred—prone to rot in damp conditions. Gritty, fast-draining succulent mix essential. Fertilize once in spring with diluted cactus fertilizer.
