Avoid touching leaves—the farina coating doesn't grow back. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Also known as: Spekboom. Small-leaved succulent often confused with jade; drought-tolerant, can be bonsai-trained. Native to South Africa.
commonExamples: Portulacaria afra (Dwarf jade, Spekboom, Elephant bush)
careTips: Water when soil is dry (every 1-2 weeks). Bright indirect to direct light. Low humidity fine. Fertilize 2-3 times per year. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Large genus of succulents in the Crassulaceae family, includes both trailing and upright varieties.
commonExamples: Sedum morganianum (Burro's tail), S. rubrotinctum (Jelly bean plant), S. adolphii (Golden sedum), S. 'Autumn Joy'
careTips: Water when soil is completely dry (every 2-3 weeks). Very drought tolerant. Bright indirect to direct light preferred. Low humidity is fine. Fertilize 2-3 times per year during growing season with succulent fertilizer at quarter strength. Well-draining soil essential. Repot every 2-3 years. Many varieties available - trailing and upright. Very easy-care succulents.

description: Also known as: Hen and chicks. Hardy succulents in the Crassulaceae family known as hen and chicks, form rosettes and produce offsets. Extremely cold hardy and drought tolerant. Excellent for rock gardens, alpine gardens, and containers.
commonExamples: Sempervivum tectorum (Common houseleek, Hen and chicks), S. arachnoideum (Cobweb houseleek), many cultivars in various colors
careTips: Water when soil is completely dry (every 2-3 weeks). Very drought tolerant. Bright indirect to direct light preferred. Low humidity is fine. Fertilize sparingly (2-3 times per year) with succulent fertilizer at quarter strength. Well-draining soil essential. Produces offsets (chicks) around parent plant (hen). Repot every 2-3 years. Very cold-hardy succulents.

description: Large genus of succulents in the Asteraceae family, includes trailing varieties like string of pearls (many reclassified to Curio).
commonExamples: Curio rowleyanus (syn. Senecio rowleyanus; String of pearls), Curio radicans (syn. S. radicans; String of bananas), Curio repens (syn. Senecio serpens; Blue chalk sticks), Curio talinoides subsp. mandraliscae (syn. Senecio mandraliscae)
careTips: Water when soil is completely dry (every 2-3 weeks). Very drought tolerant. Bright indirect to direct light preferred. Low humidity is fine. Fertilize 2-3 times per year during growing season with succulent fertilizer at quarter strength. Well-draining soil essential. Many are trailing plants. Repot every 2-3 years. Large genus with many varieties.

description: Stone-mimicking succulent that resembles a split boulder, closely related to lithops but slightly larger. Native to South Africa.
commonExamples: Pleiospilos nelii (Split rock, Cleft stone, Mimicry plant), P. nelii 'Royal Flush' (purple form)
careTips: Water ONLY when old leaves have fully dried and absorbed into the new pair - typically only 2-4 times per year. Overwatering causes stacking (extra leaf pairs) and rot. Bright direct light essential - at least 5 hours daily. Very low humidity preferred. Do not fertilize. Excellent drainage essential - use mostly mineral substrate (pumice, perlite). Bottom watering preferred. Repot every 3-5 years. Very specific watering requirements similar to lithops.

description: Trailing succulent with banana-shaped leaves, faster growing than String of Pearls.
commonExamples: Curio radicans (String of bananas, syn. Senecio radicans)
careTips: Water when leaves show slight wrinkling - this indicates thirst. Avoid overwatering which causes rot. Bright indirect light preferred. Medium humidity preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with succulent fertilizer at half strength. Faster growing than String of Pearls. Perfect for hanging baskets. Repot every 2-3 years. Handle carefully to avoid leaf drop. Banana-shaped leaves. Toxic if ingested by pets.

description: Also known as: Dolphin Plant, Dolphin Succulent. Trailing succulent with leaves shaped like leaping dolphins.
commonExamples: Curio × peregrinus (String of dolphins, syn. Senecio × peregrinus)
careTips: Water when leaves show slight wrinkling - this indicates thirst. Avoid overwatering which causes rot. Bright indirect light preferred. Medium humidity preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with succulent fertilizer at half strength. Unique dolphin-shaped leaves. Perfect for hanging baskets. Repot every 2-3 years. Handle carefully. Toxic if ingested by pets.

description: Trailing succulent with heart-shaped leaves and purple undersides, produces tubers along stems.
commonExamples: Ceropegia woodii (String of hearts, Rosary vine, Chain of hearts)
careTips: Water when soil is dry (every 1-2 weeks). More drought tolerant than String of Pearls due to tubers along stems. Bright indirect light preferred. Medium humidity preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Produces tubers along stems for storage. Perfect for hanging baskets. Repot every 2-3 years. Heart-shaped leaves with purple undersides. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Delicate trailing succulent with thin, needle-like leaves along wiry stems. Related to string of hearts but with a finer, more airy appearance.
commonExamples: Ceropegia linearis (String of needles)
careTips: Water when soil is completely dry. Bright indirect light preferred; tolerates some direct morning sun. Low humidity is fine. Very susceptible to overwatering — use well-draining succulent mix. Fertilize lightly spring through summer. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Trailing succulent with bead-like leaves, perfect for hanging baskets.
commonExamples: Curio rowleyanus (String of pearls, syn. Senecio rowleyanus), C. herreianus (String of beads)
careTips: Water when pearls (leaves) show slight wrinkling - this indicates thirst. Avoid overwatering which causes rot. Bright indirect light preferred. Medium humidity preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with succulent fertilizer at half strength. Perfect for hanging baskets. Repot every 2-3 years. Bead-like leaves are delicate - handle carefully. Very popular trailing succulent. Toxic to pets.

description: Trailing succulent with bean-shaped leaves that turn deep ruby-red in bright light; stems are purple-tinged.
commonExamples: Othonna capensis (String of rubies, Ruby necklace, Little pickles)
careTips: Water thoroughly when soil is completely dry; drought-tolerant. Bright indirect to direct light brings out intense red coloring—green in low light. Low humidity fine. Use well-draining succulent/cactus mix. Fertilize sparingly 2-3 times during growing season at quarter strength. Propagates easily from stem cuttings. Toxic to pets.

description: Also known as: Turtle Vine, Peperomia Prostrata. Trailing peperomia with small, patterned leaves resembling turtle shells, slower growing than other string plants.
commonExamples: Peperomia prostrata (String of turtles, Turtle vine), P. prostrata 'Variegata' (variegated form)
careTips: Water when top 2 inches of soil is dry. Keep slightly more moist than other string plants but still avoid overwatering. Bright indirect light preferred. High humidity (60%+) preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Slower growing than other string plants. Perfect for hanging baskets. Repot every 2-3 years. Small patterned leaves resembling turtle shells.

description: Compact aloe with dark green to black-tinted leaves; same care as aloe vera. Toxic to pets.
commonExamples: Aloe 'Black Gem'
careTips: Water when soil is dry (every 2-3 weeks). Bright indirect to direct light. Low humidity fine. Fertilize 2-3 times per year. Toxic to pets.

description: Hybrid echeveria with lavender-pink rosettes; powdery farina. Non-toxic to pets.
commonExamples: Echeveria 'Lola'
careTips: Water when soil is dry (every 1-2 weeks). Water at base to avoid farina. Bright light preferred. Low humidity fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Also known as: PVN. Popular echeveria with purple-pink rosettes and powdery farina; classic succulent. Non-toxic to pets.
commonExamples: Echeveria 'Perle von Nurnberg' (PVN)
careTips: Water when soil is dry (every 1-2 weeks). Water at base to avoid farina. Bright light enhances color. Low humidity fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Also known as: Window plant. Haworthia with translucent "window" leaves; tolerates lower light than most succulents. Non-toxic to pets.
commonExamples: Haworthia cooperi (Window plant)
careTips: Water when soil is dry (every 1-2 weeks). Bright indirect to medium light—tolerates lower light. Medium humidity fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Drought-adapted plants with water-storing leaves, need excellent drainage.
commonExamples: Echeveria, Sedum, Graptopetalum, Graptoveria
careTips: Water when soil is completely dry (every 1-3 weeks depending on conditions). Water deeply but infrequently. Excellent drainage is essential - use cactus/succulent mix. Bright indirect to direct light preferred. Low humidity is fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with succulent fertilizer at half strength. Repot every 2-3 years. Drought-adapted plants with water-storing leaves.

description: Also known as: Golden barrel cactus. Round, barrel-shaped cacti that can grow quite large, very low-maintenance.
commonExamples: Echinocactus grusonii (Golden barrel cactus), Ferocactus (Barrel cactus), E. texensis (Horse crippler)
careTips: Water when soil is completely dry (every 3-4 weeks in summer, less in winter). Very drought tolerant. Full sun to bright indirect light preferred. Low humidity is fine. Fertilize 2-3 times per year during growing season with cactus fertilizer at quarter strength. Well-draining soil essential. Can grow quite large. Repot every 3-5 years. Very low-maintenance. Handle with care - sharp spines.

description: Desert plants in the Cactaceae family with spines and areoles, need excellent drainage and bright light.
commonExamples: Echinocactus (Barrel cactus), Opuntia (Prickly pear, Bunny ears), Mammillaria (Pincushion cactus), Ferocactus
careTips: Water when soil is completely dry (every 3-6 weeks). Water deeply but infrequently. Reduce significantly or stop watering in winter dormancy (November-February). Bright direct light essential - full sun preferred. Low humidity preferred. Fertilize 2-3 times per year during growing season with cactus fertilizer at quarter strength. Excellent drainage essential. Repot every 3-5 years. Handle with care - spines are sharp.

description: Also known as: True Christmas cactus. Forest cactus that blooms around Christmas, requires cool temperatures and reduced light to flower, has rounded leaf segments.
commonExamples: Schlumbergera × buckleyi (Christmas cactus, True Christmas cactus), S. truncata (Thanksgiving cactus, often mislabeled as Christmas cactus)
careTips: Keep soil slightly moist spring through summer. Reduce watering in fall (September-October) to encourage blooms - this triggers bud formation. More frequent watering than desert cacti. Bright indirect light preferred; avoid direct hot sun. High humidity (50-60%) preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Cool temperatures (60-65°F) and reduced light in fall encourage flowering. Repot every 2-3 years. Rounded leaf segments distinguish from Thanksgiving cactus.

description: Forest cactus that blooms in spring, with rounded leaf segments.
commonExamples: Hatiora gaertneri (Easter cactus, syn. Rhipsalidopsis gaertneri)
careTips: Keep soil slightly moist spring through summer. Reduce watering in winter (December-February) to encourage spring blooms. Bright indirect light preferred. High humidity (50-60%) preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Cool temperatures in winter encourage flowering. Repot every 2-3 years. Rounded leaf segments. Blooms in spring (Easter time).

description: Round or columnar cacti that produce large, funnel-shaped flowers in white, pink, or red, often opening at night.
commonExamples: Echinopsis spp. (Easter lily cactus)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect light preferred; some morning sun is fine. Medium humidity (40-50%). Fertilize monthly spring through fall with cactus fertilizer. Large flowers bloom spring through summer. Repot every 1-2 years when roots fill container.

description: Epiphytic woodland cactus with flat, leaf-like stems that produce spectacular nocturnal flowers in many colors.
commonExamples: Epiphyllum spp. (Orchid cactus)
careTips: Keep soil slightly moist spring through summer; reduce watering in winter. Bright indirect light preferred; avoid strong midday sun. Medium humidity (40-50%). Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Epiphytic—use well-draining mix. Repot every 2-3 years.

description: Epiphytic cacti native to tropical forests, require different care from desert cacti with higher humidity needs.
commonExamples: Schlumbergera (Christmas cactus, Thanksgiving cactus), Rhipsalis (Mistletoe cactus), Epiphyllum (Orchid cactus, Queen of the night)
careTips: Keep soil slightly moist spring through summer. More frequent watering than desert cacti. Reduce watering in fall for bloom induction. Bright indirect light preferred; some direct morning sun is fine. High humidity (50-60%) preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Epiphytic cacti native to tropical forests. Repot every 2-3 years in well-draining mix. Different care from desert cacti.

description: Also known as: Moon cactus. Small, round cacti with chin-like notches above each areole; Moon cactus is a colorful grafted form.
commonExamples: Gymnocalycium mihanovichii (Moon cactus)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect light preferred; avoid intense direct sun. Medium humidity (40-50%). Fertilize monthly spring through fall with cactus fertilizer. Moon cactus is grafted—keep colorful top from burning. Repot every 1-2 years when roots fill container.

description: Compact, round cacti with spiral tubercles and a crown of small flowers in spring.
commonExamples: Mammillaria spp. (Pincushion cactus)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect or direct light preferred. Medium humidity (40-50%). Fertilize monthly spring through fall with cactus fertilizer. Flowers form a ring around the crown in spring. Well-draining soil essential. Repot every 1-2 years when roots fill container.

description: Round, woolly cactus covered in white hairs, produces pink flowers.
commonExamples: Mammillaria hahniana (Old lady cactus), M. bocasana (Powder puff cactus)
careTips: Water when soil is completely dry (every 3-4 weeks in summer, less in winter). Very drought tolerant. Bright indirect to direct light preferred. Low humidity is fine. Fertilize 2-3 times per year during growing season with cactus fertilizer. Well-draining soil essential. Covered in white hairs giving woolly appearance. Produces pink flowers in spring. Repot every 3-5 years. Compact, round growth habit.

description: Flat-padded cactus with glochids (tiny barbed spines) instead of large spines; handle with care.
commonExamples: Opuntia microdasys (Bunny ears, Polka dot cactus)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect to direct light preferred. Medium humidity (40-50%). Fertilize monthly spring through fall with cactus fertilizer. Handle with extreme care—glochids detach easily and are very irritating. Repot every 1-2 years when roots fill container.

description: Round, ribbed cacti that produce yellow or golden flowers from the crown.
commonExamples: Parodia leninghausii, P. magnifica
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect or direct light preferred. Medium humidity (40-50%). Fertilize monthly spring through fall with cactus fertilizer. Golden flowers bloom spring through summer. Well-draining soil essential. Repot every 1-2 years when roots fill container.

description: Flat-padded cacti in the Opuntia genus, can produce edible fruit, very low-maintenance.
commonExamples: Opuntia ficus-indica (Indian fig opuntia), O. microdasys (Bunny ears), O. humifusa (Eastern prickly pear)
careTips: Water when soil is completely dry (every 3-4 weeks in summer, less in winter). Very drought tolerant. Full sun to bright indirect light preferred. Low humidity is fine. Fertilize 2-3 times per year during growing season with cactus fertilizer. Well-draining soil essential. Flat, pad-like stems. Can produce edible fruit. Repot every 3-5 years. Handle with extreme care - tiny glochids are very irritating.

description: Trailing cactus with long, thin stems covered in spines, produces bright pink or red flowers.
commonExamples: Aporocactus flagelliformis (Rat tail cactus), Disocactus flagelliformis
careTips: Water when soil is completely dry (every 2-3 weeks in summer, less in winter). More water-tolerant than some cacti. Bright indirect to direct light preferred. Medium humidity (40-50%) preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with cactus fertilizer at half strength. Trailing growth habit - perfect for hanging baskets. Produces bright pink or red flowers. Repot every 2-3 years. Long, thin trailing stems.

description: Genus-level entry: epiphytic jungle cacti with branching, often pendulous stems; spineless and ideal for hanging baskets.
commonExamples: Rhipsalis baccifera (Mistletoe cactus), R. cereuscula (Coral cactus), R. pilocarpa (Hairy-stemmed rhipsalis), R. ewaldiana, R. mesembryanthemoides
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect light preferred; avoid direct sun. Medium humidity (40-50%). Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Epiphytic—well-draining mix. Trailing habit suits hanging baskets. Repot every 2-3 years.

description: Also known as: Giant cactus. Iconic columnar cactus of the Sonoran Desert, growing up to 12m tall with arm-like branches. Extremely slow-growing; takes 10 years to reach 2.5cm.
commonExamples: Carnegiea gigantea (Saguaro cactus)
careTips: Water deeply but infrequently — every 2-4 weeks in summer, monthly or less in winter. Requires full sun and excellent drainage. Use cactus mix with extra perlite. Extremely slow grower; indoor specimens rarely exceed 30cm. Tolerates extreme heat but protect from frost below -5°C. Fertilize once in spring with dilute cactus fertilizer. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Small, round cactus with star-shaped pattern, very slow-growing and rare.
commonExamples: Astrophytum asterias (Star cactus, Sand dollar cactus, Sea urchin cactus)
careTips: Water when soil is completely dry (every 3-4 weeks in summer, very little in winter). Very drought tolerant. Bright indirect to direct light preferred. Low humidity is fine. Fertilize sparingly (2-3 times per year) with cactus fertilizer at quarter strength. Well-draining soil essential. Very slow-growing. Star-shaped pattern on top. Produces yellow flowers. Repot every 3-5 years. Rare and protected in wild.

description: Also known as: Crab cactus. Forest cactus that blooms in late fall, similar to Christmas cactus but with pointed leaf segments.
commonExamples: Schlumbergera truncata (Thanksgiving cactus, Crab cactus)
careTips: Keep soil slightly moist spring through summer. Reduce watering in fall (September-October) to encourage blooms. Bright indirect light preferred. High humidity (50-60%) preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Pointed leaf segments distinguish from Christmas cactus. Blooms in late fall (Thanksgiving time). Repot every 2-3 years.

description: Compact flowering plants in the Gesneriaceae family with fuzzy leaves and colorful blooms, avoid getting water on leaves. Includes various cultivars with different flower colors, single, double, or ruffled flowers.
commonExamples: Saintpaulia ionantha (African violet), various cultivars with different flower colors, single, double, or ruffled flowers
careTips: Keep soil lightly moist. Always water from bottom or avoid wetting leaves - water on leaves causes permanent spots. Use room temperature water. Bright indirect light preferred; direct sun burns leaves. High humidity (50-60%) preferred. Fertilize every 2-3 weeks with African violet fertilizer to encourage continuous blooms. Repot annually in spring. Remove spent flowers. Crown rot is common - avoid overwatering.

description: Classic tropical houseplant with glossy, heart-shaped spathes in red, pink, white, or coral that bloom year-round with proper care.
commonExamples: Anthurium andraeanum (Flamingo flower, Flamingo lily, Laceleaf), A. scherzerianum (Pigtail anthurium)
careTips: Water when top 2-3 cm of soil is dry; keep slightly moist but never soggy. Bright indirect light—direct sun bleaches spathes. High humidity (60%+) preferred; mist regularly or use a pebble tray. Well-draining, chunky aroid mix. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with quarter-strength phosphorus-rich fertilizer to promote flowering. Wipe leaves to remove dust. Toxic to pets (calcium oxalate crystals).

description: Cane begonias with wing-shaped spotted leaves and pendent flower clusters in red, pink, or white.
commonExamples: Begonia coccinea, B. 'Lucerna'
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect light preferred; some morning sun is fine. Medium humidity (40-50%). Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer. Prune leggy stems to encourage bushiness. Toxic to pets. Repot every 1-2 years when roots fill container.

description: Cane begonia with silver-spotted leaves, red undersides, and white flower clusters. The most commonly sold form is the 'Wightii' cultivar.
commonExamples: Begonia maculata (Polka dot begonia, Spotted begonia), B. maculata 'Wightii' (most common cultivar)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect light preferred; avoid direct sun. Medium humidity (40-50%). Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer. Leaf spots fade in low light. Toxic to pets. Repot every 1-2 years when roots fill container.

description: Rhizomatous begonia grown for its spectacular, multicolored foliage in swirling patterns of silver, purple, pink, red, and green. One of the most ornamental houseplant species.
commonExamples: Begonia rex-cultorum (Rex begonia, Painted-leaf begonia, King begonia), 'Escargot' (spiral pattern), 'Fireworks', 'Silver Dollar'
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry; avoid getting water on leaves. Bright indirect light — direct sun scorches leaves. High humidity (50%+) preferred. Well-draining soil. Feed every 2-4 weeks spring through fall. May go dormant in winter. Toxic to pets.

description: Also known as: Silver vase plant. Bromeliads with pink flower spikes and silver-banded leaves.
commonExamples: Aechmea fasciata (Silver vase plant, Urn plant), A. 'Blue Rain'
careTips: Keep central cup (tank) filled with water at all times. Water soil when dry. Change cup water monthly to prevent stagnation and mosquito breeding. Bright indirect light preferred. High humidity (50-60%) preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall by adding diluted fertilizer to cup water. Flower spike lasts months. After flowering, plant produces offsets (pups) - parent plant dies but pups can be separated and repotted.

description: Colorful bromeliads with bright, long-lasting flower spikes.
commonExamples: Guzmania lingulata, G. 'Luna', G. 'Rana'
careTips: Keep central cup (tank) filled with water at all times. Water soil when dry. Change cup water monthly to prevent stagnation. Bright indirect light preferred. High humidity (50-60%) preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall by adding diluted fertilizer to cup water. Bright, long-lasting flower spikes. After flowering, plant produces offsets (pups) - parent dies but pups can be separated and repotted.

description: Tropical plants in the Bromeliaceae family with rosette growth and central cups (tanks) that hold water.
commonExamples: Guzmania (Flaming sword), Tillandsia (some species), Aechmea (Urn plant), Neoregelia (Blushing bromeliad)
careTips: Keep central cup (tank) filled with water at all times. Water soil when dry. Change cup water monthly to prevent stagnation and mosquito breeding. Bright indirect light preferred. High humidity (50-60%) preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall by adding diluted fertilizer to cup water. After flowering, plant produces offsets (pups) - parent dies but pups can be separated. Most bloom once then produce pups.

description: Shade-tolerant flowering plant with strap-like leaves and striking orange or yellow flower clusters.
commonExamples: Clivia miniata (Bush lily), C. nobilis
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Needs a cool, dry rest period (6-8 weeks in fall) with minimal watering to trigger blooming. Bright indirect light preferred; tolerates low light. Keep slightly pot-bound to encourage flowering. Fertilize monthly spring through summer. Toxic to pets.

description: Also known as: Arabian coffee. Glossy-leaved shrub that can produce white flowers and red coffee cherries indoors.
commonExamples: Coffea arabica (Arabian coffee)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect light preferred. Medium humidity (40-50%). Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer. Berries need several years to ripen. Acidic soil preferred. Toxic to pets. Repot every 1-2 years when roots fill container.

description: Trailing gesneriad with tubular flowers resembling goldfish; ideal for hanging baskets.
commonExamples: Columnea gloriosa (Column flower)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect light preferred; avoid direct sun. Medium humidity (40-50%). Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Compact winter rest encourages blooming. Non-toxic to pets. Repot every 1-2 years when roots fill container.

description: Thorny succulent shrub with colorful bracts that bloom year-round in bright light.
commonExamples: Euphorbia milii (Crown of thorns, Christ plant)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect to direct light preferred. Medium humidity (40-50%). Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer. Milky sap is irritating—handle with care. Toxic to pets. Repot every 1-2 years when roots fill container.

description: Tuberous flowering plants in the Primulaceae family with heart-shaped leaves and upswept flowers.
commonExamples: Cyclamen persicum (Florist's cyclamen), C. hederifolium (Hardy cyclamen), various colors
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist but not soggy. Water from bottom to avoid wetting leaves and crown. Cool temperatures (60-65°F) extend bloom time. Bright indirect light preferred. Medium humidity (50%) preferred. Fertilize every 2 weeks during flowering with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Goes dormant after flowering - reduce watering and allow foliage to die back. Repot when dormant. Upswept, colorful flowers.

description: Also known as: Cape jasmine. Fragrant flowering shrubs in the Rubiaceae family with glossy leaves and white blooms, require high humidity.
commonExamples: Gardenia jasminoides (Cape jasmine, Common gardenia), G. 'August Beauty', G. 'Veitchii'
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist but well-drained (water when top inch is dry). Acidic soil essential (pH 5.0-6.5). Bright indirect light preferred; some direct morning sun is fine. High humidity (60%+) essential - use humidifier. Fertilize every 2-3 weeks spring through fall with acid-loving plant fertilizer. Very fragrant white flowers. Prune after flowering. Can be finicky - requires consistent care. Repot every 2-3 years.

description: Also known as: Florist's Gloxinia, Sinningia. Tuberous flowering plants in the Gesneriaceae family with velvety leaves and large, bell-shaped flowers.
commonExamples: Sinningia speciosa (Gloxinia, Florist's gloxinia), various colors and patterns
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist but not soggy. Water from bottom to avoid wetting leaves. Bright indirect light preferred; avoid direct sun. High humidity (60%+) preferred. Fertilize every 2 weeks during flowering with high-phosphorus fertilizer. Goes dormant after flowering - reduce watering and allow foliage to die back. Repot when dormant. Large, bell-shaped velvety flowers. Velvety leaves.

description: Trailing gesneriad with waxy, fish-shaped flowers in orange or red; blooms from leaf axils.
commonExamples: Columnea gloriosa, Nematanthus gregarius
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect light preferred; avoid direct sun. Medium humidity (40-50%). Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Cooler, drier winter promotes spring blooms. Non-toxic to pets. Repot every 1-2 years when roots fill container.

description: Also known as: Chinese hibiscus. Showy shrub with large, colorful trumpet flowers that last one day but bloom repeatedly.
commonExamples: Hibiscus rosa-sinensis (Chinese hibiscus)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect to direct light preferred. Medium humidity (40-50%). Fertilize weekly spring through fall with bloom fertilizer. Bud drop from stress or pests. Non-toxic to pets. Repot every 1-2 years when roots fill container.

description: Also known as: Wax plant. Classic wax plant with thick, waxy leaves and fragrant star-shaped flowers.
commonExamples: Hoya carnosa (Wax plant, Porcelain flower), H. carnosa 'Krimson Princess', H. carnosa 'Compacta'
careTips: Water when most of pot is dry (every 1-2 weeks). More drought tolerant than many houseplants. Bright indirect light preferred; some direct morning sun encourages flowering. Medium humidity (40-50%) is fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Don't remove spent flower stems (peduncles) - they rebloom. Repot every 2-3 years. Fragrant star-shaped flowers. Can trail or climb.

description: Heart-shaped hoya often sold as single leaves, slow-growing but charming.
commonExamples: Hoya kerrii (Sweetheart hoya, Valentine hoya)
careTips: Water when most of pot is dry (every 1-2 weeks). Bright indirect light preferred. Medium humidity (40-50%) is fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Very slow-growing - single leaves may never grow into full plant. If you have a stem cutting (not just leaf), it will grow. Repot every 2-3 years. Charming heart-shaped leaves.

description: Epiphytic vines in the Apocynaceae family with waxy leaves and fragrant star-shaped flowers, also called wax plants.
commonExamples: Hoya carnosa (Wax plant, Porcelain flower), H. pubicalyx, H. kerrii (Sweetheart hoya, Valentine hoya)
careTips: Water when most of pot is dry (every 1-2 weeks). More drought tolerant than many houseplants. Reduce watering in winter when growth slows. Bright indirect light preferred; some direct morning sun encourages flowering. Medium humidity (40-50%) is fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Don't remove spent flower stems - they rebloom. Repot every 2-3 years. Fragrant star-shaped flowers. Can trail or climb.

description: Also known as: Flame of the woods. Tropical shrub producing dense clusters of tiny star-shaped flowers in vibrant red, orange, yellow, or pink.
commonExamples: Ixora coccinea (Jungle geranium, Flame of the woods), I. chinensis, I. 'Nora Grant', I. 'Maui Yellow'
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist during growing season; reduce in winter. Bright direct to indirect light for best flowering. Medium humidity preferred. Acidic soil essential (pH 5.0-6.0)—iron chlorosis (yellow leaves) in alkaline soil. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with acid-forming fertilizer. Prune after flowering to maintain shape. Mildly toxic to pets.

description: Also known as: Pink jasmine. Fragrant flowering vines in the Oleaceae family, popular for their sweet-smelling blooms.
commonExamples: Jasminum polyanthum (Pink jasmine), J. sambac (Arabian jasmine), J. officinale (Common jasmine)
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist (water when top inch is dry). Bright indirect to direct light preferred - more light encourages flowering. High humidity (60%+) preferred. Fertilize every 2 weeks spring through fall with high-phosphorus fertilizer to encourage flowering. Provide support for climbing. Prune after flowering. Very fragrant flowers. Can be grown as houseplant or outdoor in warm climates. Repot every 1-2 years.

description: Also known as: Flaming Katy, Florist Kalanchoe. Colorful succulent houseplants with clusters of long-lasting blooms in red, pink, orange, yellow, and white. The most popular species is K. blossfeldiana.
commonExamples: Kalanchoe blossfeldiana (Flaming Katy), K. tomentosa (Panda plant), K. daigremontiana (Mother of thousands), K. pinnata (Cathedral bells)
careTips: Water when soil is completely dry — very drought tolerant. Bright indirect to direct light. Low humidity preferred. Well-draining succulent mix. Fertilize monthly during growing season. K. blossfeldiana needs short days (14+ hours darkness) for 6 weeks to rebloom. Deadhead spent flowers. Toxic to pets — contains cardiac glycosides.

description: Also known as: Lipstick vine. Trailing gesneriad with tubular red flowers emerging from dark calyxes like lipstick.
commonExamples: Aeschynanthus radicans (Lipstick vine)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect light preferred; some morning sun encourages blooms. Medium humidity (40-50%). Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Trailing habit suits hanging baskets. Non-toxic to pets. Repot every 1-2 years when roots fill container.

description: Vining plant with trumpet flowers in pink, red, or white; blooms from spring through fall.
commonExamples: Mandevilla sanderi (Rock trumpet)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect to direct light preferred. Medium humidity (40-50%). Fertilize weekly spring through fall with bloom fertilizer. Provide trellis or support for climbing. Toxic to pets. Repot every 1-2 years when roots fill container.

description: Also known as: Rose Grape. Dramatic tropical houseplant with large, leathery leaves and cascading clusters of pink flowers that can last for months.
commonExamples: Medinilla magnifica (Rose grape, Philippine orchid, Showy medinilla)
careTips: Water when top 2-3 cm of soil is dry; reduce watering in winter. Bright indirect light—avoid direct sun which scorches leaves. High humidity (60%+) essential; mist daily or use a humidifier. Use well-draining, slightly acidic potting mix. Fertilize every 2 weeks spring through summer with half-strength balanced fertilizer. Needs a cool dry rest period (16-18°C) in winter to trigger reblooming. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Aroids with white spathes and dark green foliage, excellent air purifiers, droop dramatically when thirsty as a watering indicator. Includes various cultivars ranging from compact to large.
commonExamples: Spathiphyllum wallisii (Peace lily), S. wallisii 'Domino', S. 'Sensation', S. floribundum, S. 'Mauna Loa'
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist but not soggy, water when leaves droop slightly. Fertilize every 6-8 weeks during growing season. Remove spent flowers to encourage new blooms. Repot when roots fill container, typically every 1-2 years. Toxic to humans and pets if ingested; causes mouth irritation.

description: Also known as: Moth orchid. Moth orchids, most common and beginner-friendly orchid genus in the Orchidaceae family with long-lasting blooms. Available in various colors.
commonExamples: Phalaenopsis (Moth orchid, Phal), various hybrid cultivars in many colors
careTips: Soak roots weekly for 15-20 minutes, then allow to dry between waterings. Never let sit in water. Avoid getting water in crown (center) which causes fatal crown rot. Use well-draining orchid bark mix, never regular potting soil. Bright indirect light preferred; direct sun burns leaves. High humidity (50-70%) preferred. Fertilize weekly spring through fall with orchid fertilizer at quarter strength. Repot every 1-2 years when bark breaks down. Blooms last 2-3 months. Most beginner-friendly orchid.

description: Foliage begonias prized for colorful, patterned leaves in shades of silver, pink, red, and green. Includes stunning colorful and patterned varieties.
commonExamples: Begonia rex-cultorum, B. 'Escargot', B. 'Iron Cross', various hybrid cultivars
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist, never let dry completely. High humidity (60-70%) preferred - use pebble tray or humidifier. Bright indirect light maintains vibrant leaf colors; direct sun fades colors. Avoid wetting leaves which causes spots. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Water from bottom when possible. Repot every 1-2 years. Prone to powdery mildew - ensure good air circulation.

description: Also known as: Madagascar jasmine, Wax flower. Twining vine with waxy, tubular white flowers of exquisite fragrance, traditionally used in wedding bouquets.
commonExamples: Stephanotis floribunda (Madagascar jasmine, Bridal wreath, Wax flower)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist spring through fall; reduce in winter but don't let it dry out completely. Bright indirect light—some morning sun beneficial. High humidity (50-60%+) preferred. Well-draining potting mix. Fertilize every 2 weeks spring through summer with half-strength balanced fertilizer. Provide a trellis or hoop for climbing. Avoid moving once buds form—bud drop is common from changes in position or light. Cool winter rest (13-16°C) promotes flowering. Mildly toxic to pets.

description: Gesneriad with strappy leaves and trumpet flowers in blue, purple, pink, or white.
commonExamples: Streptocarpus spp. (Cape primrose)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect light preferred; avoid direct sun. Medium humidity (40-50%). Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Long blooming season. Non-toxic to pets. Repot every 1-2 years when roots fill container.

description: Flowering begonias grown from tubers, often with large showy blooms in various colors.
commonExamples: Begonia × tuberhybrida (Tuberous begonia), various hybrid cultivars
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist during active growth (spring through fall). Reduce watering significantly during dormancy period (winter) when leaves die back. Bright indirect light preferred; avoid direct hot sun. High humidity (50-60%) preferred. Fertilize every 2 weeks during active growth with high-phosphorus fertilizer to encourage blooms. Store tubers dry in winter. Repot tubers in spring. Large showy blooms in various colors.

description: Tropical plant with bold white-veined leaves and showy yellow bract flowers; requires consistent moisture and high humidity.
commonExamples: Aphelandra squarrosa (Zebra plant, Saffron spike zebra)
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist but not soggy. Bright indirect light essential. High humidity (60-70%) required—use pebble tray or humidifier. Fertilize monthly spring through fall. Prone to leaf drop if care is inconsistent. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Compact prayer plant with light green leaves featuring bold dark green striping along the veins; folds leaves upward at night.
commonExamples: Goeppertia concinna (syn. Calathea concinna 'Freddie')
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist but never soggy; use filtered or distilled water as sensitive to minerals and chlorine. Low to bright indirect light—no direct sun which scorches leaves. High humidity essential (60%+); use humidifier or pebble tray. Fertilize monthly spring through fall at quarter strength. Sensitive to drafts and temperature changes. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Also known as: Peacock plant, Cathedral windows. Prayer plant with oval leaves featuring peacock-like patterns, leaves fold up at night.
commonExamples: Goeppertia makoyana (Peacock plant, Cathedral windows), Calathea makoyana
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist but not soggy. High humidity (60%+) essential - use humidifier or pebble tray. Bright indirect light preferred; avoid direct sun. Use distilled or filtered water to prevent leaf browning. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Leaves fold up at night (prayer plant behavior). Repot every 1-2 years. Peacock-like pattern on leaves. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Popular prayer plant with dark green leaves and purple undersides, requires high humidity, leaves fold up at night.
commonExamples: Goeppertia roseopicta 'Medallion' (Calathea medallion), G. roseopicta 'Dottie' (darker variety), G. roseopicta 'Rosy'
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist, never let dry. High humidity (60-70%) essential - use humidifier or pebble tray. Use only distilled or filtered water to prevent leaf browning from minerals. Bright indirect light preferred; direct sun burns leaves. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Leaves fold up at night (nyctinasty). Repot every 1-2 years. Wipe leaves monthly. Sensitive to tap water and low humidity. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Stunning prayer plant with an intricate mosaic-like network pattern on its leaves that resembles stained glass or circuit boards, one of the most visually complex leaf patterns in nature.
commonExamples: Goeppertia kegeljanii (syn. Calathea musaica, Network calathea)
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist but not waterlogged; very sensitive to drying out. Bright indirect light—no direct sun. High humidity (60%+) essential; leaf edges brown quickly in dry air. Use filtered or distilled water—sensitive to fluoride and chlorine in tap water. Well-draining, peat-based mix. Fertilize monthly spring through fall at quarter strength. Leaves fold up at night (nyctinasty). Non-toxic to pets.

description: Also known as: Round-leaved calathea. Large prayer plant with silver-striped round leaves, requires high humidity, leaves fold up at night (nyctinasty).
commonExamples: Goeppertia orbifolia (Calathea orbifolia, Round-leaved calathea), one of the larger calathea varieties
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist, never let dry. High humidity (60-70%) essential - use humidifier. Use only distilled or filtered water to prevent leaf browning. Bright indirect light preferred; direct sun fades silver stripes. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Leaves fold up at night (nyctinasty). Repot every 1-2 years. One of the larger calathea varieties. Wipe large leaves monthly. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Also known as: Pin-stripe plant. Elegant prayer plant with dark green, glossy leaves adorned with thin pink or white pinstripes that fade to cream with age.
commonExamples: Goeppertia ornata (Pin-stripe calathea), G. ornata 'Sanderiana' (Broad-stripe calathea)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist; water when the top inch feels slightly dry. Medium indirect light is ideal — avoid direct sun, which scorches the delicate leaves. Maintain humidity above 60%; mist regularly or use a humidifier. Use filtered, distilled, or rainwater to prevent brown leaf edges from mineral sensitivity. Fertilize monthly during the growing season with a diluted balanced liquid fertilizer. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Prayer plant with wavy, patterned leaves resembling a rattlesnake's tail.
commonExamples: Goeppertia lancifolia (Calathea rattlesnake, syn. Calathea lancifolia)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist, never let dry. High humidity (60-70%) essential - use humidifier. Use distilled or filtered water to prevent leaf browning. Bright indirect light preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Wavy, patterned leaves resembling rattlesnake's tail. Repot every 1-2 years. Wipe leaves monthly. Sensitive to tap water and low humidity. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Also known as: Rose painted calathea. Prayer plant with oval leaves featuring a bold pink or cream border on dark green, with purple undersides. Multiple popular cultivars.
commonExamples: Goeppertia roseopicta (Rose painted calathea), G. roseopicta 'Medallion', G. roseopicta 'Dottie' (nearly black leaves with pink outline), G. roseopicta 'Rosy' (pink center)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is slightly dry; keep consistently moist. Use filtered water. Medium indirect light preferred. High humidity (60%+) essential — brown leaf edges indicate low humidity. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Prayer plant with delicate white pinstripes on bright green, elliptical leaves. More compact than Calathea ornata with finer, more numerous stripes.
commonExamples: Goeppertia elliptica 'Vittata' (syn. Calathea vittata, White-striped calathea)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is slightly dry; keep consistently moist but not soggy. Use filtered water — sensitive to fluoride and chlorine. Medium indirect light; direct sun scorches leaves. High humidity (60%+) essential. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Prayer plant with variegated leaves in white, green, and lavender; leaves fold up at night.
commonExamples: Goeppertia lietzei 'White Fusion' (syn. Calathea lietzei 'White Fusion')
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist, never let dry. Bright indirect light preferred; avoid direct sun. High humidity (60%+) essential—variegation reverts in low humidity. Use distilled or filtered water to prevent leaf browning. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Repot every 1-2 years when roots fill container. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Prayer plant with bold white stripes on dark green leaves; leaves fold up at night.
commonExamples: Goeppertia majestica 'Whitestar' (syn. Calathea 'White Star', Calathea majestica 'Whitestar')
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist, never let dry. Bright indirect light preferred; avoid direct sun. High humidity (60%+) preferred. Use distilled or filtered water to prevent leaf browning. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Repot every 1-2 years when roots fill container. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Prayer plant with velvety stripes alternating dark and light green; leaves fold up at night.
commonExamples: Calathea zebrina (syn. Goeppertia zebrina; Zebra plant)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist, never let dry. Bright indirect light preferred; avoid direct sun. Medium to high humidity (50-60%). Use distilled or filtered water to prevent leaf browning. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Leaves fold at night. Repot every 1-2 years when roots fill container. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Also known as: Fishbone prayer plant. Prayer plants in the Marantaceae family with patterned leaves that fold up at night, more tolerant than some prayer plants.
commonExamples: Ctenanthe burle-marxii (Fishbone prayer plant), C. burle-marxii 'Amagris' (Golden Mosaic), C. setosa (Grey Star), C. oppenheimiana (Never-never plant), C. lubbersiana
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist but not soggy. High humidity (60%+) preferred - more tolerant than some prayer plants. Bright indirect light preferred; avoid direct sun. Use distilled or filtered water to prevent leaf browning. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Leaves fold up at night (prayer plant behavior). Patterned leaves. Repot every 1-2 years.

description: Striking Maranta cultivar with dark green leaves featuring red veins and a herringbone pattern that fold upward at night.
commonExamples: Maranta leuconeura var. erythroneura (Red prayer plant), M. leuconeura var. kerchoveana (Rabbit tracks), M. leuconeura var. leuconeura (Green prayer plant)
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist but never waterlogged; water when the top inch begins to dry. Bright to medium indirect light is ideal — direct sun bleaches the leaf patterns. Maintain humidity above 60% using a pebble tray or humidifier; brown leaf tips indicate low humidity. Use filtered or distilled water, as this species is sensitive to fluoride and chlorine. Fertilize monthly in spring and summer with a diluted balanced fertilizer at half strength. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Also known as: Maranta Leuconeura. Classic prayer plant with red-veined leaves that fold up at night.
commonExamples: Maranta leuconeura (Prayer plant), M. leuconeura 'Erythroneura', M. leuconeura 'Kerchoveana'
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist, never let dry. High humidity (60-70%) preferred - use humidifier or pebble tray. Use distilled or filtered water to prevent leaf browning. Bright indirect light preferred; direct sun burns leaves. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Red-veined leaves fold up at night (nyctinasty). Repot every 1-2 years. Wipe leaves monthly.

description: Plants in Marantaceae family with leaves that fold up at night (nyctinasty), require high humidity.
commonExamples: Calathea (Goeppertia), Maranta leuconeura (Prayer plant), Stromanthe sanguinea
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist, never let dry. High humidity (60-70%) essential - use humidifier. Use only distilled or filtered water to prevent leaf browning from minerals. Bright indirect light preferred; direct sun burns leaves. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Leaves fold up at night (nyctinasty). Repot every 1-2 years. Wipe leaves monthly. Sensitive to tap water, low humidity, and drafts.

description: Prayer plants in the Marantaceae family with colorful, patterned leaves that fold up at night.
commonExamples: Stromanthe sanguinea 'Triostar' (Tricolor stromanthe), S. sanguinea 'Magic Star' (spotted form), S. thalia
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist but not soggy. High humidity (60%+) essential - use humidifier or pebble tray. Bright indirect light preferred; avoid direct sun. Use distilled or filtered water to prevent leaf browning. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Leaves fold up at night (prayer plant behavior). Colorful, patterned leaves. Repot every 1-2 years.

description: Tropical climbing vine with stunning elongated leaves featuring silver, green, and purple coloring with deep red-purple undersides, not a true begonia despite the common name.
commonExamples: Cissus discolor (Rex begonia vine, Tapestry vine)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist but not soggy; sensitive to both drought and overwatering. Bright indirect light—direct sun fades the stunning leaf colors. High humidity (60%+) essential—drops leaves rapidly in dry air. Well-draining potting mix. Fertilize monthly spring through fall at half strength. Provide a trellis or moss pole. May go semi-dormant in winter, losing some leaves—reduce watering. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Also known as: String of nickels. Epiphytic succulents related to Hoya, with coin-shaped or heart-shaped leaves; trailing or climbing habit.
commonExamples: Dischidia nummularia (String of nickels), D. ruscifolia
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect light preferred. Medium humidity (40-50%). Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Epiphytic—well-draining mix. Trailing habit suits hanging baskets. Repot every 1-2 years when roots fill container.

description: Classic trailing vine with lobed leaves, can be grown indoors or outdoors.
commonExamples: Hedera helix (English ivy, Common ivy), H. helix 'Glacier', H. helix 'Needlepoint'
careTips: Keep soil slightly moist. Cooler temperatures (60-70°F) preferred. Bright indirect light preferred. Medium humidity (40-50%) preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Prone to spider mites - mist regularly and inspect leaves. Prune to control length. Repot every 1-2 years. Can be grown indoors or outdoors. Toxic to pets.

description: Also known as: Venezuela Treebine. Trailing vine with glossy, grape-like trifoliate leaves. Excellent low-maintenance houseplant that tolerates lower light conditions and adapts well to indoor environments. Can trail from hanging baskets or climb a moss pole.
commonExamples: Cissus rhombifolia (Grape ivy, Oak leaf ivy), C. alata
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Allow to dry between waterings. Bright indirect light preferred. Medium humidity (40-50%) is fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Prune to control length. Repot every 1-2 years. Easy-care houseplant. Grape-like leaves. Can trail or climb with support.

description: Vining Hoya with waxy, oval leaves and fragrant white flowers with red centers.
commonExamples: Hoya australis
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect light preferred. Medium humidity (40-50%). Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Allow soil to dry between waterings. Repot every 2-3 years when roots fill container.

description: Compact, trailing hoya with small, pointed leaves and clusters of star-shaped, fragrant white flowers with pink or purple centers. One of the most popular hoyas for hanging baskets.
commonExamples: Hoya lanceolata subsp. bella (Hoya bella, Miniature wax plant, Beautiful hoya)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect light encourages blooming. Do not remove spent flower stalks (peduncles) — new flowers emerge from the same spurs. Average to high humidity preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through summer. Mildly toxic.

description: Distinctive Hoya species with long, pointed leaves featuring prominent dark veining on a light green background, giving a stained-glass appearance. A highly sought-after collector Hoya.
commonExamples: Hoya callistophylla
careTips: Allow soil to dry between waterings. Bright indirect light for best leaf coloring; tolerates medium light. Do not remove flower peduncles as they rebloom from the same stalk. Well-draining aroid or orchid mix with bark and perlite. Fertilize monthly spring through fall. Slow to moderate grower. Leaves develop best venation pattern with good light. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Hoya carnosa cultivar with twisted, curled leaves creating a rope-like appearance; Hindu rope.
commonExamples: Hoya carnosa 'Compacta'
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect light preferred. Medium humidity (40-50%). Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Slow-growing. Waxy pink flowers when mature. Repot every 2-3 years when roots fill container.

description: Compact Hoya species with small, thick oval leaves and fragrant yellow star-shaped flower clusters. One of the easier Hoyas to bring into bloom.
commonExamples: Hoya cumingiana
careTips: Allow soil to dry out between waterings — water thoroughly when dry. Bright indirect light encourages blooming; tolerates medium light. Do not remove spent flower stalks as new blooms emerge from the same peduncle. Well-draining mix essential — orchid bark, perlite, and peat. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Trailing Hoya with small, silver-mottled leaves; ideal for hanging baskets.
commonExamples: Hoya curtisii
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect light preferred. Medium humidity (40-50%). Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Compact growth. Repot every 2-3 years when roots fill container.

description: Also known as: Variegated wax plant. Popular variegated Hoya carnosa cultivar with creamy white to pink margins on waxy, semi-succulent leaves.
commonExamples: Hoya carnosa 'Krimson Queen' (Tricolor hoya, Variegated wax plant)
careTips: Allow soil to dry out between waterings; water thoroughly when the top 2-3 cm feel dry. Bright indirect light is essential to maintain variegation — some morning sun encourages pink tones on new growth. Use a well-draining, chunky mix with orchid bark and perlite. Maintain 40-60% humidity; tolerates average home humidity. Fertilize monthly in spring and summer with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Do not remove spent flower peduncles, as they rebloom from the same spurs. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Trailing Hoya with long, narrow, fuzzy leaves; pendulous habit suits hanging baskets.
commonExamples: Hoya linearis
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect light preferred. Medium humidity (40-50%). Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Fragrant white flowers. Repot every 2-3 years when roots fill container.

description: Compact Hoya with silver-flecked leaves; hybrid of H. serpens × H. carnosa.
commonExamples: Hoya mathilde
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect light preferred. Medium humidity (40-50%). Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Slow-growing. Repot every 2-3 years when roots fill container.

description: Also known as: Wax Plant. Large, round-leaved Hoya with thick, often silver-splashed foliage. Splash markings are the standard form. Produces fragrant star-shaped flower clusters.
commonExamples: Hoya obovata
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect light preferred. Medium humidity (40-50%). Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Pink flowers in clusters. Repot every 2-3 years when roots fill container.

description: Fast-growing Hoya with silver-flecked leaves and fragrant dark pink or red flowers.
commonExamples: Hoya pubicalyx
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect light preferred. Medium humidity (40-50%). Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Prolific bloomer. Repot every 2-3 years when roots fill container.

description: Trailing hoya with narrow, elongated leaves edged in red or dark maroon, producing clusters of fragrant star-shaped flowers when mature.
commonExamples: Hoya wayetii, H. wayetii 'Variegata'
careTips: Allow soil to dry mostly between waterings (every 1-2 weeks). Bright indirect light preferred—some direct morning sun enhances leaf color. Medium humidity (40-50%) fine. Well-draining mix with perlite and orchid bark. Fertilize monthly spring through fall at half strength. Don't remove old flower stems (peduncles)—they rebloom. Let it become slightly rootbound for flowering. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Also known as: Lemon-lime philodendron. Variegated heart-leaf philodendron with green and yellow-chartreuse leaves, easy-care trailing plant.
commonExamples: Philodendron hederaceum 'Brasil' (Brasil philodendron, Lemon-lime philodendron)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Very forgiving of inconsistent care. Bright indirect light maintains variegation; tolerates low light but may lose variegation. Medium humidity (40-50%) is fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Fast-growing trailing plant. Prune to control length. Repot every 1-2 years. Green and yellow-chartreuse variegation. Toxic to pets.

description: Also known as: Silver pothos. Trailing aroids often called satin pothos, with silvery-splotched leaves, easy-care houseplants.
commonExamples: Scindapsus pictus (Satin pothos, Silver pothos), S. pictus 'Exotica' (large silver leaves), S. pictus 'Argyraeus', S. treubii 'Moonlight', S. treubii 'Dark Form'
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Very forgiving of inconsistent care. Bright indirect light maintains silvery variegation; tolerates low light. Medium humidity (40-50%) is fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Trailing growth habit. Prune to control length. Repot every 1-2 years. Silvery-splotched leaves. Often called satin pothos but not a true pothos. Mildly toxic to pets -- causes mouth and skin irritation.

description: Trailing vine with heart-shaped, matte green leaves covered in silvery spots and patches. Not a true pothos despite the common name; belongs to the genus Scindapsus.
commonExamples: Scindapsus pictus 'Argyraeus' (Satin pothos), S. pictus 'Exotica' (larger silver patches), S. pictus 'Silver Ann' (mostly silver)
careTips: Water when top 1-2 inches of soil is dry. Bright indirect light brings out the silver markings. Average humidity is fine but higher humidity encouraged for larger leaves. Let dry out slightly between waterings. Toxic to pets.

description: Also known as: Spiderwort. Fast-growing trailing plants in the Commelinaceae family with colorful striped or solid leaves.
commonExamples: Tradescantia zebrina (Wandering dude, Inch plant), T. pallida (Purple heart), T. fluminensis (Small-leaf spiderwort), T. spathacea (Moses-in-the-cradle)
careTips: Keep soil lightly moist, allow to dry slightly between waterings. Very fast-growing - may need frequent pruning. Bright indirect light maintains vibrant colors; low light causes leggy growth. Medium humidity (40-50%) is fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Pinch tips to encourage bushiness. Repot every 1-2 years. Perfect for hanging baskets. Easy to propagate from cuttings. Mildly toxic to pets -- causes mouth and skin irritation.

description: Trailing plant with thick, striped leaves in pink, green, and cream; compact, upright-then-cascading habit.
commonExamples: Tradescantia 'Nanouk'
careTips: Keep soil lightly moist. Bright indirect light maintains pink stripes. Medium humidity (40-50%). Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Fast-growing. Mildly toxic to pets -- causes mouth and skin irritation. Repot every 1-2 years when roots fill container.

description: Trailing plant with vivid purple foliage and small pink flowers; can be grown indoors or outdoors.
commonExamples: Tradescantia pallida (Purple heart)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect to direct light enhances purple color. Medium humidity (40-50%). Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Mildly toxic to pets -- causes mouth and skin irritation. Repot every 1-2 years when roots fill container.

description: Houseplants with trailing or climbing growth habits, popular for hanging baskets and shelves. Many are fast-growing and easy to propagate.
commonExamples: Epipremnum aureum (Pothos), Hedera helix (English ivy), Tradescantia (Spiderwort), Hoya (Wax plant), Ceropegia woodii (String of hearts)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Most are forgiving of occasional missed waterings. Bright indirect to medium light preferred — most tolerate lower light but may lose variegation. Medium humidity (40-50%) is fine for most species. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced liquid fertilizer at half strength. Prune to control length and encourage bushier growth — cuttings root easily in water. Provide support (moss pole, trellis) for climbing species. Research specific species for exact requirements.

description: Tall fig tree with leathery, variegated leaves in shades of green and yellow. Also called council tree. Easier to care for than fiddle leaf fig.
commonExamples: Ficus altissima (Council tree), F. altissima 'Yellow Gem' (variegated cultivar)
careTips: Water when top 1-2 inches of soil is dry. Bright indirect to direct light preferred. Average humidity is fine. Avoid moving frequently — can drop leaves from environmental changes. Fertilize monthly spring through fall. Toxic to pets.

description: The more forgiving cousin of the Fiddle Leaf Fig, with velvety, oval leaves and pale trunk, increasingly popular as a statement houseplant.
commonExamples: Ficus benghalensis (Ficus Audrey, Banyan fig—indoor cultivar)
careTips: Water when top 2-5 cm of soil is dry; more forgiving than Fiddle Leaf Fig but still dislikes soggy soil. Bright indirect light preferred—tolerates some direct morning sun. Medium humidity fine. Well-draining potting mix. Fertilize monthly spring through fall at half strength. Wipe velvety leaves with damp cloth to remove dust. Less prone to leaf drop than Fiddle Leaf Fig but still dislikes being moved. Toxic to pets (milky latex sap).

description: Ficus with glossy oval leaves, popular for bonsai; can develop aerial roots.
commonExamples: Ficus microcarpa (Chinese banyan, Ginseng ficus, Banyan fig), F. microcarpa 'Green Island'
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect light. Often grown as bonsai. Avoid moving once established. Fertilize monthly spring through fall. Toxic to pets.

description: Also known as: FLF. Popular but finicky ficus with large violin-shaped leaves, requires consistent care and stable environment.
commonExamples: Ficus lyrata (Fiddle-leaf fig, FLF), F. lyrata 'Bambino' (compact variety), F. lyrata variegated (rare)
careTips: Water when top 2-3 inches of soil is dry. Very sensitive to overwatering and location changes - may drop leaves. Avoid drafts and sudden temperature changes. Bright indirect light essential - rotate regularly for even growth. High humidity (60%+) preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Wipe large leaves monthly. Repot every 2-3 years. Popular but finicky - requires consistent care and stable environment. Toxic to pets.

description: Popular ficus with large, glossy dark green or burgundy leaves, can grow into a tree.
commonExamples: Ficus elastica (Rubber plant, Rubber tree), F. elastica 'Burgundy'
careTips: Water when top 2-3 inches of soil is dry. Avoid overwatering which causes root rot. Sensitive to location changes - may drop leaves when moved. Bright indirect light preferred; some direct morning sun is fine. Medium to high humidity (50-60%) preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Wipe large glossy leaves monthly. Prune to control height. Repot every 2-3 years. Can grow into a tree. Toxic to pets.

description: Ficus elastica cultivar with dark burgundy, nearly black leaves; bold statement plant.
commonExamples: Ficus elastica 'Burgundy'
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect light preferred; tolerates low light. Medium humidity (40-50%). Wipe leaves to remove dust. Toxic to pets. Repot every 1-2 years when roots fill container.

description: Striking Ficus elastica cultivar with tricolored leaves in deep green, cream, and vivid ruby-pink, especially vibrant on new growth.
commonExamples: Ficus elastica 'Ruby' (Ruby rubber plant, Pink rubber tree)
careTips: Water when the top 2-3 cm of soil feel dry; avoid overwatering which causes leaf drop. Bright indirect light is crucial to maintain the pink and cream variegation — low light causes reversion to green. Wipe the large, glossy leaves monthly with a damp cloth to keep them dust-free. Average room humidity is adequate. Fertilize monthly during spring and summer with balanced liquid fertilizer at half strength. Prune to control height and encourage branching. Mildly toxic — the milky sap can irritate skin and is harmful to pets if ingested.

description: Fast-growing grasses in the Poaceae family, can be clumping or running types, popular for screening and containers.
commonExamples: Bambusa (Clumping bamboo), Phyllostachys (Running bamboo), Fargesia (Cold-hardy clumping bamboo), indoor varieties like Dracaena sanderiana (Lucky bamboo)
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist (2-3 times per week). Running types spread aggressively - contain with barriers or plant in containers. Clumping types are more manageable. Full sun to partial shade depending on species. Fertilize monthly during growing season with high-nitrogen fertilizer. Prune to control height and remove old canes. Container-grown bamboo needs regular repotting. Research clumping vs running types before planting. Some species are invasive - check local regulations. Indoor lucky bamboo grows in water or soil.

description: Also known as: Crane flower. Large tropical plants in the Strelitziaceae family with distinctive bird-like flowers and banana-like leaves.
commonExamples: Strelitzia reginae (Bird of paradise, Crane flower), S. nicolai (Giant white bird of paradise, Wild banana)
careTips: Water when top 2 inches of soil is dry. Keep consistently moist in growing season, reduce in winter. Bright indirect to direct light preferred - needs lots of light to flower. High humidity (50-60%) preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Wipe large leaves monthly. Repot every 2-3 years. Distinctive bird-like flowers. Can grow quite large - provide adequate space. Toxic to pets.

description: Also known as: Giant bird of paradise. Large tropical plant with banana-like leaves and striking white and blue crane-shaped flowers. Grows to 6m outdoors; popular as dramatic indoor foliage plant.
commonExamples: Strelitzia nicolai (White bird of paradise, Giant bird of paradise)
careTips: Water when top 5cm of soil is dry; reduce in winter. Bright indirect to direct light — more light encourages flowering. Medium humidity sufficient but appreciates higher. Large plant that needs space; repot every 2-3 years. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer. Leaves may split naturally with age. Prune dead leaves at base. Mildly toxic to pets.

description: Miniature trees created through cultivation techniques - care varies by species, this is a general guide.
commonExamples: Juniperus (Juniper), Ficus, Acer (Maple), Pinus (Pine)
careTips: Water when soil surface is dry - check daily as small pots dry quickly. Avoid both over and under-watering. Adjust based on species needs - research your specific tree type. Bright indirect to direct light depending on species. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with bonsai fertilizer. Prune regularly to maintain shape. Repot every 2-3 years with bonsai soil mix. Requires patience and consistent care. Each species has specific requirements.

description: Also known as: Painted nettle. Colorful foliage plants in the Lamiaceae family with vibrant leaves in various patterns and colors, pinch flowers to maintain foliage.
commonExamples: Coleus scutellarioides (syn. Plectranthus scutellarioides, Solenostemon scutellarioides) (Coleus, Painted nettle), various hybrid cultivars
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist, avoid letting dry out. Bright indirect light maintains vibrant colors; direct sun may fade colors. High humidity (50-60%) preferred. Fertilize every 2 weeks spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Pinch flower spikes to redirect energy into leaf growth and maintain the best foliage color, though flowering does not kill the plant. Pinch tips regularly to maintain bushy growth. Repot annually. Easy to propagate from cuttings. Annual in most climates. Mildly toxic to pets if ingested.

description: World's largest unbranched flower structure, producing a massive spathe that smells of rotting flesh when blooming. Blooms are rare, occurring every 7-10 years.
commonExamples: Amorphophallus titanum (Titan arum, Corpse flower). Distinct from Rafflesia, which is the world's largest individual flower
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist but well-drained during active growth. Bright indirect light. Very high humidity (70-80%) required. Goes completely dormant after flowering — reduce water drastically. Requires large pot (60+ cm) for mature corm. Fertilize monthly during growing season with balanced fertilizer. Grows from a massive underground corm. Prefers acidic soil. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Also known as: Garden croton. Colorful tropical foliage plants in the Euphorbiaceae family with vibrant leaves in red, orange, yellow, and green, sensitive to changes.
commonExamples: Codiaeum variegatum (Croton, Garden croton), C. variegatum 'Petra', C. variegatum 'Mammy'
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist, avoid letting dry out. High humidity (60%+) preferred - use humidifier. Bright indirect to direct light essential to maintain vibrant colors. Sensitive to changes - avoid moving once established. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. May drop leaves if stressed (drafts, temperature changes, low humidity). Repot every 1-2 years. Wipe leaves monthly. Toxic to pets.

description: Croton cultivar with twisted, spiral leaves in red, orange, yellow, and green.
commonExamples: Codiaeum variegatum 'Mammy'
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist, avoid letting dry out. Bright indirect to direct light essential for vibrant colors. High humidity (60%+) preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Sensitive to drafts and changes. Toxic to pets. Repot every 1-2 years.

description: Ancient palm-like plants in the Cycadaceae family, slow-growing with stiff fronds, many are endangered in the wild.
commonExamples: Cycas revoluta (Sago palm, King sago), Zamia (Coontie, Cardboard palm), Dioon (Dioon cycad), Macrozamia
careTips: Water when top 2-3 inches of soil is dry. Allow to dry slightly between waterings - avoid overwatering which causes root rot. Bright indirect to direct light preferred. Low to medium humidity is fine. Fertilize 2-3 times per year during growing season with palm fertilizer. Very slow-growing - repot every 3-5 years. Remove dead fronds at base. Toxic to pets if ingested. Ancient plants that have existed for millions of years. Research specific species for exact requirements.

description: Bold tropical foliage plant with large, deeply lobed palmately compound leaves.
commonExamples: Fatsia japonica (Japanese aralia, Paper plant), F. japonica 'Spider Web'
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect light; tolerates lower light. High humidity preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall. Can grow large; prune to control size. Toxic to pets.

description: Striking tropical plant with deeply textured, dark purple-black suckered leaves that shimmer in the light. A trending collector plant.
commonExamples: Geogenanthus ciliatus (Geo plant, Seersucker plant)
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist — sensitive to drought; leaf edges crisp quickly if too dry. Medium indirect light; avoid direct sun. High humidity (60%+) critical — brown leaf edges indicate low humidity. Well-draining, moisture-retentive mix. Fertilize monthly spring through fall at quarter strength. Slow grower. Sensitive to cold — keep above 18°C. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Bright golden conifer with lemony scent, popular as indoor or patio plant, requires good air circulation.
commonExamples: Cupressus macrocarpa 'Goldcrest' (Lemon cypress, Goldcrest cypress, Monterey cypress 'Goldcrest')
careTips: Keep soil moist but not waterlogged. Excellent drainage essential. Allow top inch to dry slightly between waterings. Bright indirect to direct light preferred. Good air circulation essential - avoid stagnant air. Medium humidity (40-50%) preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Prune to maintain shape. Repot every 2-3 years. Bright golden color with lemony scent. Popular as indoor or patio plant.

description: Also known as: Chinese water bamboo. Dracaena species often grown in water or soil, popular for feng shui, not a true bamboo.
commonExamples: Dracaena sanderiana (Lucky bamboo, Chinese water bamboo, Ribbon plant), can be grown in water or soil
careTips: In water: Change water weekly, keep water level consistent. In soil: Water when top inch is dry. Bright indirect light preferred; avoid direct sun. Medium humidity is fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength (if in soil) or add to water monthly. Can be grown in water indefinitely or in soil. Popular for feng shui arrangements. Not a true bamboo. Toxic to pets. Repot every 2-3 years if in soil.

description: Tropical tree with palmate leaves, often sold with braided trunk; symbol of prosperity and good luck.
commonExamples: Pachira aquatica (Money tree, Guiana chestnut, Malabar chestnut)
careTips: Water when top 2 inches of soil is dry. Avoid overwatering which causes root rot—very sensitive to soggy soil. Bright indirect light preferred. Medium to high humidity (50-60%) preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Often sold with braided trunk—don't untie. Repot every 2-3 years. Remove yellowing leaves. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Also known as: Mosaic plant. Colorful foliage plants in the Acanthaceae family with distinctive veining in various colors, will wilt dramatically when thirsty.
commonExamples: Fittonia albivenis, F. verschaffeltii (Nerve plant, Mosaic plant), F. 'Pink Angel', F. 'Red Anne'
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist, never let dry. High humidity (70%+) essential - use humidifier or terrarium. Will wilt dramatically when thirsty but recovers quickly when watered. Bright indirect light preferred; direct sun burns leaves. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Pinch tips to encourage bushiness. Repot every 1-2 years. Perfect for terrariums. Distinctive veining in various colors.

description: Also known as: Star pine. Indoor conifer native to Norfolk Island, popular as holiday plant, not a true pine but resembles one, sensitive to dry air. Requires consistent moisture.
commonExamples: Araucaria heterophylla (Norfolk Island pine, Star pine)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist, avoid drying out completely. High humidity (50-60%) preferred - mist regularly in dry conditions or use humidifier. Bright indirect light preferred; some direct morning sun is fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Sensitive to dry air - brown needles indicate low humidity. Repot every 2-3 years. Popular as holiday plant. Not a true pine despite the name.

description: Plants in the Oxalidaceae family with clover-like leaves that fold at night, some species go dormant seasonally.
commonExamples: Oxalis triangularis (Purple shamrock, False shamrock), O. regnellii (Green shamrock, Lucky clover)
careTips: Keep soil moist during active growth. Reduce significantly or stop watering during dormancy when leaves die back - this is normal. Bright indirect to direct light preferred. Medium humidity (40-50%) is fine. Fertilize monthly during active growth with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Clover-like leaves fold at night. Some species go dormant seasonally - don't discard, it will regrow. Repot every 2-3 years. Toxic to pets.

description: Also known as: False shamrock. Clover-like plant with purple triangular leaves that fold at night; produces small pink or white flowers.
commonExamples: Oxalis triangularis (Purple shamrock, False shamrock)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect light preferred; some direct morning sun enhances purple. Medium humidity (40-50%). Goes dormant periodically—reduce watering when leaves die back. Fertilize monthly during active growth. Toxic to pets. Repot every 1-2 years.

description: Compact tropical foliage plants in the Piperaceae family with thick, succulent-like leaves.
commonExamples: Peperomia obtusifolia (Baby rubber plant), P. caperata (Ripple peperomia), P. argyreia (Watermelon peperomia), P. 'Hope', P. 'Rosso'
