careTips: Water when top 2 inches of soil is dry. More drought tolerant than many tropical plants due to succulent-like leaves. Bright indirect light preferred. Medium humidity (40-50%) is fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Compact growth habit. Repot every 2-3 years. Easy-care houseplants. Thick, succulent-like leaves store water. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Compact peperomia with deeply ridged, heart-shaped leaves in red, green, or silver.
commonExamples: Peperomia caperata (Emerald ripple)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect light preferred; avoid direct sun. Medium humidity (40-50%). Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Susceptible to overwatering. Repot every 1-2 years when roots fill container. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Peperomia with thick, glossy oval leaves; upright or trailing, not a true rubber plant.
commonExamples: Peperomia obtusifolia (Baby rubber plant)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect light preferred. Medium humidity (40-50%). Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Tolerates low light. Non-toxic to pets. Repot every 1-2 years when roots fill container.

description: Compact peperomia with deeply ridged, dark green leaves and striking red undersides. Semi-succulent with low water needs. Excellent desk plant.
commonExamples: Peperomia caperata 'Rosso' (Emerald ripple pepper, Red ripple peperomia)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry; semi-succulent so tolerates slight drought. Bright indirect light enhances red coloring. Average humidity is fine. Compact grower rarely needing repotting. Fertilize lightly spring through summer. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Compact peperomia with silver-striped leaves resembling watermelon rind.
commonExamples: Peperomia argyreia (Watermelon peperomia, syn. P. sandersii)
careTips: Water when top 2 inches of soil is dry. Allow to dry between waterings. Bright indirect light maintains silver stripes. Medium humidity (40-50%) is fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Silver-striped leaves resembling watermelon rind. Compact growth habit. Repot every 2-3 years. Easy-care houseplant. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Compact tropical foliage plants in the Urticaceae family with round or textured leaves.
commonExamples: Pilea peperomioides (Chinese money plant, Pancake plant, UFO plant), P. cadierei (Aluminum plant), P. involucrata (Friendship plant)
careTips: Water when top 2 inches of soil is dry. Allow to dry between waterings. Avoid overwatering. Bright indirect light preferred. Medium humidity (40-50%) is fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Compact growth habit. Round or textured leaves. Repot every 1-2 years. Easy to propagate from offsets or cuttings.

description: Also known as: UFO plant. Popular Pilea with round, coin-like leaves on upright stems.
commonExamples: Pilea peperomioides (Chinese money plant, Pancake plant, UFO plant)
careTips: Water when top 2 inches of soil is dry. Allow to dry between waterings. Bright indirect light preferred; rotate regularly for even growth. Medium humidity (40-50%) is fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Produces offsets (pups) that can be separated and repotted. Repot every 1-2 years. Round, coin-like leaves on upright stems. Popular and easy-care.

description: Compact pilea with quilted, bronze-veined leaves; easy to propagate and share—hence the name.
commonExamples: Pilea involucrata (Friendship plant)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect light preferred; avoid direct sun. Medium humidity (40-50%). Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Easy to propagate from cuttings. Repot every 1-2 years when roots fill container.

description: Also known as: Kusamaki. Conifer-like evergreen with narrow leaves, popular for bonsai and topiary.
commonExamples: Podocarpus macrophyllus (Buddhist pine, Kusamaki, Yew pine), P. henkelii
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect light. Tolerates lower light. Fertilize monthly spring through fall. Prune to maintain shape. Good for bonsai. Toxic to pets.

description: Colorful foliage plants in the Acanthaceae family with spotted leaves in pink, red, or white, pinch to maintain bushy growth.
commonExamples: Hypoestes phyllostachya (Polka dot plant, Freckle face), various color cultivars
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist, avoid letting dry out. High humidity (60%+) preferred - use humidifier or pebble tray. Bright indirect light maintains vibrant colors. Fertilize every 2 weeks spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Pinch tips regularly to encourage branching and maintain bushy growth. Pinch flowers immediately to prolong plant life. Repot annually. Annual in most climates. Easy to propagate from cuttings.

description: World's largest individual flower, up to 1m diameter and weighing 11kg. A parasitic plant with no stems, leaves, or roots — it lives entirely within a host vine and only emerges to bloom.
commonExamples: Rafflesia arnoldii (Corpse lily), R. keithii, R. tuan-mudae
careTips: Cannot be cultivated outside its native Southeast Asian rainforest habitat. Parasitizes Tetrastigma vines. Requires specific tropical conditions: 70-90% humidity, 22-32°C, deep shade. Blooms last only 5-7 days and smell of rotting flesh to attract pollinating flies. Several species critically endangered. Botanical gardens worldwide have attempted cultivation with extremely limited success. Non-toxic.

description: Tropical shrub with glossy, palmately compound leaves—leaflets radiate from a central point like umbrella ribs.
commonExamples: Schefflera actinophylla (Umbrella tree, Octopus tree), S. arboricola (Dwarf umbrella tree, Hawaiian elf)
careTips: Water when top 2 inches of soil is dry. Keep consistently moist but not soggy. Bright indirect light preferred. Medium to high humidity (50-60%) preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Prune to control size and encourage bushiness. Wipe leaves monthly. Repot every 2-3 years. Can grow quite large. Toxic to pets.

description: One of the most unusual plants on Earth — a living fossil from the Namib Desert. Each plant produces only two leaves in its entire lifetime, which grow continuously and split into straps. Can live over 1,000 years.
commonExamples: Welwitschia mirabilis (Welwitschia, Tree tumbo, Tweeblaarkanniedood)
careTips: Extremely drought tolerant but benefits from occasional deep watering. Full sun. Excellent drainage is critical — grows naturally in desert sand and gravel. Very slow growing. Nearly impossible to transplant due to a deep taproot. Non-toxic.

description: Deciduous conifer with feathery foliage and distinctive "knees"; tolerates wet or swampy sites.
commonExamples: Taxodium distichum (Bald cypress)
careTips: Keep soil moist; tolerates standing water. Full sun preferred. Adapts to wet or dry sites once established. Fertilize in spring when young. Prune in late winter. Develops woody "knees" in wet soil. Golden fall color. Long-lived.

description: Strangler fig with a dramatic aerial root system that forms secondary trunks, allowing a single tree to cover several acres. National tree of India.
commonExamples: Ficus benghalensis (Indian banyan), F. macrophylla (Moreton Bay fig), F. citrifolia (Shortleaf fig)
careTips: Water regularly to keep soil consistently moist, especially when young. Full sun preferred for outdoor specimens. Rich, well-drained soil with high organic matter. Fertilize monthly during growing season. Aerial roots need humidity to develop—mist regularly in dry climates. Requires enormous space outdoors; can also be grown as an indoor bonsai. Mildly toxic to pets (latex sap causes irritation).

description: Also known as: Tree of Life. Massive African tree with a hugely swollen trunk that stores water, sparse crown, and edible fruit rich in vitamin C.
commonExamples: Adansonia digitata (African baobab, Tree of Life), A. grandidieri (Grandidier's baobab), A. madagascariensis
careTips: Very drought-tolerant; water sparingly during growing season and withhold water entirely during dormancy (leaf-drop period). Full sun essential. Requires excellent drainage—sandy, well-drained soil. Do not overwater; trunk rot is the primary killer. Frost-sensitive—protect below 10°C. Can be grown as a bonsai or container specimen in temperate climates. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Deciduous trees in the Betulaceae family with distinctive white or colored bark, prefer cool climates and moist soil.
commonExamples: Betula papyrifera (Paper birch), B. nigra (River birch), B. pendula (Silver birch, European white birch), B. alleghaniensis (Yellow birch)
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist, especially during hot weather. Prefer cool climates and moist, well-drained soil. Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize in early spring with tree fertilizer during establishment. Prune in late summer to avoid bleeding sap. Mulch around base to keep roots cool and moist. Distinctive white or colored bark. Research specific species for exact requirements. Deciduous; reduce or withhold watering when leaves drop in fall.

description: The oldest known living organisms on Earth, with gnarled, wind-sculpted forms found at high elevations in the American West. Some specimens exceed 5,000 years old.
commonExamples: Pinus longaeva (Great Basin bristlecone pine), P. aristata (Rocky Mountain bristlecone pine)
careTips: Extremely drought-tolerant; water sparingly. Full sun essential. Requires excellent drainage—thrives in rocky, alkaline, nutrient-poor soil. Do not fertilize. Extremely slow-growing (may add only a few centimeters per year). Very cold-hardy. Difficult to cultivate outside its native high-altitude habitat. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Ornamental cherry with clouds of pink or white spring blossoms; iconic in Japanese gardens.
commonExamples: Prunus serrulata (Japanese flowering cherry)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist during bloom. Full sun preferred. Well-draining soil. Fertilize after flowering. Prune after bloom to avoid disease; minimal pruning preferred. Short-lived (15–25 years). Susceptible to borers and diseases.

description: Graceful deciduous or semi-evergreen tree with small leaves, fine branching, and attractive mottled bark that flakes to reveal orange, grey, and cream. The most popular species for bonsai.
commonExamples: Ulmus parvifolia (Chinese elm, Lacebark elm), popular bonsai tree
careTips: Water regularly — keep soil consistently moist but not waterlogged. Full sun to partial shade. Adapts to most soil types. Prune in late winter for shape. Highly resistant to Dutch elm disease. Excellent for bonsai — responds well to pruning and wiring. Non-toxic.

description: Evergreen fruit trees in the Rutaceae family with fragrant flowers and edible fruits, require warm climates or indoor protection.
commonExamples: Citrus limon (Lemon), C. sinensis (Orange, Sweet orange), C. × aurantifolia (Lime), C. reticulata (Mandarin, Tangerine)
careTips: Deep soak regularly (weekly in growing season). Keep consistently moist but well-drained. Reduce watering in winter when growth slows. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize monthly spring through fall with citrus-specific fertilizer. Prune after fruiting to maintain shape. Protect from frost - bring indoors or cover if temperatures drop below 32°F. Fragrant flowers precede fruit. Require warm climates or indoor protection in winter. Evergreen; reduce watering in winter when growth slows.

description: The tallest trees on Earth, native to the foggy coastal forests of California and Oregon, with soft reddish bark and flat needles.
commonExamples: Sequoia sempervirens (Coast redwood, California redwood)
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist; benefits greatly from fog or supplemental misting in dry climates. Full sun to partial shade. Prefers deep, acidic, well-drained soil rich in organic matter. Fertilize young trees in spring. Needs humidity—struggles in arid inland climates. Very fast-growing (up to 1 meter per year). Non-toxic to pets.

description: Cone-bearing evergreen trees and shrubs, include pines, spruces, firs, and cedars, provide year-round structure.
commonExamples: Pinus (Pine, Eastern white pine, Scots pine), Picea (Spruce, Norway spruce, Blue spruce), Abies (Fir, Balsam fir), Cedrus (Cedar), Juniperus (Juniper)
careTips: Deep soak regularly (weekly during growing season). Water well before ground freezes in winter to prevent winter desiccation. Mulch around base to retain moisture and protect roots. Full sun preferred for most species. Fertilize in early spring with evergreen fertilizer. Prune in late winter/early spring. Many species are drought-tolerant once established. Provide year-round structure and privacy screening. Research specific species for exact requirements and mature size. Evergreen; reduce watering in winter when growth slows.

description: Small flowering tree with spring blossoms and persistent ornamental fruit; many disease-resistant cultivars.
commonExamples: Malus spp. (Flowering crabapple)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun essential. Well-draining soil. Fertilize in spring. Prune in late winter; thin for airflow. Choose disease-resistant cultivars (e.g. scab, fire blight). Fruit attracts birds. Edible fruit in some cultivars.

description: Deciduous flowering tree prized for long-lasting summer blooms in pink, purple, red, or white, and attractive exfoliating bark.
commonExamples: Lagerstroemia indica (Crepe myrtle), L. 'Natchez' (white), L. 'Tuscarora' (coral pink), L. 'Dynamite' (red)
careTips: Water deeply once per week during first two years; established trees are drought-tolerant. Full sun required for best flowering — minimum 6 hours direct. Prune in late winter to shape; avoid 'crepe murder' (severe topping). Fertilize in early spring with balanced slow-release fertilizer. Good air circulation prevents powdery mildew. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Deciduous conifer discovered in China in 1944, previously known only from fossils, with feathery foliage that turns russet-bronze in autumn.
commonExamples: Metasequoia glyptostroboides (Dawn redwood)
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist, especially during the first few years. Tolerates wet and even temporarily flooded conditions. Full sun preferred. Prefers moist, slightly acidic, well-drained soil but adapts to various conditions. Fertilize in spring with balanced fertilizer. Fast-growing (up to 60 cm per year). Deciduous—drops needles in fall. Very cold-hardy. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Trees that lose their leaves seasonally, provide shade in summer and allow light in winter.
commonExamples: Acer (Maple, Sugar maple, Red maple), Quercus (Oak, Red oak, White oak), Betula (Birch), Fraxinus (Ash), Ulmus (Elm)
careTips: Deep soak regularly (weekly for first 2-3 years). Water well during establishment period. Mature trees are more drought tolerant but benefit from deep watering during dry spells. Full sun to partial shade depending on species. Fertilize in early spring with tree fertilizer. Prune in late winter/early spring when dormant. Mulch around base to retain moisture. Provide shade in summer, allow light in winter. Research specific species for exact requirements.

description: Also known as: Mesquite. Trees adapted to arid desert conditions, extremely drought tolerant once established.
commonExamples: Prosopis (Mesquite, Honey mesquite), Acacia (Acacia, Sweet acacia), Parkinsonia (Palo verde, Blue palo verde), Olneya (Ironwood)
careTips: Minimal watering once established (monthly or less). Deep but infrequent watering during establishment (first 1-2 years). Allow to dry completely between waterings. Full sun essential. Well-draining soil critical. Fertilize sparingly if at all. Prune in late winter. Extremely drought tolerant once established. Adapted to arid desert conditions. Research specific species for exact requirements. Some are evergreen, others drought-deciduous. Research specific species for seasonal behavior.

description: Deciduous trees and shrubs in the Cornaceae family with showy spring flowers and colorful fall foliage.
commonExamples: Cornus florida (Flowering dogwood), C. kousa (Kousa dogwood, Japanese dogwood), C. nuttallii (Pacific dogwood), C. mas (Cornelian cherry)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist, especially during flowering and fruit development. Prefer partial shade to full sun depending on climate. Well-drained, slightly acidic soil preferred. Fertilize in early spring with acid-loving plant fertilizer. Prune after flowering if needed. Mulch around base to retain moisture. Showy spring flowers and colorful fall foliage. Research specific species for exact requirements. Deciduous; reduce or withhold watering when leaves drop in fall.

description: Iconic umbrella-shaped tree endemic to Socotra Island, Yemen. Known for its distinctive mushroom-like canopy and crimson red resin (dragon's blood) used in traditional medicine and dyes for centuries.
commonExamples: Dracaena cinnabari (Socotra dragon tree, Dragon blood tree)
careTips: Extremely drought tolerant once established. Full sun. Well-draining soil essential. Very slow growing — can live 300-600+ years. Difficult to cultivate outside its native habitat. Hardy in warm, arid climates only. Non-toxic.

description: Also known as: Cider gum. Fast-growing evergreen trees native to Australia with aromatic, often silvery-blue foliage and distinctive peeling bark; widely planted for timber, ornamental value, and essential oil.
commonExamples: Eucalyptus gunnii (Cider gum), E. cinerea (Silver dollar tree), E. pauciflora subsp. niphophila (Snow gum), E. deglupta (Rainbow eucalyptus)
careTips: Water deeply and infrequently once established; young trees need regular watering during the first 2 years. Full sun is essential. Well-drained, slightly acidic soil is ideal; intolerant of waterlogged conditions. Fast-growing — can add 2-3 meters per year in good conditions. Prune to shape in late winter or early spring. Many species are fire-adapted with flammable oils, so consider placement carefully. Coppice multi-stemmed types annually for fresh juvenile foliage. Toxic to pets — eucalyptus oil is harmful if ingested.

description: Trees that retain foliage year-round, provide year-round structure and privacy screening.
commonExamples: Pinus (Pine, Eastern white pine, Scots pine), Picea (Spruce, Norway spruce, Blue spruce), Abies (Fir, Balsam fir), Cedrus (Cedar)
careTips: Deep soak regularly (weekly during growing season). Water well before ground freezes in winter to prevent winter desiccation. Mulch around base to retain moisture and protect roots. Full sun to partial shade depending on species. Fertilize in early spring with evergreen fertilizer. Prune in late winter/early spring. Provide year-round structure and privacy screening. Research specific species for exact requirements. Evergreen; reduce watering in winter when growth slows.

description: Deciduous and evergreen trees grown for edible fruits, require proper pruning and often need cross-pollination.
commonExamples: Malus domestica (Apple), Prunus persica (Peach), Pyrus (Pear), Prunus avium (Cherry)
careTips: Deep soak regularly (weekly during growing season). Increase watering during fruit development. Mulch around base to retain moisture. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize in early spring with fruit tree fertilizer. Prune in late winter/early spring to maintain shape and encourage fruiting. Many require cross-pollination - plant compatible varieties nearby. Thin fruit for larger, healthier fruits. Protect from late frosts during flowering. Reduce watering when dormant in winter.

description: Also known as: Wellingtonia. The largest trees on Earth by volume, native to the western Sierra Nevada with massive trunks and spongy, fire-resistant bark.
commonExamples: Sequoiadendron giganteum (Giant sequoia, Sierra redwood, Wellingtonia)
careTips: Water regularly during establishment (first 3-5 years); mature trees are moderately drought-tolerant. Full sun preferred. Well-drained, deep soil. Fertilize young trees in spring with balanced fertilizer. Very long-lived—some specimens exceed 3,000 years. Extremely cold-hardy. Needs space for massive trunk and root system. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Also known as: Maidenhair tree. Ancient deciduous trees in the Ginkgoaceae family, living fossil, popular street tree in China, male and female trees.
commonExamples: Ginkgo biloba (Ginkgo, Maidenhair tree), male cultivars (no fruit), 'Autumn Gold', 'Princeton Sentry'
careTips: Deep soak regularly during establishment. Mature trees are drought tolerant. Well-drained soil preferred. Full sun preferred. Fertilize in early spring during establishment. Prune in late winter. Ancient living fossil. Popular street tree in China. Plant male cultivars to avoid smelly fruit. Beautiful golden fall foliage. Very long-lived. Deciduous; reduce or withhold watering when leaves drop in fall.

description: Hardy deciduous tree with fluted bark; excellent for hedging and topiary.
commonExamples: Carpinus betulus (European hornbeam)
careTips: Keep soil moist when young. Full sun to partial shade. Tolerates heavy pruning. Fertilize in spring when establishing. Prune in late summer; excellent for formal hedges. Fall color yellow to orange. Dense wood—"ironwood."

description: Also known as: Pencil pine. Iconic narrow, columnar evergreen conifer with dark green, scale-like foliage; a defining element of Mediterranean and Tuscan landscapes.
commonExamples: Cupressus sempervirens (Italian cypress), C. sempervirens 'Stricta' (Columnar Italian cypress), C. sempervirens 'Swane's Gold' (Golden Italian cypress)
careTips: Water deeply but infrequently; drought-tolerant once established — overwatering is the main killer. Full sun is essential for its tight, columnar form. Well-drained, even rocky or gravelly soil is ideal; tolerates alkaline conditions and poor soil. Minimal pruning needed — trim only to remove dead branches. Does not tolerate heavy, waterlogged clay. Protect from sustained freezing winds in marginal zones. Plant in groups for a dramatic landscape statement. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Graceful maple with delicate lobed leaves; red, green, or variegated; stunning fall color.
commonExamples: Acer palmatum (Japanese maple)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist; avoid drought stress. Partial shade preferred—full sun can scorch leaves. Well-draining, slightly acidic soil. Fertilize lightly in spring. Prune in winter when dormant. Protect from wind. Red cultivars need some sun for color.

description: Iconic tree-like yucca of the Mojave Desert with twisted branches and spiky leaf clusters, a symbol of the American Southwest.
commonExamples: Yucca brevifolia (Joshua tree)
careTips: Extremely drought-tolerant; water deeply but infrequently (every 2-3 weeks in summer, rarely in winter). Full sun essential—needs intense direct sunlight. Requires excellent drainage; sandy or gravelly soil ideal. Do not fertilize. Very slow-growing. Protect from frost below -10°C. Mildly toxic (saponins) to pets.

description: Massive tropical tree that can reach 60-70 meters with buttress roots and a wide canopy. Produces large pods containing silky, cotton-like fiber (kapok) used for stuffing and insulation.
commonExamples: Ceiba pentandra (Kapok tree, Silk-cotton tree, Java cotton)
careTips: Water regularly when young; drought tolerant once established. Full sun. Rich, well-draining soil. Fast growing in tropical climates. Cannot tolerate frost. Sacred tree in many cultures — the Mayan World Tree. Non-toxic.

description: Deciduous and evergreen trees in the Magnoliaceae family with large, fragrant flowers, many species are ancient flowering plants.
commonExamples: Magnolia grandiflora (Southern magnolia), M. × soulangeana (Saucer magnolia), M. stellata (Star magnolia), M. liliiflora (Lily magnolia)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist, especially during flowering. Prefer consistently moist but well-drained soil. Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize in early spring with balanced fertilizer. Prune after flowering if needed. Mulch around base to retain moisture. Large, fragrant flowers. Many species are ancient flowering plants. Research specific species for exact requirements. Deciduous; reduce or withhold watering when leaves drop in fall.

description: Compact deciduous magnolia with fragrant star-shaped white flowers appearing before leaves in early spring; ideal small garden tree.
commonExamples: Magnolia stellata (Star magnolia), M. stellata 'Royal Star', M. stellata 'Rosea' (Pink star magnolia)
careTips: Water regularly during first 2-3 years; established trees are moderately drought-tolerant. Full sun to partial shade; protect from late frosts that damage early blooms. Prefers moist, acidic, well-draining soil rich in organic matter. Mulch around base to retain moisture and keep roots cool. Minimal pruning needed—prune only after flowering if necessary. Fertilize in spring with acid-loving plant food. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Tropical coastal trees adapted to saltwater environments with distinctive aerial prop roots. Vital to coastal ecosystems, providing habitat and shoreline protection.
commonExamples: Rhizophora mangle (Red mangrove), Avicennia germinans (Black mangrove), Laguncularia racemosa (White mangrove)
careTips: Keep roots permanently submerged or in very wet soil. Full sun preferred. High humidity essential. Use brackish or saltwater for established plants; freshwater for seedlings. Fertilize sparingly — mangroves thrive in nutrient-poor conditions. Indoor cultivation possible in large containers with standing water. Prune to control size. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Deciduous trees in the Sapindaceae family known for brilliant fall foliage, many species are popular landscape trees.
commonExamples: Acer saccharum (Sugar maple), A. rubrum (Red maple), A. palmatum (Japanese maple), A. platanoides (Norway maple), A. saccharinum (Silver maple)
careTips: Deep soak regularly during establishment (first 2-3 years). Keep consistently moist but well-drained. Mature trees are more drought tolerant. Full sun to partial shade depending on species. Fertilize in early spring with tree fertilizer during establishment. Prune in late winter when dormant. Mulch around base. Brilliant fall foliage. Research specific species for exact requirements.

description: Fast-growing, drought-tolerant tree with edible leaves, pods, seeds, and flowers. Extremely nutritious — leaves contain high levels of vitamins and minerals.
commonExamples: Moringa oleifera (Moringa, Drumstick tree, Horseradish tree, Ben oil tree)
careTips: Water deeply once established, then allow soil to dry somewhat between waterings. Full sun essential. Well-draining sandy or loamy soil. Extremely fast growing — can reach 3+ meters in the first year. Cannot tolerate frost. Prune regularly to encourage bushier growth. Non-toxic — all parts are edible.

description: Evergreen tree native to the Indian subcontinent, widely cultivated for its medicinal and insecticidal properties. Nearly every part of the tree has been used in traditional medicine.
commonExamples: Azadirachta indica (Neem tree, Indian lilac, Margosa tree)
careTips: Water regularly when young; very drought tolerant once established. Full sun. Adapts to poor soils but prefers well-draining conditions. Fast growing. Cannot tolerate frost or prolonged cold. Neem oil from seeds is a popular organic pesticide. Mildly toxic if ingested in large quantities.

description: Majestic deciduous and evergreen trees in the Fagaceae family, provide shade and wildlife habitat, many species are long-lived.
commonExamples: Quercus rubra (Red oak), Q. alba (White oak), Q. virginiana (Live oak), Q. palustris (Pin oak), Q. robur (English oak)
careTips: Deep soak regularly during establishment (first 2-3 years). Mature trees are drought tolerant but benefit from deep watering during extended dry periods. Full sun preferred. Fertilize in early spring with tree fertilizer during first 5 years. Prune in late winter when dormant. Mulch around base to retain moisture. Provide shade in summer. Many species live for centuries. Research specific species for exact requirements.

description: Evergreen conifers in the Pinaceae family with needle-like leaves and woody cones, many species are long-lived and widely planted for timber, shelter, and ornament.
commonExamples: Pinus sylvestris (Scots pine), P. strobus (Eastern white pine), P. ponderosa (Ponderosa pine), P. mugo (Mugo pine), P. nigra (Austrian pine)
careTips: Water deeply during establishment (first 2-3 years). Mature trees are drought tolerant once established. Full sun essential - at least 6 hours daily. Prefer acidic, well-drained soil. Fertilize young trees in early spring with acid-forming fertilizer. Prune candles in spring to control growth - avoid cutting into old wood. Mulch with pine needles to maintain soil acidity. Avoid planting in waterlogged soil. Evergreen - no seasonal leaf drop. Many species live for centuries. Toxic to pets.

description: Also known as: Frangipani. Tropical tree famous for its intensely fragrant, waxy flowers in white, yellow, pink, or red; widely associated with Hawaiian leis.
commonExamples: Plumeria rubra (Common frangipani), P. obtusa (Singapore plumeria), P. 'Celadine' (Yellow frangipani)
careTips: Water regularly during growing season but allow soil to dry between waterings; reduce to almost none in winter dormancy. Full sun essential—at least 6 hours daily for flowering. Well-draining soil critical; prone to root rot in wet conditions. Fertilize with high-phosphorus fertilizer every 2 weeks spring through fall to promote blooms. Goes dormant and drops leaves in winter—this is normal. Protect from frost. Propagates easily from cuttings—allow cut end to dry for a week before planting. Milky sap can irritate skin; mildly toxic to pets.

description: Small tree with magenta flowers on bare branches in early spring; heart-shaped leaves.
commonExamples: Cercis canadensis (Eastern redbud)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist when young. Full sun to partial shade. Well-draining soil. Fertilize in spring. Prune after flowering if needed. Nitrogen-fixing. Susceptible to canker—avoid wounding. Edible flowers. Fall color yellow.

description: Large shrub or small tree with pink flowers on branches before leaves; more heat-tolerant than Eastern redbud.
commonExamples: Cercis chinensis (Chinese redbud)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist when young. Full sun to partial shade. Well-draining soil. Fertilize in spring. Prune after flowering. Tolerates heat better than C. canadensis. Often multi-trunked. Fall color yellow.

description: Multi-trunk birch with distinctive peeling cinnamon-brown bark; tolerates wet soils.
commonExamples: Betula nigra (River birch)
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist; tolerates wet sites. Full sun to partial shade. Acidic soil preferred. Fertilize in spring when young. Prune in late summer to avoid sap bleed. Resistant to bronze birch borer. Heat-tolerant. Often grown multi-trunked.

description: Also known as: Juneberry. Small tree or large shrub with white spring flowers, edible berries, and brilliant fall color.
commonExamples: Amelanchier spp. (Serviceberry, Juneberry)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist when young. Full sun to partial shade. Adapts to various soils. Fertilize in spring. Prune in late winter. Edible berries attract birds. Excellent fall color. Native to North America. Multi-season interest.

description: Shrub or small tree with fluffy gray-pink "smoke" plumes and purple or green foliage.
commonExamples: Cotinus coggygria (Smoke bush)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun for best color and flowering. Well-draining soil. Fertilize in spring. Prune in late winter—cut hard for large leaves, light prune for plumes. Purple cultivars need full sun. Drought tolerant. Fall color orange to red. Mildly toxic to pets—sap may cause irritation; ingestion may cause GI upset.

description: Tall deciduous tree with star-shaped leaves and spiky seed balls; brilliant fall color.
commonExamples: Liquidambar styraciflua (American sweetgum)
careTips: Keep soil moist when young. Full sun preferred. Tolerates wet or dry soil. Fertilize in spring when establishing. Prune in late winter. Fall color red, orange, yellow. Seed balls can be messy—consider fruitless cultivars. Deep taproot.

description: The tallest eastern North American hardwood, with unique four-lobed leaves and tulip-shaped yellow-green flowers in late spring.
commonExamples: Liriodendron tulipifera (Tulip tree, Yellow poplar, Tulip poplar)
careTips: Water deeply and regularly during establishment and dry spells; somewhat drought-sensitive. Full sun preferred. Prefers deep, moist, well-drained, slightly acidic to neutral soil. Fertilize young trees in early spring. Fast-growing shade tree. Prune in late winter when dormant. Aphids on leaves may produce sticky honeydew. Brilliant golden-yellow fall color. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Iconic deciduous tree with gracefully cascading branches that sweep to the ground. Fast-growing; often planted near water features and ponds for dramatic silhouette.
commonExamples: Salix babylonica (Weeping willow), S. × sepulcralis 'Chrysocoma' (Golden weeping willow), S. alba 'Tristis'
careTips: Thrives in moist to wet soil; ideal near ponds, streams, and low-lying areas. Full sun preferred. Extremely fast-growing — can add 2-3m per year. Plant well away from foundations, septic systems, and underground pipes as roots are aggressive. Prune dead or damaged branches in late winter. Short-lived for a tree (30-50 years). Very cold-hardy. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Fast-growing tree with gracefully cascading branches; needs ample water and space.
commonExamples: Salix babylonica (Weeping willow)
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist; thrives near water. Full sun. Plant away from pipes and foundations—aggressive roots. Prune in late winter. Fast growth. Short-lived (30–50 years). Weak wood—susceptible to storm damage. Avoid in small yards.

description: Living fossil discovered in 1994 in a remote canyon in Australia. Thought to have been extinct for 2 million years. Distinctive bubbly, chocolate-brown bark.
commonExamples: Wollemia nobilis (Wollemi pine, Dinosaur tree)
careTips: Water regularly; prefers consistently moist but not waterlogged soil. Partial shade to full sun. Prefers acidic, well-draining soil. Surprisingly adaptable in cultivation. Hardy to about -5°C. Slow growing. Non-toxic. Conservation status: critically endangered in the wild.

description: Also known as: Glossy abelia. Compact shrub with glossy leaves and tubular white-pink flowers; long bloom season.
commonExamples: Abelia × grandiflora (Glossy abelia)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun to partial shade. Well-draining soil. Fertilize in spring. Prune lightly after flowering. Semi-evergreen to evergreen. Attracts pollinators. Deer resistant.

description: Flowering shrubs in the Ericaceae family, part of the Rhododendron genus, prefer acidic soil and partial shade.
commonExamples: Rhododendron (Azalea), R. indicum (Southern Indian azalea), R. kiusianum (Kyushu azalea), evergreen and deciduous varieties, Kurume and Southern Indica hybrids
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist but well-drained (2-3 times per week). Acidic soil essential (pH 4.5-6.0) - use acidifying fertilizer and mulch with pine needles or oak leaves. Partial shade preferred - morning sun with afternoon shade is ideal. Fertilize in early spring with acid-loving plant fertilizer. Prune immediately after flowering. Mulch to keep roots cool and retain moisture. Don't plant too deep - keep root ball slightly above soil level. Research evergreen vs deciduous varieties for your climate. Deciduous varieties: reduce watering when dormant in winter.

description: Thorny shrub with red, gold, or green foliage; small berries; invasive in many regions.
commonExamples: Berberis thunbergii (Japanese barberry)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun for best color. Tolerates poor soil. Fertilize in spring. Prune in late winter—wear gloves for thorns. Deer resistant. Invasive in eastern North America—check local restrictions. Consider sterile cultivars. Mildly toxic to pets—may cause GI upset if ingested.

description: Deciduous shrub with arching branches and vivid magenta-purple berry clusters that encircle the stems in autumn, providing striking fall and winter interest.
commonExamples: Callicarpa americana (American beautyberry), C. bodinieri var. giraldii 'Profusion', C. dichotoma (Purple beautyberry), C. japonica
careTips: Water regularly during establishment; moderately drought-tolerant once mature. Full sun to partial shade—more sun means more berries. Adaptable to most well-drained soils. Fertilize lightly in spring. Can be cut back hard to the ground in late winter to rejuvenate (blooms on new wood). Berries attract birds. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Evergreen shrubs in the Buxaceae family with dense foliage, popular for hedges and topiary, slow-growing and long-lived.
commonExamples: Buxus sempervirens (Common boxwood, English boxwood), B. microphylla (Littleleaf boxwood), B. sinica (Korean boxwood)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist, especially during establishment. Well-drained soil essential. Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize in early spring with balanced fertilizer. Prune in late spring or early summer to maintain shape. Mulch around base. Dense foliage perfect for hedges and topiary. Slow-growing and long-lived. Watch for boxwood blight and pests. Evergreen; reduce watering in winter when growth slows.

description: Shrub with corky winged branches; brilliant scarlet fall color; invasive in many areas.
commonExamples: Euonymus alatus (Winged euonymus)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun for best fall color. Adapts to most soils. Fertilize in spring. Prune in late winter. Invasive in eastern North America—avoid or use sterile cultivars. Berries toxic. Corky "wings" on stems distinctive.

description: Also known as: Summer lilac. Arching shrub with fragrant flower spikes; attracts butterflies; can be invasive.
commonExamples: Buddleja davidii (Summer lilac)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun essential. Well-draining soil. Fertilize in spring. Prune hard in late winter—flowers on new growth. Deadhead to prolong bloom. Invasive in some regions—choose sterile cultivars. Deer resistant.

description: Evergreen shrubs in the Theaceae family with beautiful flowers, includes tea plant, popular in Chinese gardens.
commonExamples: Camellia japonica (Japanese camellia), C. sinensis (Tea plant), C. sasanqua (Sasanqua camellia)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (weekly deep watering). Well-drained, acidic soil essential. Partial shade preferred - avoid hot afternoon sun. Fertilize in spring with acid-loving plant fertilizer. Prune after flowering. Beautiful flowers in winter/spring. Tea plant (C. sinensis) leaves are used for tea. Popular in Chinese gardens. Protect from harsh winds. Evergreen; reduce watering in winter when growth slows.

description: Also known as: Bluebeard. Compact shrub with blue flower clusters in late summer; silvery-gray foliage.
commonExamples: Caryopteris × clandonensis (Bluebeard)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun preferred. Well-draining soil. Fertilize in spring. Cut back hard in late winter—flowers on new growth. Drought tolerant. Attracts bees and butterflies. Deer resistant. Late-season bloomer.

description: Evergreen plants that tolerate cold winter temperatures, provide year-round structure and color in landscapes.
commonExamples: Buxus (Boxwood), Ilex (Holly, American holly, English holly), Taxus (Yew), Juniperus (Juniper), Thuja (Arborvitae)
careTips: Deep soak regularly during growing season. Water well before ground freezes in winter to prevent winter desiccation (brown needles). Mulch around base to retain moisture and protect roots. Full sun to partial shade depending on species. Fertilize in early spring with evergreen fertilizer. Prune in late winter/early spring. Tolerate cold winter temperatures. Provide year-round structure and color. Research specific species for exact requirements.

description: Spreading shrub with herringbone branches, small leaves, and red berries; groundcover or upright.
commonExamples: Cotoneaster horizontalis, C. dammeri
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun to partial shade. Well-draining soil. Fertilize in spring. Prune after berries drop. Fire blight susceptible. Berries attract birds. Some species invasive—check locally. Drought tolerant once established.

description: Woody shrubs that retain foliage year-round, provide structure and privacy in landscapes.
commonExamples: Buxus (Boxwood, American boxwood), Ligustrum (Privet), Ilex (Holly, American holly), Taxus (Yew), Camellia
careTips: Deep soak regularly (weekly during growing season). Keep consistently moist during establishment (first 1-2 years). Water well before ground freezes in winter to prevent desiccation. Full sun to partial shade depending on species. Fertilize in early spring with shrub fertilizer. Prune in late winter/early spring to maintain shape. Mulch around base. Provide structure and privacy year-round. Research specific species for exact requirements. Evergreen; reduce watering in winter when growth slows.

description: Woody shrubs grown primarily for their flowers, many require specific soil pH for optimal bloom color.
commonExamples: Hydrangea (Bigleaf, Panicle, Oakleaf), Rhododendron (Azalea), Syringa (Lilac), Forsythia
careTips: Deep soak at base regularly (weekly during growing season). Keep consistently moist during flowering period. Mulch around base to retain moisture. Full sun to partial shade depending on species. Fertilize in early spring with flowering shrub fertilizer. Many require specific soil pH for optimal bloom color (e.g., hydrangeas - acidic for blue, alkaline for pink). Prune after flowering or in late winter depending on species. Research specific species for exact requirements. Deciduous in most climates; reduce watering when dormant in winter.

description: One of the earliest spring-blooming shrubs, covered in bright yellow flowers before leaves emerge. Fast-growing and hardy; often used as hedging or specimen plants.
commonExamples: Forsythia × intermedia (Border forsythia), F. suspensa (Weeping forsythia), F. 'Lynwood Gold', F. 'Spring Glory'
careTips: Water regularly during first year; established plants are drought-tolerant. Full sun produces best flowering; tolerates partial shade. Prune immediately after flowering since blooms form on previous year's wood. Rejuvenate overgrown plants by cutting one-third of oldest stems to ground annually. Fertilize in early spring. Extremely cold-hardy. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Evergreen or deciduous shrub with spiny leaves and red berries; needs male and female for fruit.
commonExamples: Ilex spp. (American holly, English holly)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist. Full sun to partial shade. Slightly acidic soil preferred. Fertilize in spring. Prune in late winter. Male and female plants needed for berries. Berries toxic. Deer resistant. Many cultivars for size and form.

description: Also known as: Mophead, Lacecap. Popular flowering shrubs in the Hydrangeaceae family, flower color depends on soil pH for some varieties.
commonExamples: Hydrangea macrophylla (Bigleaf hydrangea, Mophead, Lacecap), H. paniculata (Panicle hydrangea), H. arborescens (Smooth hydrangea), H. quercifolia (Oakleaf hydrangea)
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist (2-3 times per week). Water deeply during flowering period. Mulch to retain moisture. Partial shade preferred - morning sun with afternoon shade is ideal. Fertilize in early spring with balanced fertilizer. Bigleaf hydrangeas: acidic soil (pH 5.5) produces blue flowers; alkaline soil (pH 6.5+) produces pink flowers. Prune after flowering or in late winter depending on species. Research specific type for pruning requirements - some bloom on old wood, others on new wood. Deciduous varieties: reduce watering when dormant in winter.

description: Evergreen coniferous shrubs and trees in the Cupressaceae family, drought-tolerant and versatile for landscapes.
commonExamples: Juniperus horizontalis (Creeping juniper, Blue rug juniper), J. chinensis (Chinese juniper), J. virginiana (Eastern red cedar), J. scopulorum (Rocky Mountain juniper)
careTips: Water deeply but infrequently once established (every 2-3 weeks). Very drought tolerant. Well-drained soil essential. Full sun preferred. Fertilize sparingly in spring with evergreen fertilizer. Prune in late winter or early spring. Many varieties available from groundcovers to trees. Very versatile for landscapes. Evergreen; reduce watering in winter when growth slows.

description: Disease-resistant, continuously blooming landscape rose that revolutionized home rose growing. Requires minimal maintenance compared to traditional hybrid tea roses.
commonExamples: Rosa 'Radrazz' (Knock Out rose), 'Double Knock Out' (double petals), 'Pink Knock Out', 'Sunny Knock Out' (yellow)
careTips: Water deeply once or twice a week. Full sun (6+ hours). Well-draining, slightly acidic soil. Prune in early spring to 12-18 inches. Self-cleaning — no deadheading needed. Highly resistant to black spot. Fertilize in spring and summer. Non-toxic.

description: Also known as: English lavender. Aromatic flowering herbs in the Lamiaceae family with silvery foliage and fragrant purple flowers, drought-tolerant once established.
commonExamples: Lavandula angustifolia (English lavender), L. stoechas (Spanish lavender), L. × intermedia (Lavandin)
careTips: Water when soil is dry (every 1-2 weeks once established). Well-draining soil essential - avoid heavy clay. Avoid overwatering which causes root rot. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Drought-tolerant once established. Fertilize sparingly in spring with low-nitrogen fertilizer. Prune after flowering to maintain shape. Harvest flowers when buds are just opening. Silvery foliage and fragrant purple flowers. Excellent for dry gardens. Evergreen; reduce watering in winter when growth slows.

description: Native prairie shrub with silvery-gray foliage and purple flower spikes; nitrogen-fixing, drought tolerant, attracts pollinators.
commonExamples: Amorpha canescens
careTips: Water when top 2 inches dry; very drought-tolerant once established. Full sun. Deep taproot fixes nitrogen—improves surrounding soil. Sandy to loamy, well-draining soil. Rarely needs fertilizer. Cut back in late winter. Slow to establish but extremely long-lived.

description: Deciduous shrubs in the Oleaceae family with fragrant spring flowers in shades of purple, pink, white, and blue.
commonExamples: Syringa vulgaris (Common lilac, French lilac), S. × persica (Persian lilac), S. reticulata (Japanese tree lilac)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist during growing season. Well-drained, slightly alkaline soil preferred. Full sun essential for best flowering. Fertilize in early spring with balanced fertilizer. Prune immediately after flowering to remove spent blooms and shape. Remove old canes to rejuvenate. Fragrant spring flowers. Very cold hardy. Deciduous varieties: reduce watering when dormant in winter.

description: Panicle hydrangea with large, cone-shaped flower clusters that emerge lime-green, turn white, then fade to pink in fall. Blooms on new wood, so reliable even after harsh winters.
commonExamples: Hydrangea paniculata 'Limelight' (Limelight hydrangea), 'Little Lime' (dwarf form), 'Limelight Prime'
careTips: Water regularly — prefers consistently moist soil. Partial sun to full sun. Unlike bigleaf hydrangeas, flower color is not affected by soil pH. Prune in late winter or early spring. Blooms on new wood. Very cold hardy. Toxic if ingested.

description: Also known as: Chinese fringe flower. Shrub with purple or green foliage and fringed white or pink flowers; related to witch hazel.
commonExamples: Loropetalum chinense (Chinese fringe flower)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun for best color. Well-draining, slightly acidic soil. Fertilize in spring. Prune after flowering. Purple cultivars need sun for color. Cold-sensitive in marginal zones. Fast-growing. Versatile size.

description: Evergreen shrub native to eastern North America with leathery leaves and stunning clusters of geometric cup-shaped flowers with unique spring-loaded stamens.
commonExamples: Kalmia latifolia (Mountain laurel), K. latifolia 'Olympic Fire', K. latifolia 'Elf', K. latifolia 'Carousel'
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist but well-drained; never allow to sit in standing water. Partial shade preferred—tolerates deep shade but flowers best with morning sun. Requires acidic soil (pH 4.5-5.5); mulch with pine needles or oak leaves. Fertilize lightly in spring with acid-loving plant fertilizer. Minimal pruning—remove spent flower clusters to encourage next year's bloom. Toxic to pets and humans (grayanotoxins).

description: Bamboo-like shrub with ferny foliage; red fall color and berries; invasive in Southeast US.
commonExamples: Nandina domestica (Heavenly bamboo)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun to partial shade. Adapts to most soils. Fertilize in spring. Prune to remove old canes. Toxic to pets. Berries toxic to birds—choose fruitless cultivars. Invasive in warm climates. Not a true bamboo.

description: Hardy shrub with peeling bark and colorful foliage; white or pink flower clusters.
commonExamples: Physocarpus opulifolius
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun for best color. Tolerates various soils. Fertilize in spring. Prune in late winter—rejuvenation prune if overgrown. Bark peels in layers. Purple and gold cultivars available. Native. Deer resistant. Mildly toxic to pets—bark may cause GI upset if ingested.

description: Also known as: Sweet osmanthus. Evergreen shrubs in the Oleaceae family with highly fragrant flowers, popular in Chinese gardens and tea.
commonExamples: Osmanthus fragrans (Sweet osmanthus, Fragrant olive, Tea olive), O. × fortunei, various cultivars
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (weekly deep watering). Well-drained, slightly acidic soil preferred. Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize in early spring with acid-loving plant fertilizer. Prune after flowering to maintain shape. Highly fragrant flowers in fall. Popular in Chinese gardens and tea. Can be grown in containers. Evergreen foliage. Evergreen; reduce watering in winter when growth slows.

description: Also known as: Lily of the valley shrub, Andromeda. Evergreen shrub with cascading clusters of bell-shaped white or pink flowers in spring and colorful new growth in shades of red, bronze, or pink.
commonExamples: Pieris japonica (Japanese pieris, Lily of the valley shrub), P. japonica 'Mountain Fire', P. japonica 'Flaming Silver'
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist but not waterlogged; water deeply during dry periods. Partial shade preferred—morning sun with afternoon shade is ideal. Requires acidic soil (pH 4.5-6.0); amend with peat or sulfur if needed. Mulch with pine needles or bark to maintain acidity. Prune lightly after flowering to shape. Fertilize in spring with acid-loving plant food. All parts toxic to pets and humans (grayanotoxins).

description: Also known as: Cape leadwort. Sprawling subtropical shrub with clusters of sky-blue phlox-like flowers blooming profusely from spring through fall. Excellent for fences, arbors, and containers.
commonExamples: Plumbago auriculata (Cape plumbago), P. auriculata 'Alba' (white), P. auriculata 'Royal Cape' (deep blue)
careTips: Water regularly during bloom season; drought-tolerant once established. Full sun produces heaviest flowering; tolerates partial shade. Prune hard in late winter to encourage bushy growth. Fertilize monthly during growing season. Fast grower; can become leggy without pruning. Mildly toxic — may cause skin irritation. Protect from hard frost.

description: Evergreen and deciduous flowering shrubs in the Ericaceae family, prefer acidic soil and partial shade, many are large-growing.
commonExamples: Rhododendron (Rhododendron), R. catawbiense (Catawba rhododendron), R. maximum (Rosebay rhododendron), R. yakushimanum (Yakushima rhododendron), large-leaved and small-leaved varieties
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist but well-drained (2-3 times per week). Acidic soil essential (pH 4.5-6.0) - use acidifying fertilizer and mulch with pine needles or oak leaves. Partial shade preferred - morning sun with afternoon shade is ideal. Protect from hot afternoon sun. Fertilize in early spring with acid-loving plant fertilizer. Prune immediately after flowering if needed. Mulch to keep roots cool and retain moisture. Don't plant too deep. Research specific variety for mature size - some grow very large. Deciduous varieties: reduce watering when dormant in winter.

description: Upright shrub with late-summer hibiscus flowers; can self-seed prolifically.
commonExamples: Hibiscus syriacus (Shrub althea)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun preferred. Well-draining soil. Fertilize in spring. Prune in late winter. Choose sterile cultivars to avoid seed spread. Flowers on new growth. Drought tolerant. Single or double flowers.

description: Aromatic evergreen herbs in the Lamiaceae family, drought-tolerant once established, can grow as shrub or groundcover.
commonExamples: Salvia rosmarinus (syn. Rosmarinus officinalis) (Rosemary), upright and prostrate varieties, R. officinalis 'Arp' (cold-hardy), R. officinalis 'Tuscan Blue'
careTips: Water when soil is dry (every 1-2 weeks once established). Avoid overwatering which causes root rot. Well-draining soil essential. Very drought tolerant once established. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize sparingly in spring. Prune regularly to harvest and maintain shape. Can grow as shrub or groundcover depending on variety. Aromatic evergreen herb. Excellent for Mediterranean gardens. Evergreen; reduce watering in winter when growth slows.

description: Classic flowering shrubs in the Rosaceae family with fragrant blooms, require good air circulation.
commonExamples: Rosa (Rose), various types: Hybrid tea, Floribunda, Grandiflora, Climbing roses
careTips: Regular deep watering at base (2-3 times per week during growing season). Avoid wetting leaves to prevent disease (black spot, powdery mildew). Mulch around base to retain moisture. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize monthly spring through fall with rose fertilizer. Prune in late winter/early spring. Deadhead spent flowers to encourage reblooming. Good air circulation essential to prevent disease. Research specific type for exact requirements. Deciduous in most climates; reduce watering when dormant in winter.

description: Upright perennial with lavender-blue flower spikes and silvery foliage; aromatic.
commonExamples: Salvia yangii (syn. Perovskia atriplicifolia; Russian sage), S. yangii 'Blue Spire'
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun essential. Well-draining soil; drought tolerant. Fertilize sparingly. Cut back to ground in late winter. Deer resistant. Attracts pollinators.

description: Versatile shrub with spring or summer flowers; mound-forming or cascading forms.
commonExamples: Spiraea japonica, S. prunifolia (Bridal wreath)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun preferred. Adapts to most soils. Fertilize in spring. Spring bloomers: prune after flowering. Summer bloomers: prune in late winter. Tough and easy. Many cultivars for size and color.

description: Deciduous and evergreen shrubs in the Adoxaceae family with showy flowers, colorful berries, and fall foliage.
commonExamples: Viburnum opulus (European cranberrybush, Snowball viburnum), V. dentatum (Arrowwood), V. plicatum (Japanese snowball), V. carlesii (Koreanspice viburnum)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist, especially during flowering and fruiting. Well-drained soil preferred. Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize in early spring with balanced fertilizer. Prune after flowering if needed. Mulch around base. Showy flowers, colorful berries, and fall foliage. Many species attract birds. Research specific species for exact requirements. Deciduous varieties: reduce watering when dormant in winter.

description: Architectural shrub with trumpet flowers in spring; green, gold, or variegated foliage.
commonExamples: Weigela florida
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun for best bloom. Well-draining soil. Fertilize in spring. Prune after flowering—remove old wood. May rebloom lightly. Hummingbird magnet. Deer resistant. Many cultivars for size and leaf color.

description: Deciduous shrub or small tree that blooms in late winter to early spring with fragrant, spidery, ribbon-like flowers in yellow, orange, or red when most other plants are dormant.
commonExamples: Hamamelis virginiana (Common witch hazel), H. x intermedia 'Jelena', H. x intermedia 'Arnold Promise', H. mollis (Chinese witch hazel)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist, especially during establishment. Partial shade to full sun; afternoon shade beneficial in hot climates. Prefers moist, acidic, well-drained soil rich in organic matter. Fertilize lightly in spring. Minimal pruning needed—prune right after flowering if shaping is desired. Valued for winter interest when little else blooms. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Ancient evergreen conifer with dark green needles and red berry-like arils. Extremely long-lived and tolerant of heavy pruning; one of the finest hedge and topiary plants.
commonExamples: Taxus baccata (English yew), T. cuspidata (Japanese yew), T. × media 'Hicksii' (Hicks yew), T. 'Fastigiata' (Irish yew)
careTips: Water regularly when young; established yews tolerate drought. Partial sun to full shade — one of few conifers thriving in deep shade. Well-drained soil essential — yews will not tolerate wet feet. Prune anytime for shaping; responds well to hard renovation pruning. Fertilize in early spring. Extremely cold-hardy. All parts highly toxic to pets and humans except the red aril flesh.

description: Also known as: African lily. Clump-forming perennial with strap-shaped leaves and spectacular rounded clusters of blue, purple, or white trumpet flowers on tall stalks.
commonExamples: Agapanthus africanus (African lily), A. praecox (Lily of the Nile), A. 'Storm Cloud' (deep blue), A. 'White Heaven'
careTips: Water regularly during growing season; reduce in winter. Full sun produces best flowering. Performs best when slightly root-bound — do not over-pot. Divide congested clumps every 4-5 years after flowering. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with high-potassium fertilizer. Evergreen types less cold-hardy than deciduous. Mulch in cold climates. Mildly toxic if ingested.

description: Also known as: Hyssop. Aromatic perennial with dense spikes of tubular flowers in orange, pink, purple, or blue; a magnet for hummingbirds, bees, and butterflies.
commonExamples: Agastache foeniculum (Anise hyssop), A. rupestris (Sunset hyssop), A. 'Blue Fortune' (Blue Fortune hyssop), A. aurantiaca 'Coronado' (Coronado hyssop)
careTips: Water sparingly once established; very drought-tolerant and sensitive to overwatering, especially in winter. Full sun (6+ hours) is essential for the most flowers and most aromatic foliage. Excellent drainage is critical — thrives in lean, sandy, or gravelly soil and struggles in heavy clay. Do not cut back in fall; leave stems standing through winter for protection, then prune to new growth in spring. Short-lived (3-5 years) but self-seeds freely. Deer and rabbit resistant due to aromatic foliage. Non-toxic to pets — anise hyssop leaves are even edible for humans.

description: Fall-blooming perennial flowering plants in the Asteraceae family, provide late-season color with daisy-like flowers.
commonExamples: Symphyotrichum (Aster, New England aster), S. novae-angliae (New England aster), S. novi-belgii (New York aster), Callistephus (China aster, annual)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Water deeply during flowering period. Full sun preferred for best flowering. Fertilize in early spring with balanced fertilizer. Pinch back in early summer to encourage bushier growth and more flowers. Divide every 2-3 years in spring. Stake tall varieties. Remove spent flowers to encourage more blooms. Excellent for fall color. Attract butterflies and pollinators. Research perennial vs annual varieties. Herbaceous perennials die back; reduce watering when dormant.

description: Also known as: False spirea. Feathery plumes in pink, white, or red; thrives in moist shade.
commonExamples: Astilbe × arendsii (False spirea)
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist. Partial to full shade; burns in full sun. Rich, well-draining soil. Fertilize in spring. Divide every 3–4 years. Deadhead spent plumes. Attracts pollinators. Deer resistant.

description: Also known as: Bergamot. Native perennial with shaggy red, pink, or purple flowers; aromatic foliage.
commonExamples: Monarda didyma (Bergamot)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist. Full sun to partial shade. Well-draining soil. Fertilize in spring. Prone to mildew—plant for airflow, choose resistant cultivars. Deadhead to prolong bloom. Divide every 2–3 years. Attracts hummingbirds and bees.

description: Also known as: Gloriosa daisy. Herbaceous perennials in the Asteraceae family with bright yellow daisy-like flowers and dark centers, native wildflowers.
commonExamples: Rudbeckia hirta (Black-eyed Susan, Gloriosa daisy), R. fulgida (Orange coneflower), R. laciniata (Cutleaf coneflower), R. triloba (Brown-eyed Susan)
careTips: Water deeply once per week during growing season. Drought tolerant once established. Well-drained soil preferred. Full sun essential for best flowering. Fertilize in early spring with balanced fertilizer. Deadhead spent flowers to encourage reblooming. Self-seeds readily. Divide every 3-4 years. Bright yellow daisy-like flowers. Native wildflowers. Herbaceous perennials die back; reduce watering when dormant.

description: Prairie native with tall purple flower spikes; attracts butterflies and pollinators; drought tolerant.
commonExamples: Liatris spicata
careTips: Water when top 1-2 inches dry; drought-tolerant once established. Full sun essential for upright growth. Well-draining soil; avoid wet winter conditions. No fertilizer needed on average soil. Excellent cut flower. Key monarch butterfly nectar source in late summer.

description: Also known as: Dicentra. Graceful heart-shaped flowers on arching stems; foliage goes dormant in summer heat.
commonExamples: Lamprocapnos spectabilis (syn. Dicentra spectabilis; Old-fashioned bleeding heart)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist. Partial to full shade. Rich, well-draining soil. Fertilize in spring. Foliage yellows and dies back in summer—plant with later emergers. Toxic. Divide in fall. Long-lived.

description: Native milkweed with bright orange flowers; essential for monarch butterflies.
commonExamples: Asclepias tuberosa (Orange milkweed)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun essential. Well-draining, drier soil; avoid wet feet. Drought tolerant. Do not use pesticides—host plant for monarchs. Taproot—difficult to transplant. Leave seed pods for wildlife. Toxic to pets.

description: Mounding perennial with lavender-blue flower spikes; aromatic, cat-attracting foliage.
commonExamples: Nepeta × faassenii (Catmint)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun preferred. Well-draining soil. Drought tolerant. Shear after first bloom for rebloom. Deer resistant. Low maintenance. Spreads by rhizomes—divide if needed.

description: Also known as: Florist's chrysanthemum. Fall-blooming perennial flowering plants in the Asteraceae family, provide late-season color, many varieties available.
commonExamples: Chrysanthemum × morifolium (Garden mum, Florist's chrysanthemum), C. indicum, cushion, daisy, pompon, and spider varieties
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Water deeply during flowering period. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize in early spring and again in midsummer with balanced fertilizer. Pinch back until mid-July to encourage bushiness and more flowers. Divide every 2-3 years in spring. Stake tall varieties. Excellent for fall color. Many are treated as annuals but are perennials in zones 5-9. Research hardiness for your zone. Herbaceous perennials die back; reduce watering when dormant.

description: Also known as: Granny's Bonnet. Delicate woodland perennial with distinctive spurred flowers in vivid color combinations—red & yellow, blue & white, pink & purple. Blooms mid-spring to early summer; attracts hummingbirds. Short-lived (3-4 years) but self-seeds freely to naturalize.
commonExamples: Aquilegia vulgaris (European columbine)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist. Partial shade preferred in hot climates. Well-draining soil. Fertilize in spring. Short-lived but self-seeds. Leaf miners common—remove affected leaves. Hummingbird magnet. Toxic.

description: Essential Monarch butterfly host plant; fragrant pink flowers; spreads by rhizomes; full sun.
commonExamples: Asclepias syriaca
careTips: Water when top 1-2 inches of soil is dry. Full sun preferred; drought tolerant once established. Well-draining soil. Fertilize lightly in spring if needed; many prairie natives prefer lean soil. Toxic to pets.

description: Tall prairie native with large yellow flowers; leaves orient north-south; drought tolerant.
commonExamples: Silphium laciniatum
careTips: Water when top 2 inches dry; extremely drought-tolerant once established. Full sun. Deep taproot (15+ ft) makes transplanting difficult—site carefully. Well-draining, lean soil. No fertilizer. Basal leaves orient north-south (hence the name). Slow to bloom from seed (3-5 years).

description: Herbaceous perennials in the Asteraceae family with daisy-like flowers and prominent central cones, attract butterflies and birds.
commonExamples: Echinacea purpurea (Purple coneflower), E. pallida (Pale purple coneflower), E. angustifolia (Narrow-leaf coneflower), E. tennesseensis (Tennessee coneflower), E. paradoxa (Yellow coneflower)
careTips: Water deeply once per week during growing season. Drought tolerant once established. Well-drained soil preferred. Full sun essential for best flowering. Fertilize in early spring with balanced fertilizer. Deadhead spent flowers to encourage reblooming. Leave seed heads in fall for birds. Divide every 3-4 years. Attract butterflies and birds. Herbaceous perennials die back; reduce watering when dormant.

description: Cheerful yellow daisies; long bloom season, low maintenance.
commonExamples: Coreopsis grandiflora, C. tinctoria
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun preferred. Well-draining soil. Drought tolerant. Deadhead for prolonged bloom. Cut back in midsummer to rejuvenate. Some cultivars sterile—no deadheading needed. Deer resistant.

description: Also known as: Mother of thyme. Low mat-forming herb with tiny flowers; aromatic, walkable groundcover.
commonExamples: Thymus serpyllum (Mother of thyme)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun essential. Well-draining, lean soil. Drought tolerant. Shear after flowering. Tolerates light foot traffic. Ideal between paving stones. Edible. Deer resistant.

description: Native perennial with white candelabra flower spikes; attracts butterflies; prefers moist soil.
commonExamples: Veronicastrum virginicum
careTips: Water when top 1-2 inches of soil is dry. Full sun preferred; drought tolerant once established. Well-draining soil. Fertilize lightly in spring if needed; many prairie natives prefer lean soil. Mildly toxic to pets—roots are potent; keep away from pets.

description: Daisy-like flowering plants in the Asteraceae family, include both annual and perennial types with white or colored petals.
commonExamples: Leucanthemum vulgare (Oxeye daisy), L. × superbum (Shasta daisy), Gerbera (Gerbera daisy), Bellis perennis (English daisy), Argyranthemum (Marguerite daisy)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Water at base to avoid wetting flowers. Full sun preferred for best flowering. Fertilize monthly during growing season with balanced fertilizer. Deadhead regularly to encourage continuous blooming. Divide perennials every 2-3 years in spring or fall. Cut back after flowering. Many are excellent cut flowers. Attract butterflies and pollinators. Research specific type (annual vs perennial) for exact requirements. Herbaceous perennials die back; reduce watering when dormant.

description: Also known as: Daylily. Hardy perennial flowering plants in the Asphodelaceae family, each flower lasts one day but plants produce many blooms.
commonExamples: Hemerocallis (Daylily), H. fulva (Orange daylily, Tawny daylily), H. 'Stella de Oro', reblooming and evergreen varieties
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Water deeply during flowering period. Full sun to partial shade - more sun equals more flowers. Fertilize in early spring and after first bloom with balanced fertilizer. Divide every 3-5 years in spring or fall to maintain vigor. Remove spent flowers daily. Cut back foliage in fall or spring. Very low-maintenance and drought-tolerant once established. Research reblooming varieties for extended flowering. Herbaceous perennials die back; reduce watering when dormant.

description: Tall spikes of blue, purple, or white flowers; may need staking. Toxic.
commonExamples: Delphinium elatum (Bee larkspur)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist. Full sun preferred. Rich, well-draining soil. Fertilize in spring. Stake tall varieties. Deadhead to encourage rebloom. Short-lived—replace every 2–3 years. Protect from slugs. All parts toxic to humans and pets.

description: Also known as: Pinks. Compact plants with fragrant, fringed flowers; pinks, carnations, and sweet william.
commonExamples: Dianthus plumarius (Pinks, Cottage pink)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun essential. Well-draining, neutral to alkaline soil. Fertilize in spring. Deadhead for rebloom. Avoid wet foliage—crown rot. Short-lived in humid climates. Many cultivars for size and flower type. Toxic to pets.

description: One of the world's oldest cultivated flowers, grown for over 2,000 years. Prized for ruffled, fragrant blooms in almost every color. A staple in the cut flower industry.
commonExamples: Dianthus caryophyllus (Carnation, Clove pink), 'Chabaud' (garden), 'Grenadin' (double), Spray carnations (multiple small flowers)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry; avoid wetting foliage. Full sun (6+ hours). Well-draining, neutral to slightly alkaline soil. Deadhead regularly to encourage repeat blooming. Stake tall varieties. Fertilize monthly during growing season. Mildly toxic to pets.

description: Native legume with blue flowers and blue-gray foliage; nitrogen-fixing; drought tolerant.
commonExamples: Baptisia australis (Blue false indigo), B. tinctoria (Yellow wild indigo), B. 'Twilite Prairieblues', B. alba (White wild indigo)
careTips: Water when top 1-2 inches of soil is dry. Full sun preferred; drought tolerant once established. Well-draining soil. Fertilize lightly in spring if needed; many prairie natives prefer lean soil. Mildly toxic to pets—may cause GI upset if ingested.

description: European wildflower with lavender pincushion flowers; long blooming; attracts butterflies.
commonExamples: Knautia arvensis
careTips: Water when top 1-2 inches dry; moderate drought tolerance once established. Full sun to partial shade. Well-draining, alkaline-leaning soil. Light spring fertilizer. Lavender-blue pincushion flowers June-September. Deadhead for extended bloom. Beloved by butterflies and pollinators. European meadow native.

description: Tall spikes of tubular, bell-shaped flowers in pink, purple, or white; biennial or short-lived perennial. All parts are toxic.
commonExamples: Digitalis purpurea (Common foxglove)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun to partial shade depending on species. Fertilize in spring. Mulch to retain moisture. Prune as needed for shape. All parts highly toxic to humans and pets. Contains cardiac glycosides.

description: Also known as: Blanket Flower. Colorful daisy-like perennials and annuals with red, yellow, and orange bicolor flowers. Drought tolerant and long-blooming, excellent for pollinators.
commonExamples: Gaillardia x grandiflora (Blanket flower), G. pulchella (Indian blanket, annual), G. 'Arizona Sun', G. 'Goblin', G. aristata
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun to partial shade depending on species. Fertilize in spring. Mulch to retain moisture. Prune as needed for shape. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Also known as: Bee blossom. Graceful perennial with slender, wiry stems bearing delicate white or pink flowers that dance in the breeze from late spring to frost.
commonExamples: Oenothera lindheimeri (Gaura, Bee blossom), O. lindheimeri 'Whirling Butterflies' (White gaura), O. lindheimeri 'Siskiyou Pink' (Pink gaura), O. lindheimeri 'Crimson Butterflies'
careTips: Water sparingly once established; drought-tolerant and prone to root rot in wet soils. Full sun produces the most floriferous display. Well-drained, lean soil is ideal — rich soil promotes floppy growth. Cut back by one-third after the first bloom flush to encourage reblooming. May be short-lived (3-5 years) but self-seeds readily in favorable conditions. Does not transplant well due to a deep taproot — site carefully when planting. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Native perennial with yellow flower plumes in fall; important for pollinators; drought tolerant.
commonExamples: Solidago (Goldenrod), S. speciosa (Showy goldenrod), S. rugosa 'Fireworks', S. canadensis (Canada goldenrod), S. sempervirens (Seaside goldenrod)
careTips: Water when top 1-2 inches dry; drought-tolerant once established. Full sun to light shade. Adapts to most soils. Minimal fertilizer; rich soil causes floppy growth. Cut back in late winter. Does NOT cause hay fever (wind-pollinated ragweed blooms simultaneously). Vital late-season pollinator plant.

description: Tall biennial with velvety leaves and yellow flower spike; drought tolerant; self-seeds.
commonExamples: Verbascum thapsus
careTips: Water when top 1-2 inches of soil is dry. Full sun preferred; drought tolerant once established. Well-draining soil. Fertilize lightly in spring if needed; tolerates lean soil; European wildflower. Mildly toxic to pets—seeds and compounds may cause GI upset; keep away from pets.

description: Also known as: Cranesbill. True perennial geraniums with cup-shaped flowers and rounded leaves; low-maintenance groundcover for borders.
commonExamples: Geranium spp. (Cranesbill)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun to partial shade; afternoon shade in hot climates. Well-draining soil enriched with compost. Fertilize lightly in spring. Shear after first bloom flush for tidy rebloom. Spreading groundcover; divide every 3-4 years. Deer and rabbit resistant. Non-toxic.

description: Also known as: Rose mallow. Cold-hardy perennial hibiscus producing dinner-plate-sized flowers (up to 30 cm) in white, pink, red, and bicolor from mid-summer to frost.
commonExamples: Hibiscus moscheutos (Rose mallow), H. moscheutos 'Luna' series, H. 'Lord Baltimore' (Red hardy hibiscus), H. coccineus (Texas star hibiscus)
careTips: Water consistently to keep soil evenly moist; thrives near ponds and in rain gardens. Full sun (6+ hours) is essential for maximum flowering. Rich, moisture-retentive soil amended with compost is ideal. Fertilize monthly during the growing season with balanced fertilizer. Cut stems to 10-15 cm in late fall after frost kills the foliage — new growth emerges late in spring (don't give up on it!). Mulch the crown in cold zones for extra winter protection. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Also known as: Helen's flower. Late-summer to fall perennial with daisy-like flowers in warm tones of yellow, orange, red, and bicolor, featuring distinctive raised central cones.
commonExamples: Helenium autumnale (Common sneezeweed), H. 'Mardi Gras' (Mardi Gras sneezeweed), H. 'Sahin's Early Flowerer', H. 'Moerheim Beauty'
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist during the growing season; does not tolerate prolonged drought. Full sun (6+ hours) is essential for upright growth and maximum flowering. Average to rich, moisture-retentive soil is ideal. Pinch stem tips in late spring to promote bushier, more compact growth and more flowers. Divide every 3-4 years in spring to maintain vigor and prevent center die-out. Mildly toxic if ingested — the common name refers to dried leaves historically used as snuff, not allergenic pollen.

description: Also known as: Lenten rose. Shade-loving perennials that bloom in late winter to early spring with nodding flowers in white, pink, purple, green, or burgundy.
commonExamples: Helleborus orientalis (Lenten rose), H. niger (Christmas rose), H. x hybridus (Hybrid hellebore), H. foetidus (Stinking hellebore)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist but well-drained; reduce watering once established. Partial to full shade preferred—avoid hot afternoon sun. Rich, humus-laden soil with neutral to slightly alkaline pH. Fertilize in late winter or early spring with balanced fertilizer. Remove old foliage in late winter before flowers emerge. Self-sows readily. Toxic to pets and humans (protoanemonin).

description: Non-woody perennial flowers that die back in winter and regrow from roots in spring, provide long-term garden structure.
commonExamples: Hemerocallis (Daylily), Hosta (Plantain lily), Echinacea (Coneflower), Rudbeckia (Black-eyed Susan), Salvia (Sage)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (weekly deep watering during growing season). Deep watering encourages strong root systems. Mulch around plants to retain moisture and suppress weeds. Full sun to partial shade depending on species. Fertilize in early spring with balanced fertilizer. Deadhead spent flowers to encourage reblooming. Cut back dead foliage in late fall or early spring. Divide every 3-5 years to maintain vigor. Provide long-term garden structure. Research specific species for exact requirements. Herbaceous perennials die back; reduce watering when dormant.

description: Also known as: Coral Bells. Versatile shade-loving perennial grown primarily for its colorful foliage in shades of purple, bronze, lime, peach, and silver. Delicate bell-shaped flowers on wiry stems.
commonExamples: Heuchera 'Palace Purple', H. 'Lime Rickey', H. 'Caramel', H. 'Obsidian' (black foliage), H. villosa 'Autumn Bride'
careTips: Water regularly to keep soil evenly moist; do not let dry out completely. Partial shade to full shade — dark-leaved varieties tolerate more sun. Mulch around crown to keep roots cool. Divide every 3-4 years when crown rises above soil. Cut back spent flower stalks. Fertilize in spring with slow-release fertilizer. Excellent for containers, borders, and woodland gardens. Non-toxic to pets.
