description: Tall, stately biennial to short-lived perennial producing towering spikes of large, saucer-shaped flowers in a wide range of colors from summer into fall.
commonExamples: Alcea rosea (Common hollyhock), A. rosea 'Nigra' (Black hollyhock), A. rosea 'Chater's Double' (Double hollyhock)
careTips: Water at the base when the top inch of soil is dry; avoid overhead watering to reduce rust disease. Full sun and a sheltered position protected from strong winds is ideal, as stems can reach 2-3 meters tall. Well-drained, fertile soil enriched with compost produces the best results. Stake tall varieties to prevent toppling. Watch for hollyhock rust — remove and destroy affected leaves promptly. Sow seeds in summer for blooms the following year. Non-toxic to pets and humans.

description: Also known as: Funkia. Shade-loving perennial foliage plants in the Asparagaceae family, grown for their attractive leaves in various colors and sizes.
commonExamples: Hosta (Plantain lily, Funkia), H. 'Francee', H. 'Patriot', H. 'Blue Angel', H. 'Sum and Substance', miniature and giant varieties
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist (2-3 times per week). Mulch to retain moisture and keep roots cool. Partial to full shade preferred - morning sun is fine but avoid hot afternoon sun. Fertilize in early spring with balanced fertilizer. Divide every 3-5 years in spring or fall. Remove flower stalks after blooming to focus energy on foliage (unless you enjoy the flowers). Watch for slugs and snails which love hostas. Excellent for shade gardens. Herbaceous perennials die back; reduce watering when dormant.

description: Perennial flowering plants in the Iridaceae family with distinctive sword-like leaves and showy flowers, include bearded and beardless types.
commonExamples: Iris germanica (Bearded iris), I. sibirica (Siberian iris), I. ensata (Japanese iris), I. reticulata (Dwarf iris), I. pseudacorus (Yellow flag iris)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist during growth and flowering (spring). Allow to dry slightly after flowering. Many prefer well-drained soil. Full sun essential for best flowering (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize in early spring with low-nitrogen fertilizer. Divide bearded irises every 3-4 years in late summer. Plant rhizomes with top exposed to sun. Remove spent flowers. Cut back foliage in fall. Research specific type (bearded, beardless, bulbous) for exact requirements. Herbaceous perennials die back; reduce watering when dormant.

description: Native perennial with purple flowers; thrives in moist soils; attracts butterflies.
commonExamples: Vernonia noveboracensis
careTips: Water when top 1-2 inches of soil is dry. Full sun preferred; prefers consistently moist soil. Well-draining soil. Fertilize lightly in spring if needed; many prairie natives prefer lean soil. Mildly toxic to pets—may cause irritation.

description: Elegant fall-blooming perennials with simple pink or white flowers on tall, wiry stems, thriving in partial shade where few other plants flower in autumn.
commonExamples: Anemone hupehensis (Japanese anemone), A. x hybrida 'Honorine Jobert', A. x hybrida 'September Charm', A. tomentosa 'Robustissima'
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist during growing season; more drought-tolerant once established. Partial shade preferred—tolerates morning sun but avoid hot afternoon exposure. Rich, moist, well-drained soil. Fertilize in spring with balanced fertilizer. Can spread by underground runners—may need containment. Cut back after frost kills foliage. Mildly toxic to pets (protoanemonin).

description: Also known as: Sweet Joe Pye. Tall native with pink-purple flower clusters; prefers moist to wet soil; butterfly magnet.
commonExamples: Eutrochium purpureum
careTips: Water when top 1-2 inches of soil is dry. Full sun preferred; prefers consistently moist soil. Well-draining soil. Fertilize lightly in spring if needed; many prairie natives prefer lean soil.

description: Bold clusters of flowers in orange, pink, yellow, or red; attracts butterflies; heat-tolerant.
commonExamples: Lantana camara (Common lantana)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun preferred. Fertilize in spring. Mulch to retain moisture. Prune as needed for shape. Toxic to pets. Perennial in frost-free zones (USDA 9-11); grown as annual in cooler climates.

description: Fragrant white bell flowers on arching stems; spreads by rhizomes; classic shade plant.
commonExamples: Convallaria majalis
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist. Partial to full shade. Rich, well-draining soil. Fertilize in spring. Mulch to retain moisture. Divide when crowded. Highly toxic to humans and pets if ingested.

description: Also known as: Garden lupine. Tall spikes of pea-like flowers in blue, purple, pink, yellow, and bicolors; nitrogen-fixing perennial that enriches soil.
commonExamples: Lupinus spp. (Garden lupine)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry; avoid wet winter conditions. Full sun essential. Well-draining, slightly acidic soil. Avoid fertilizer—lupines fix nitrogen. Deadhead spent spikes for possible rebloom. Taproot makes transplanting difficult. Short-lived (3-4 years) but self-seeds. Toxic to pets and humans if ingested.

description: Prairie native with tall stems of yellow flowers; spreads by rhizomes; bird and pollinator favorite.
commonExamples: Helianthus maximiliani
careTips: Water when top 1-2 inches dry; very drought-tolerant once established. Full sun essential. Adapts to most soils including clay. No fertilizer needed. Spreads by rhizomes—may need division every 3-4 years. Tall (6-10 ft); stake or plant with support. Important late-fall pollinator food source.

description: European geranium with blue-violet flowers; long blooming; low maintenance.
commonExamples: Geranium pratense
careTips: Water when top 1-2 inches dry; moderate drought tolerance once established. Full sun to partial shade. Well-draining soil; tolerates clay. Light spring fertilizer. Violet-blue saucer flowers June-August. Cut back after first flush for rebloom. Self-seeds moderately. European meadow wildflower; deer resistant.

description: Salvia with violet-blue flower spikes; long blooming; drought tolerant once established.
commonExamples: Salvia pratensis
careTips: Water when top 1-2 inches dry; moderate drought tolerance. Full sun for best flowering. Well-draining soil; avoid winter wet. Light spring fertilizer optional. Deadhead spent spikes to encourage reblooming through fall. Deer resistant. Aromatic foliage. Excellent hummingbird and bee plant.

description: Native prairie wildflower with distinctive drooping yellow or red-brown petals surrounding a tall central cone.
commonExamples: Ratibida columnifera (Mexican hat, Prairie coneflower, Upright prairie coneflower)
careTips: Very drought-tolerant once established; water sparingly, every 1-2 weeks in dry spells. Full sun essential—at least 6 hours daily. Thrives in poor, well-drained soil; avoid rich or wet conditions. Do not fertilize—excess nutrients reduce flowering. Self-sows freely. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Native fall bloomer with purple daisy flowers; attracts butterflies; prefers moist soil.
commonExamples: Symphyotrichum novae-angliae
careTips: Water when top 1-2 inches of soil is dry. Full sun preferred; prefers consistently moist soil. Well-draining soil. Fertilize lightly in spring if needed; many prairie natives prefer lean soil.

description: Dramatic purple, pink, or white globe-shaped flower heads on tall stems, related to onions and garlic but grown purely for ornamental display.
commonExamples: Allium giganteum (Giant allium), A. 'Globemaster', A. cristophii (Star of Persia), A. 'Purple Sensation'
careTips: Water moderately during growing season; allow soil to dry between waterings. Full sun essential—at least 6 hours daily. Well-drained soil critical; bulbs rot in wet soil. Fertilize in early spring with bulb fertilizer. Allow foliage to die back naturally after flowering. Deer and rodent resistant. Toxic to pets — all Allium species contain compounds that can cause hemolytic anemia in cats and dogs.

description: Also known as: Garden salvia. Long-blooming perennial salvias grown for their showy flower spikes in purple, blue, red, or pink; highly attractive to hummingbirds and butterflies.
commonExamples: Salvia nemorosa (Woodland sage), S. x sylvestris 'May Night' (May Night salvia), S. guaranitica (Anise-scented sage), S. greggii (Autumn sage)
careTips: Water when the top inch of soil is dry; moderately drought-tolerant once established. Full sun (6+ hours) produces the densest flower spikes and strongest growth. Well-drained soil is essential; avoid heavy, wet clay. Cut back spent flower spikes to the next set of leaves to encourage reblooming throughout the season. Shear by one-third after the first flush fades. Divide every 3-4 years in spring. Non-toxic to pets.

description: European wildflower with white petals and yellow centers; naturalizes; drought tolerant.
commonExamples: Leucanthemum vulgare
careTips: Water when top 1-2 inches of soil is dry. Full sun preferred; drought tolerant once established. Well-draining soil. Fertilize lightly in spring if needed; tolerates lean soil; European wildflower. Mildly toxic to pets—may cause GI upset if ingested.

description: Also known as: Pyrethrum. Colorful daisy-like flowers in pink, red, or white with ferny foliage; natural source of pyrethrin insecticide.
commonExamples: Tanacetum coccineum (Pyrethrum)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun to partial shade depending on species. Fertilize in spring. Mulch to retain moisture. Prune as needed for shape. Toxic to pets—contains pyrethrins; keep away from pets.

description: Also known as: Beardtongue. Tubular flowers on upright stems in many colors; native North American perennial, drought-tolerant, attracts hummingbirds.
commonExamples: Penstemon digitalis (Beardtongue)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun to partial shade depending on species. Fertilize in spring. Mulch to retain moisture. Prune as needed for shape. Mildly toxic to pets—may accumulate selenium; keep away from pets.

description: Herbaceous and tree perennials in the Paeoniaceae family with large, fragrant flowers in spring, long-lived garden favorites.
commonExamples: Paeonia lactiflora (Garden peony, Chinese peony), P. suffruticosa (Tree peony), P. officinalis (Common peony), P. tenuifolia (Fernleaf peony)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist during growing season. Well-drained, fertile soil preferred. Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize in early spring with balanced fertilizer. Plant with eyes (buds) 2 inches below soil surface. Support heavy blooms with stakes. Cut back foliage in fall. Long-lived - can thrive for decades. Large, fragrant flowers. Herbaceous perennials die back; reduce watering when dormant. Ants on buds are normal and harmless—they feed on bud nectar.

description: Also known as: Garden phlox. Fragrant clusters of flowers in summer in many colors; cottage garden staple. Needs good air circulation to prevent mildew.
commonExamples: Phlox paniculata (Garden phlox)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun to partial shade depending on species. Fertilize in spring. Mulch to retain moisture. Prune as needed for shape. Mildly toxic to pets—may cause GI upset if ingested. Choose mildew-resistant cultivars. Space for air circulation. Avoid overhead watering.

description: Prairie native with drooping yellow petals around tall cone; drought tolerant; Ratibida.
commonExamples: Ratibida pinnata
careTips: Water when top 1-2 inches dry; very drought-tolerant once established. Full sun. Lean, well-draining soil preferred. No fertilizer needed. Distinctive columnar seed head (like a sombrero). Self-seeds readily. Deadhead to prevent excessive spreading or leave for winter bird food.

description: Tall prairie native with large heart-shaped leaves and yellow flowers; deep taproot.
commonExamples: Silphium terebinthinaceum
careTips: Water when top 2 inches dry; very drought-tolerant once established via deep taproot. Full sun. Lean to average soil. No fertilizer. Large basal leaves (up to 18 inches) with tall, mostly leafless flower stalks to 8 ft. Slow to establish from seed but extremely long-lived.

description: Prairie native with yucca-like leaves and spherical white flower clusters; drought tolerant.
commonExamples: Eryngium yuccifolium
careTips: Water when top 1-2 inches dry; drought-tolerant once established. Full sun. Well-draining, lean soil. No fertilizer. Yucca-like spiny leaves are unusual for a prairie plant (actually in the carrot family). Excellent dried flower. Important pollinator plant; attracts diverse native bees.

description: Legume with pink flower heads; nitrogen-fixing; used as cover crop and forage.
commonExamples: Trifolium pratense
careTips: Water when top 1-2 inches dry; moderate drought tolerance. Full sun to partial shade. Adapts to most soils. No fertilizer needed—fixes atmospheric nitrogen and enriches soil. Magenta flower heads attract bees and butterflies. Edible flowers for tea and salads. Short-lived perennial; self-seeds freely. European meadow native.

description: Herbaceous perennials and annuals in the Lamiaceae family with spikes of colorful flowers, many are drought-tolerant.
commonExamples: Salvia officinalis (Common sage, Garden sage), S. nemorosa (Woodland sage), S. farinacea (Mealycup sage), S. splendens (Scarlet sage)
careTips: Water deeply but infrequently once established (every 1-2 weeks). Drought tolerant. Well-drained soil essential. Full sun preferred. Fertilize sparingly in spring. Deadhead spent flowers to encourage reblooming. Cut back in late fall or early spring. Many species are drought-tolerant. Spikes of colorful flowers. Attract hummingbirds and butterflies. Herbaceous perennials die back; reduce watering when dormant.

description: Also known as: Pincushion flower. Charming perennial with delicate, domed flower heads studded with pin-like stamens in lavender, blue, pink, white, and deep burgundy; a pollinator magnet blooming from early summer to frost.
commonExamples: Scabiosa columbaria 'Butterfly Blue' (Pincushion flower), S. caucasica 'Fama Deep Blue', S. atropurpurea (Sweet scabious, annual), S. columbaria 'Pink Mist'
careTips: Water regularly to keep soil evenly moist during establishment; once established, moderately drought tolerant. Full sun (6+ hours) is essential for prolific flowering. Well-drained, neutral to slightly alkaline soil is ideal — struggles in heavy, acidic clay. Deadhead spent flowers consistently to encourage continuous blooming throughout the season. Good air circulation prevents crown rot, which is the main cause of death — avoid mulching directly against the crown. Divide every 3-4 years in spring to maintain vigor. Attracts butterflies and bees prolifically. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Also known as: Stonecrop, Autumn Joy. Hardy succulent perennials with fleshy leaves and clusters of star-shaped flowers. Includes tall upright types and low-growing groundcovers. Extremely drought tolerant.
commonExamples: Hylotelephium 'Autumn Joy' (syn. Sedum 'Autumn Joy'), H. spectabile (Showy stonecrop), Sedum spurium (Dragon's blood), S. kamtschaticum, S. reflexum (Blue spruce stonecrop)
careTips: Water deeply but infrequently once established (every 2-3 weeks). Very drought tolerant. Well-drained soil essential. Full sun preferred. Fertilize sparingly in spring. Deadhead spent flowers or leave for winter interest. Cut back in late winter. Drought-tolerant groundcovers. Clusters of star-shaped flowers. Attract butterflies. Herbaceous perennials die back; reduce watering when dormant.

description: Perennial plants adapted to woodland and shade conditions, often prefer rich organic soil.
commonExamples: Hosta (Plantain lily), Astilbe (False spirea), Helleborus (Lenten rose, Hellebore), Dicentra (Bleeding heart), Pulmonaria (Lungwort)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (weekly watering). Many prefer consistent moisture but well-drained soil. Avoid waterlogged conditions. Partial to full shade preferred. Rich organic soil preferred - amend with compost. Fertilize in early spring with balanced fertilizer. Mulch to retain moisture. Deadhead spent flowers. Divide every 3-5 years. Adapted to woodland conditions. Research specific species for exact requirements. Herbaceous perennials die back; reduce watering when dormant.

description: Classic white daisy-like flowers with golden yellow centers; reliable, long-blooming garden perennial.
commonExamples: Leucanthemum × superbum
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun to partial shade depending on species. Fertilize in spring. Mulch to retain moisture. Prune as needed for shape. Mildly toxic to pets—may cause GI upset or skin irritation if ingested.

description: Native aster with blue-purple flowers in fall; smooth leaves; drought tolerant.
commonExamples: Symphyotrichum laeve
careTips: Water when top 1-2 inches dry; drought-tolerant once established. Full sun to light shade. Adapts to most soils including clay. Minimal fertilizer. Pinch stems in June for bushier growth and more flowers. Critical late-season nectar source for monarchs and native bees.

description: Monarch host plant with pink flowers; prefers moist to wet soil; native to wetlands.
commonExamples: Asclepias incarnata
careTips: Water when top 1-2 inches of soil is dry. Full sun preferred; tolerates moist soil. Well-draining to moist soil. Fertilize lightly in spring if needed. Toxic to pets.

description: Biennial to short-lived perennial in the Dianthus family, producing dense, flat-topped clusters of fragrant flowers in red, pink, white, and bicolor patterns.
commonExamples: Dianthus barbatus (Sweet William), D. barbatus 'Holborn Glory' (Auricula-eyed), D. barbatus 'Nigrescens' (Sooty Sweet William)
careTips: Water at the base when the top inch of soil is dry; avoid wetting foliage to prevent fungal issues. Full sun (6+ hours) produces the best blooms. Well-drained, slightly alkaline soil is ideal. Deadhead spent flowers to extend blooming and prevent self-seeding if unwanted. Sow seeds in summer for blooms the following spring. Fertilize in spring with a balanced slow-release fertilizer. Mildly toxic if ingested in large quantities.

description: Clusters of small flowers in purple, pink, or white on wiry stems; heat-tolerant perennial that attracts butterflies.
commonExamples: Verbena bonariensis, Glandularia spp.
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry; moderate drought tolerance once established. Full sun essential—at least 8 hours. Well-draining soil; avoid wet conditions. Fertilize every 2-3 weeks during bloom season. Deadhead regularly for continuous flowering spring through frost. Pinch tips for bushier growth. Attracts butterflies. Mildly toxic to pets.

description: European wildflower with blue coiled flower spikes; biennial or short-lived perennial; full sun.
commonExamples: Echium vulgare
careTips: Water when top 1-2 inches of soil is dry. Full sun preferred; drought tolerant once established. Well-draining soil. Fertilize lightly in spring if needed; tolerates lean soil; European wildflower. Toxic to pets.

description: Native bee balm with lavender flowers; aromatic foliage; drought tolerant; attracts pollinators.
commonExamples: Monarda fistulosa
careTips: Water when top 1-2 inches dry; drought-tolerant once established. Full sun to partial shade. Well-draining soil; avoid wet conditions. No fertilizer needed. Aromatic leaves make excellent tea (related to bee balm). Spreads by runners—divide every 3 years. Powerhouse pollinator plant.

description: Native Baptisia with blue flowers; nitrogen-fixing; drought tolerant; long-lived.
commonExamples: Baptisia australis
careTips: Water when top 1-2 inches of soil is dry. Full sun preferred; drought tolerant once established. Well-draining soil. Fertilize lightly in spring if needed; many prairie natives prefer lean soil. Mildly toxic to pets—may cause GI upset if ingested.

description: Also known as: Milfoil. Hardy perennial with flat-topped flower clusters in white, yellow, pink, or red above ferny, aromatic foliage; drought-tolerant and pollinator-friendly.
commonExamples: Achillea millefolium (Common yarrow), A. 'Moonshine' (Moonshine yarrow), A. 'Paprika' (Paprika yarrow), A. filipendulina (Fernleaf yarrow)
careTips: Water when the top inch of soil is dry; once established, yarrow is very drought-tolerant and prefers lean, dry conditions. Full sun (6+ hours) is essential — shaded plants become floppy and produce fewer flowers. Well-drained, poor to average soil is ideal; rich soil causes weak stems and excessive spreading. Deadhead spent clusters to encourage reblooming. Divide clumps every 3-4 years to maintain vigor. Toxic to pets — contains thujone and other irritants.

description: Yellow-petaled Echinacea species native to the Ozarks; drought tolerant prairie wildflower.
commonExamples: Echinacea paradoxa
careTips: Water when top 1-2 inches dry; drought-tolerant once established. Full sun essential. Well-draining, lean soil. No fertilizer needed. Drooping yellow petals with prominent brown cone. Self-seeds freely. Leave seed heads for winter bird food. Long bloom period (July-September).

description: Also known as: Sweet alyssum. Low mounds of tiny white, pink, or purple flowers with honey fragrance; ideal for edges and containers.
commonExamples: Lobularia maritima (Sweet alyssum)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun preferred; tolerates light shade. Well-draining soil. Fertilize every 2-3 weeks with balanced fertilizer. Deadhead to prolong bloom. Cool-season annual—plant in early spring or fall.

description: Also known as: Summer snapdragon. Upright spikes of snapdragon-like flowers in purple, pink, or white; heat-tolerant and low-maintenance.
commonExamples: Angelonia angustifolia (Summer snapdragon)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun essential. Heat and drought tolerant once established. Fertilize every 2-3 weeks. No deadheading needed. Thrives in hot, humid summers.

description: Trailing plant with small white, pink, or blue flowers; ideal for hanging baskets and container edges.
commonExamples: Sutera cordata (Bacopa)
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist; avoid drying out. Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize every 2 weeks with bloom fertilizer. Pinch back to encourage bushiness. Heat-tolerant. Perfect for spillover in containers.

description: Annual and perennial flowers in the Begoniaceae family with colorful blooms and attractive foliage, shade-tolerant.
commonExamples: Begonia × semperflorens-cultorum (Wax begonia), B. × tuberhybrida (Tuberous begonia), B. boliviensis (Bolivian begonia), B. rex (Rex begonia)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist but not waterlogged (2-3 times per week). Well-drained soil essential. Partial shade to full shade preferred - avoid direct sun. Fertilize every 2-3 weeks with balanced fertilizer. Deadhead spent flowers. Mulch to retain moisture. Colorful blooms and attractive foliage. Shade-tolerant. Research specific type for exact requirements. Annual; grown for one season; no winter watering needed.

description: Compact begonia with waxy green or bronze leaves and clusters of flowers in white, pink, or red; shade-tolerant.
commonExamples: Begonia semperflorens (Wax begonia)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist. Partial shade to full shade preferred; avoid hot afternoon sun. Fertilize every 2 weeks. Deadhead to encourage blooms. Mildly toxic to pets. Ideal for shady borders and containers.

description: Miniature petunia-like flowers in many colors; prolific bloomer for containers and hanging baskets.
commonExamples: Calibrachoa × hybrida (Million bells)
careTips: Water regularly; keep soil consistently moist. Full sun preferred. Fertilize every 2 weeks with bloom fertilizer. Self-cleaning—no deadheading needed. Deadhead or shear if leggy. Thrives in heat.

description: Also known as: Cockscomb. Bold tropical annual with flower heads in distinctive plume, crest, or brain-like comb shapes; colors include brilliant red, orange, yellow, pink, and purple.
commonExamples: Celosia argentea var. cristata (Crested cockscomb), C. argentea var. plumosa (Plumed celosia), C. spicata (Wheat celosia)
careTips: Water when the top inch of soil is dry; consistent moisture promotes best blooming but avoid waterlogged soil. Full sun (6+ hours) is essential for vibrant color and sturdy growth. Well-drained, fertile soil enriched with compost is ideal. Fertilize every 2-3 weeks with balanced liquid fertilizer. Deadhead to encourage branching and more blooms. Heat-loving; plant after all frost danger has passed. Excellent for cutting and dried flower arrangements. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Also known as: Spider flower. Tall, dramatic annual with spidery flower clusters in pink, purple, or white atop long stems, self-sowing freely for return displays.
commonExamples: Cleome hassleriana (Spider flower), C. hassleriana 'Violet Queen', C. hassleriana 'White Queen', C. 'Senorita Rosalita'
careTips: Water regularly but allow soil to dry slightly between waterings; moderately drought-tolerant once established. Full sun preferred; tolerates light shade. Average, well-drained soil. Fertilize monthly with balanced fertilizer. Deadhead to extend blooming or leave some for self-sowing. Heat and humidity tolerant. Thorny stems—handle with gloves. Annual; grown for one season; no winter watering needed. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Annual flowers that prefer cooler temperatures, often planted in fall or early spring for winter/spring blooms.
commonExamples: Viola × wittrockiana (Pansy), Violas (Viola, Johnny-jump-up), Calendula (Pot marigold), Primula (Primrose), Dianthus (Sweet William)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Water at base to avoid wetting flowers and leaves. Consistent moisture important during flowering period. Partial sun to full sun depending on species. Prefer cooler temperatures (60-70°F) - plant in fall or early spring. Fertilize every 2 weeks with balanced fertilizer. Deadhead spent flowers to encourage continuous blooms. Mulch to retain moisture. Annual - replant each season.

description: Also known as: Garden cosmos. Annual flowers in the Asteraceae family with delicate, daisy-like blooms in shades of pink, white, and purple, easy to grow.
commonExamples: Cosmos bipinnatus (Garden cosmos, Mexican aster), C. sulphureus (Yellow cosmos, Orange cosmos), C. atrosanguineus (Chocolate cosmos)
careTips: Water regularly but allow to dry between waterings (2-3 times per week). Drought tolerant once established. Well-drained soil preferred. Full sun essential. Fertilize sparingly - too much fertilizer reduces blooms. Deadhead spent flowers to encourage continuous blooms. Self-seeds readily. Delicate, daisy-like blooms. Attract butterflies and bees. Annual; grown for one season; no winter watering needed.

description: Seed-grown dahlia varieties treated as annuals, producing colorful single or semi-double flowers all summer without the need to store tubers over winter.
commonExamples: Dahlia pinnata 'Bishop's Children', D. 'Figaro', D. 'Harlequin', D. 'Redskin'
careTips: Water deeply 2-3 times per week; consistent moisture important during flowering. Full sun essential—at least 6 hours daily. Rich, well-drained soil. Fertilize every 2-3 weeks with balanced fertilizer during blooming. Deadhead spent flowers to encourage continuous blooms. Pinch growing tips when young for bushier plants. Frost-sensitive—plant after last frost. Mildly toxic to pets.

description: Fringed flowers in pink, red, or white with spicy fragrance; compact form for borders and containers.
commonExamples: Dianthus chinensis (China pink)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun preferred. Well-draining, slightly alkaline soil. Fertilize every 2-3 weeks. Deadhead to prolong bloom. Cool-season performer.

description: Also known as: Silver ragwort. Silver-foliage annual (perennial in mild climates) grown for its deeply lobed, felt-textured, silvery-white leaves that provide contrast in borders and containers.
commonExamples: Jacobaea maritima (Dusty miller, Silver ragwort), Centaurea cineraria (Dusty miller), Lychnis coronaria (Rose campion, also called Dusty miller)
careTips: Water when the top inch of soil is dry; drought-tolerant once established. Full sun intensifies the silver coloring; tolerates part shade but becomes leggier. Well-drained soil is essential — susceptible to root rot in wet conditions. Pinch off small yellow flower buds to maintain foliage form and prevent the plant from declining after bloom. Low fertilizer needs; feed once in spring. Mildly toxic if ingested.

description: Classic blue (or pink, white) annual flowers with thistle-like blooms; bee-friendly and easy from seed.
commonExamples: Centaurea cyanus
careTips: Water when top 1-2 inches of soil is dry. Full sun preferred; drought tolerant once established. Well-draining soil. Fertilize lightly or not at all—prefers lean soil. Direct-sow in spring. Self-seeds.

description: Also known as: Zonal geranium. Popular annual and perennial flowering plants, include zonal geraniums (Pelargonium) and true geraniums (hardy geraniums).
commonExamples: Pelargonium × hortorum (Zonal geranium), P. peltatum (Ivy geranium), Geranium (Hardy geranium, Cranesbill), scented-leaf varieties
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist but well-drained (2-3 times per week). Allow to dry slightly between waterings. Full sun preferred for best flowering. Fertilize every 2 weeks with high-phosphorus fertilizer. Deadhead regularly to encourage continuous blooming. Pinch back when young to encourage bushiness. Zonal geraniums are annuals in most climates; hardy geraniums are perennials. Research type (annual Pelargonium vs perennial Geranium) for exact requirements. Zonal geraniums (Pelargonium) are treated as annuals in most climates; hardy geraniums (Geranium) are cold-hardy perennials.

description: Also known as: Bachelor's button (not to be confused with Centaurea). Heat-loving annual producing round, clover-like flower heads in magenta, purple, white, pink, and red that hold their color when dried.
commonExamples: Gomphrena globosa (Globe amaranth), G. globosa 'Fireworks' (Fireworks globe amaranth), G. haageana 'Strawberry Fields' (Strawberry Fields), G. pulchella (Dwarf globe amaranth)
careTips: Water when the top inch of soil is dry; drought-tolerant once established. Full sun is essential — at least 6 hours for best performance. Average, well-drained soil is fine; thrives in heat and humidity where other annuals struggle. Minimal fertilizer needed; too much nitrogen produces foliage at the expense of flowers. Deadhead for continuous bloom or leave flowers for dried arrangements. Excellent heat tolerance makes it ideal for southern gardens. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Also known as: Busy Lizzie. Shade-loving annual flowering plants in the Balsaminaceae family with colorful blooms, excellent for shady areas.
commonExamples: Impatiens walleriana (Busy Lizzie, Garden impatiens), I. balsamina (Garden balsam), I. hawkeri (New Guinea impatiens), double-flowered varieties
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist (2-3 times per week). Don't allow to dry out — wilting damages plants. Partial to full shade preferred; avoid hot afternoon sun. Bright indirect light is ideal. Fertilize every 2 weeks with balanced fertilizer. Deadhead regularly to encourage continuous blooming. Pinch back when young to encourage bushiness. Excellent for shady gardens and containers. Plant after last frost. Watch for downy mildew — choose resistant varieties if this is a problem in your area. Annual; grown for one season; no winter watering needed. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Cool-season annual with tall spikes of delphinium-like flowers in blue, purple, pink, or white, a cottage garden favorite and excellent cut flower.
commonExamples: Consolida ajacis (Larkspur, Rocket larkspur), C. regalis (Forking larkspur)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist; does not tolerate drought. Full sun preferred in cool climates; afternoon shade in hot areas. Rich, well-drained soil. Fertilize at planting and again mid-season. Direct sow in fall or early spring—dislikes transplanting. Excellent cut flower. Prefers cool weather; declines in heat. Toxic to pets and humans (alkaloids similar to delphinium).

description: Also known as: Eustoma. Elegant annual or short-lived perennial producing ruffled, rose-like blooms in white, pink, purple, and bicolor; prized as a premium cut flower.
commonExamples: Eustoma grandiflorum (Lisianthus, Texas bluebell), E. grandiflorum 'ABC' series, E. grandiflorum 'Echo' series
careTips: Water at the base when the top inch of soil feels dry; keep soil evenly moist but never waterlogged, as lisianthus is prone to crown rot. Full sun to light afternoon shade is ideal. Neutral to slightly alkaline, well-drained soil produces the best results. Fertilize every 2 weeks during bloom with a phosphorus-rich fertilizer. Stake tall varieties to support the heavy blooms. Slow to start from seed (requires 12-16 weeks); transplants are recommended for home gardens. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Mounding or trailing plant with masses of small blue, white, or pink flowers; cools down in heat but rebounds in fall.
commonExamples: Lobelia erinus (Edging lobelia)
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist; avoid drying out. Partial shade in hot climates; full sun in cool regions. Fertilize every 2 weeks. Shear back midsummer if leggy for fall rebloom. Cool-season performer. Toxic to pets.

description: Large, bold flowers in yellow or orange; pest-repellent and excellent for cutting.
commonExamples: Tagetes erecta
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun essential. Well-draining soil. Fertilize every 2-3 weeks. Deadhead to encourage blooms. Tall varieties may need staking. Repels pests.

description: Hardy annual flowering plants in the Asteraceae family with bright yellow, orange, or red flowers, excellent for pest control.
commonExamples: Tagetes (Marigold), T. patula (French marigold), T. erecta (African marigold), T. tenuifolia (Signet marigold), Calendula (Pot marigold)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Allow to dry slightly between waterings. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize monthly with balanced fertilizer. Deadhead regularly to encourage continuous blooming. Pinch back when young to encourage bushiness. Excellent companion plants - repel nematodes and some pests. Easy to grow from seed. Plant after last frost. Research variety type for size and bloom characteristics. Annual; grown for one season; no winter watering needed.

description: Also known as: Garden nasturtium. Annual and perennial flowers in the Tropaeolaceae family with edible flowers and leaves, trailing or climbing habit.
commonExamples: Tropaeolum majus (Garden nasturtium, Indian cress), T. minus (Dwarf nasturtium), T. peregrinum (Canary creeper)
careTips: Water regularly but allow to dry between waterings (2-3 times per week). Prefer slightly dry conditions - too much water reduces flowering. Well-drained soil preferred. Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize sparingly - rich soil reduces blooms. Edible flowers and leaves with peppery flavor. Trailing or climbing habit. Attract beneficial insects. Annual; grown for one season; no winter watering needed.

description: Also known as: Nagoya ornamental kale. Cool-season annual grown for its striking rosettes of ruffled or fringed leaves in purple, pink, white, and cream; color intensifies as temperatures drop below 55°F (13°C).
commonExamples: Brassica oleracea 'Nagoya' (Nagoya ornamental kale), B. oleracea 'Pigeon' series, B. oleracea 'Crane' series (tall-stemmed), B. oleracea 'Peacock' (feathered leaf type)
careTips: Water when the top inch of soil is dry; avoid overhead watering which can promote fungal diseases. Full sun (6+ hours) produces the most vivid coloration. Average, well-drained soil is fine; avoid over-fertilizing which promotes leggy green growth instead of colorful foliage. Plant in early fall for best display — colors develop only after sustained cool temperatures below 13°C. Technically edible but bred for looks, not flavor. Tolerates light frost and often looks best after a few cold snaps. Remove by spring when it bolts and becomes unsightly. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Cold-tolerant flowers with face-like markings in many colors; plant in fall or early spring.
commonExamples: Viola × wittrockiana (Pansy)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist. Full sun in cool weather; partial shade when hot. Fertilize every 2 weeks. Deadhead to prolong bloom. Cool-season annual—plant in fall or early spring for best results.

description: Star-shaped flower clusters in red, pink, or white; butterfly magnet, heat-loving.
commonExamples: Pentas lanceolata (Egyptian star cluster)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun preferred. Fertilize every 2-3 weeks. Deadhead to encourage rebloom. Heat and humidity tolerant. Perennial in frost-free zones; grow as annual elsewhere.

description: Large, trumpet-shaped flowers in many colors; showy but sensitive to rain and heat.
commonExamples: Petunia × hybrida
careTips: Water regularly; keep soil evenly moist. Full sun essential. Fertilize every 2 weeks with bloom fertilizer. Deadhead or shear back midsummer. Flowers may wilt in heavy rain.

description: Also known as: Garden petunia. Popular annual flowering plants in the Solanaceae family with trumpet-shaped flowers, excellent for containers and hanging baskets.
commonExamples: Petunia × hybrida (Garden petunia), grandiflora, multiflora, milliflora, and spreading/trailing varieties, P. integrifolia (Wild petunia)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Water at base to avoid wetting flowers. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize every 2 weeks with high-phosphorus fertilizer to encourage flowering. Deadhead regularly or shear back by one-third mid-season to encourage reblooming. Pinch back when young to encourage bushiness. Excellent for containers, hanging baskets, and borders. Plant after last frost. Research variety type for growth habit (upright vs trailing). Annual; grown for one season; no winter watering needed.

description: Succulent-like leaves with bright flowers in many colors; thrives in hot, dry, poor soil.
commonExamples: Portulaca grandiflora
careTips: Water when soil is dry; avoid overwatering. Full sun essential. Sandy, well-draining soil preferred. Fertilize sparingly. Drought tolerant. Self-seeds. Ideal for containers and rock gardens.

description: Spikes of dragon-mouth flowers in many colors; cool-season annual, excellent for cutting.
commonExamples: Antirrhinum majus (Common snapdragon)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist. Full sun in cool weather; partial shade when hot. Fertilize every 2 weeks. Deadhead to prolong bloom. Cool-season performer—plant in fall or early spring. Stake tall varieties.

description: Also known as: Wavyleaf statice. Papery, brightly colored flower clusters on wiry stems; a classic everlasting flower prized for fresh and dried arrangements.
commonExamples: Limonium sinuatum (Wavyleaf statice), L. perezii (Perez's sea lavender), L. latifolium (Broad-leaved statice)
careTips: Water sparingly once established; drought-tolerant and sensitive to overwatering. Full sun is essential for strong stems and vibrant flower color. Sandy, well-draining soil mimicking its coastal origins is ideal. Fertilize lightly once or twice during the growing season. Harvest for drying when most florets in a cluster have opened. Excellent salt tolerance; suitable for coastal gardens. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Also known as: Common stock. Sweetly fragrant cool-season annual or biennial with dense spikes of double or single flowers in white, pink, purple, red, and cream; prized for its intoxicating clove-like scent.
commonExamples: Matthiola incana (Common stock), M. incana 'Cinderella' series, M. incana 'Iron' series (heat-tolerant), M. longipetala (Night-scented stock)
careTips: Water regularly to keep soil evenly moist; inconsistent watering causes premature bolting. Full sun to partial shade; prefers cool temperatures and performs poorly above 25°C. Rich, well-drained, neutral to slightly alkaline soil is ideal. Fertilize every 2-3 weeks with balanced liquid fertilizer during bloom. Plant in early spring or fall for best results; a true cool-season flower that thrives when nights are cool. Deadhead spent blooms to prolong flowering. Night-scented stock (M. longipetala) is a separate species with smaller flowers but an incredible evening fragrance. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Annual and perennial flowers in the Asteraceae family with large, cheerful yellow blooms that follow the sun.
commonExamples: Helianthus annuus (Common sunflower), H. debilis (Beach sunflower), H. maximiliani (Maximilian sunflower), dwarf varieties
careTips: Water deeply 2-3 times per week during growing season. Consistent moisture important during flowering. Well-drained soil preferred. Full sun essential. Fertilize every 2-3 weeks with balanced fertilizer. Stake tall varieties. Deadhead to encourage side blooms or leave for birds. Large, cheerful yellow blooms. Attract birds and bees. Annual; grown for one season; no winter watering needed.

description: Beloved annual climbing flower prized for its fragrant, ruffled blooms in a wide range of pastel colors. A cottage garden classic.
commonExamples: Lathyrus odoratus (Sweet pea), 'Spencer' varieties (large, ruffled), 'Old Spice' (heirloom mix), 'Cupani' (original bicolor)
careTips: Water regularly — keep soil consistently moist but not waterlogged. Full sun with cool roots. Plant early in spring — prefers cool weather and fades in heat. Provide support for climbing. Deadhead spent flowers to prolong blooming. Seeds are toxic if ingested.

description: Trailing foliage plant in lime, purple, or bronze; grown for leaves, not tubers; fast-growing.
commonExamples: Ipomoea batatas (Ornamental sweet potato)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize every 2-3 weeks. Prune to control size; very vigorous. Generally considered non-toxic to pets (ASPCA). Ideal for containers and baskets as spillover.

description: Clusters of small flowers in purple, pink, red, or white; heat-tolerant, butterfly-friendly.
commonExamples: Verbena × hybrida
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun essential. Well-draining soil. Fertilize every 2-3 weeks. Deadhead to encourage rebloom. Drought tolerant once established. Trailing or mounding habits.

description: Also known as: Johnny-jump-up. Small pansy-like flowers with distinctive markings; Johnny-jump-up and violas are cold-tolerant.
commonExamples: Viola tricolor (Johnny-jump-up)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist. Full sun in cool weather; partial shade when hot. Fertilize every 2 weeks. Deadhead to prolong bloom. Cool-season annual. Smaller than pansies but more prolific.

description: Annual flowers that thrive in summer heat, provide continuous blooms throughout warm season.
commonExamples: Petunia (Petunia), Tagetes (Marigold, French marigold, African marigold), Zinnia (Zinnia), Impatiens (Busy Lizzie, prefer partial shade), Portulaca (Moss rose)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (daily watering may be needed in hot weather). Water at base to avoid wetting flowers which can cause disease. Consistent moisture prevents wilting. Full sun to partial shade depending on species. Thrive in summer heat. Fertilize every 2 weeks with balanced fertilizer. Deadhead spent flowers to encourage continuous blooms. Mulch to retain moisture. Annual - replant each season. Provide continuous blooms throughout warm season.

description: Also known as: Youth-and-old-age. Annual flowers in the Asteraceae family with bright, daisy-like blooms in many colors, easy to grow from seed.
commonExamples: Zinnia elegans (Common zinnia), Z. haageana (Mexican zinnia), Z. angustifolia (Narrow-leaf zinnia), Z. 'Profusion' (compact hybrid), Z. 'Benary's Giant'
careTips: Water at base regularly (2-3 times per week). Avoid wetting leaves to prevent powdery mildew. Well-drained soil preferred. Full sun essential. Fertilize every 2-3 weeks with balanced fertilizer. Deadhead spent flowers to encourage continuous blooms. Easy to grow from seed. Bright, daisy-like blooms in many colors. Attract butterflies. Annual; grown for one season; no winter watering needed.

description: Deciduous vine with three-lobed leaves that turn brilliant red in fall; clings to walls via adhesive pads.
commonExamples: Parthenocissus tricuspidata
careTips: Water regularly during establishment. Full sun to partial shade. Tolerates most soils. Fertilize in spring. Prune to control growth—can be aggressive. Spectacular fall color. Toxic to pets. Remove from masonry if concerned about damage.

description: Vigorous tropical vine with brilliant papery bracts in magenta, purple, red, orange, white, or pink that surround tiny true flowers, thriving in hot, dry climates.
commonExamples: Bougainvillea glabra (Lesser bougainvillea), B. spectabilis (Great bougainvillea), B. 'Barbara Karst', B. 'San Diego Red'
careTips: Allow soil to dry between waterings; drought stress actually promotes more prolific blooming. Full sun essential—at least 6 hours of direct sun for best color. Well-drained soil critical; does not tolerate wet feet. Fertilize with high-phosphorus fertilizer during growing season. Prune after flowering to shape. Frost-sensitive—protect below 5°C. Thorny—handle with gloves. Mildly toxic to pets.

description: Evergreen vine with fragrant yellow trumpet flowers in early spring; state flower of South Carolina.
commonExamples: Gelsemium sempervirens
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun to partial shade. Well-draining soil. Fertilize in spring after bloom. Prune after flowering. Highly toxic—all parts. Hummingbird attractant.

description: Climbing perennials in the Ranunculaceae family with large, showy flowers, require support and specific pruning.
commonExamples: Clematis × jackmanii (Jackman clematis), C. terniflora (Sweet autumn clematis), C. montana (Anemone clematis), C. viticella (Italian clematis)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist, especially during flowering. Prefer cool roots and sunny tops - mulch around base. Well-drained soil preferred. Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize in spring with balanced fertilizer. Prune according to type - some bloom on new growth, others on old wood. Provide support for climbing. Large, showy flowers. Research specific type for exact pruning requirements. Deciduous varieties: reduce watering when dormant in winter. Pruning varies by group: Group 1 (spring bloomers) minimal pruning; Group 2 (repeat bloomers) light pruning after first flush; Group 3 (summer/fall bloomers) hard prune in late winter.

description: Plants that climb using tendrils, twining stems, or aerial roots, require support structures like trellises or fences.
commonExamples: Jasminum (Jasmine, Star jasmine), Clematis (Clematis, Old man's beard), Lonicera (Honeysuckle), Wisteria, Parthenocissus (Virginia creeper)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (weekly deep watering). Water at base to avoid wetting leaves. Mulch around base to retain moisture especially for root zones. Full sun to partial shade depending on species. Provide support structures (trellises, fences, arbors) for climbing. Fertilize monthly during growing season. Prune according to species - some bloom on new growth, others on old wood. Research specific species for exact requirements. Evergreen; reduce watering in winter when growth slows.

description: Deciduous vine with lacecap flowers and aerial roots; slow to establish but vigorous once rooted.
commonExamples: Hydrangea anomala subsp. petiolaris
careTips: Keep soil moist, especially when establishing. Partial shade preferred; tolerates full shade. Rich, well-draining soil. Fertilize in spring. Prune after flowering—blooms on old wood. Patient—may take 3–5 years to take off.

description: Roses with long canes that need support; repeat-blooming or once-blooming depending on cultivar.
commonExamples: Rosa spp. (Climbing cultivars)
careTips: Water deeply 1–2 times per week. Full sun essential (6+ hours). Fertilize every 2–3 weeks during bloom. Prune after flowering—most bloom on old wood. Provide strong trellis or arbor. Mulch to retain moisture.

description: Evergreen to semi-evergreen vine with orange-red trumpet flowers in spring; hummingbird magnet.
commonExamples: Bignonia capreolata
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun to partial shade. Tolerates various soils. Fertilize in spring. Prune after flowering to control size. Fast-growing once established. Drought tolerant.

description: Climbing and shrubby plants in the Caprifoliaceae family with fragrant, tubular flowers, some species can be invasive.
commonExamples: Lonicera japonica (Japanese honeysuckle), L. sempervirens (Trumpet honeysuckle, Coral honeysuckle), L. periclymenum (European honeysuckle), L. × brownii (Brown's honeysuckle)
careTips: Water regularly during establishment, then reduce to weekly. Drought tolerant once established. Well-drained soil preferred. Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize in spring with balanced fertilizer. Prune after flowering to control growth. Provide support for climbing varieties. Fragrant, tubular flowers. Attract hummingbirds. Some species can be invasive - check local regulations. Evergreen; reduce watering in winter when growth slows.

description: Evergreen climbing and groundcover plants in the Araliaceae family, can be invasive, excellent for covering walls and ground.
commonExamples: Hedera helix (English ivy), H. hibernica (Atlantic ivy)
careTips: Water regularly during establishment (first year), then reduce to weekly. Drought tolerant once established. Well-drained soil preferred. Full sun to full shade depending on species. Fertilize in spring with balanced fertilizer. Prune to control growth - can be invasive. Excellent for covering walls and ground. Evergreen foliage. Research specific species for exact requirements. Evergreen; reduce watering in winter when growth slows.

description: Vigorous, long-lived climbing vine famous for its cascading clusters of fragrant purple, blue, pink, or white flowers in spring. Iconic in Japanese gardens, particularly the famous wisteria tunnels.
commonExamples: Wisteria floribunda (Japanese wisteria), 'Royal Purple', 'Macrobotrys' (extra-long racemes), 'Alba' (white flowers)
careTips: Water regularly when young; drought tolerant once established. Full sun essential for best flowering. Very vigorous grower — requires strong support structure (arbor, pergola). Prune twice yearly (summer and winter) to control growth and encourage flowering. May take 3-5 years to bloom. Seeds and pods are toxic.

description: Fast-growing annual and perennial vines in the Convolvulaceae family with trumpet-shaped flowers that open in morning.
commonExamples: Ipomoea purpurea (Common morning glory), I. tricolor (Heavenly blue morning glory), I. alba (Moonflower), I. quamoclit (Cypress vine)
careTips: Water regularly (2-3 times per week). Keep consistently moist during flowering. Well-drained soil preferred. Full sun essential. Fertilize every 2-3 weeks with balanced fertilizer. Provide support for climbing. Deadhead to prevent self-seeding if desired. Fast-growing vines. Trumpet-shaped flowers open in morning. Can be invasive - check local regulations. Annual; grown for one season; no winter watering needed.

description: Exotic vines with intricate purple, blue, or white flowers; some species produce edible passion fruit.
commonExamples: Passiflora caerulea (Blue passion flower)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun preferred. Well-draining soil. Fertilize every 2 weeks during growth. Prune in late winter. Provide support. Passiflora edulis is the edible species. Mildly toxic—unripe fruit and leaves.

description: Also known as: Confederate jasmine. Evergreen twining vine with intensely fragrant, pinwheel-shaped white flowers in spring and summer, excellent as groundcover or wall climber.
commonExamples: Trachelospermum jasminoides (Star jasmine, Confederate jasmine), T. asiaticum (Asian star jasmine)
careTips: Water regularly during establishment; moderately drought-tolerant once mature. Full sun to partial shade—flowers best in full sun. Well-drained soil. Fertilize in spring with balanced fertilizer. Prune after flowering to control size and shape. Can be trained on trellises, walls, or used as groundcover. Evergreen in mild climates. Mildly toxic to pets (milky latex sap).

description: Native vine with red or orange tubular flowers; non-invasive alternative to Japanese honeysuckle.
commonExamples: Lonicera sempervirens
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun to partial shade. Well-draining soil. Fertilize in spring. Prune after flowering. Hummingbird favorite. Berries attract birds. Semi-evergreen in mild climates.

description: Also known as: Trumpet creeper. Vigorous vine with orange-red trumpet flowers; very fast-growing, can be invasive.
commonExamples: Campsis radicans (Trumpet creeper)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun essential. Tolerates poor soil. Fertilize sparingly. Prune aggressively in late winter to control. Hummingbird magnet. Can damage structures—use strong support. Spreads by suckers.

description: Deciduous vine with five leaflets; spectacular red fall color, often confused with poison ivy.
commonExamples: Parthenocissus quinquefolia
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun to full shade. Tolerates most soils. Fertilize in spring. Prune to control—can be aggressive. Five leaflets (not three like poison ivy). Berries toxic to humans. Stunning fall color.

description: Vigorous climbing vines in the Fabaceae family with cascading clusters of fragrant flowers, require strong support.
commonExamples: Wisteria sinensis (Chinese wisteria), W. floribunda (Japanese wisteria), W. frutescens (American wisteria), W. macrostachya (Kentucky wisteria)
careTips: Water regularly during establishment, then reduce to weekly. Drought tolerant once established. Well-drained soil preferred. Full sun essential for flowering. Fertilize sparingly in spring - too much nitrogen reduces blooms. Prune twice yearly - summer and winter. Requires strong support - can damage structures. Cascading clusters of fragrant flowers. Very vigorous - can be invasive. Deciduous varieties: reduce watering when dormant in winter.

description: Also known as: Bugleweed. Low groundcover with blue flower spikes and bronze or green foliage; spreads by runners.
commonExamples: Ajuga reptans (Bugleweed)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist. Partial shade preferred; tolerates full sun in cool climates. Well-draining soil. Fertilize in spring. Divide every 2–3 years to control spread. Mildly toxic to pets. Can be invasive in favorable conditions.

description: Tall native prairie grass with blue-green stems that turn reddish in fall; three-forked seed heads.
commonExamples: Andropogon gerardii
careTips: Water when top 2 inches dry; very drought-tolerant once established. Full sun essential. Adapts to most soils. No fertilizer—lean soil keeps it compact. The dominant grass of the tallgrass prairie (6-8 ft). Copper-bronze fall color. Turkey-foot seed heads. Cut back in late winter.

description: Compact ornamental grass with blue-gray foliage; forms neat mounds, ideal for borders and rock gardens.
commonExamples: Festuca glauca
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun essential for best color. Well-draining soil; drought tolerant. Fertilize sparingly. Comb or shear in early spring to remove dead foliage. Short-lived—replace every 3–4 years.

description: Low native prairie grass with distinctive horizontal flower spikes resembling eyelashes; drought tolerant.
commonExamples: Bouteloua gracilis
careTips: Water sparingly; extremely drought-tolerant once established. Full sun essential. Well-draining, lean soil. Never fertilize—causes floppy growth. Short (12-18 in.) warm-season grass with distinctive eyelash-like seed heads. Excellent for xeriscaping and native lawns. Mow to 3 inches or leave natural.

description: Also known as: Moss phlox, Moss pink. Low-growing perennial groundcover in the Polemoniaceae family with masses of spring flowers, excellent for rock gardens.
commonExamples: Phlox subulata (Moss phlox, Creeping phlox, Moss pink), P. stolonifera (Creeping phlox)
careTips: Water regularly during establishment, then reduce to weekly. Drought tolerant once established. Well-drained soil essential. Full sun preferred. Fertilize in spring with balanced fertilizer. Shear after flowering to maintain shape. Excellent for rock gardens and slopes. Masses of spring flowers. Forms dense mats. Herbaceous perennials die back; reduce watering when dormant.

description: Ornamental grasses in the Poaceae family, add texture and movement to landscapes, many are drought tolerant.
commonExamples: Pennisetum (Fountain grass), Miscanthus (Maiden grass, Silver grass), Festuca (Fescue), Panicum (Switchgrass), Calamagrostis (Feather reed grass)
careTips: Occasional deep watering (every 2-3 weeks once established). Most are drought tolerant once established. Water regularly during establishment period (first year). Full sun preferred for most species. Fertilize sparingly in spring. Cut back in late winter/early spring before new growth. Divide every 3-5 years to maintain vigor. Add texture and movement to landscapes. Research specific species for exact requirements. Herbaceous perennials die back; reduce watering when dormant.

description: Low-growing plants that spread to cover ground, useful for erosion control and reducing maintenance.
commonExamples: Thymus (Thyme, Creeping thyme), Vinca (Periwinkle), Ajuga (Bugleweed), Pachysandra (Japanese spurge), Sedum (Stonecrop)
careTips: Light watering once established (every 1-2 weeks). Keep moist during establishment period (first 3-6 months). Most are drought tolerant after rooting. Full sun to partial shade depending on species. Fertilize sparingly in spring. Prune to control spread if needed. Useful for erosion control and reducing maintenance. Mulch between plants during establishment. Research specific species for exact requirements. Evergreen; reduce watering in winter when growth slows.

description: Tall native prairie grass with golden fall color and feathery bronze seed heads; warm-season grass.
commonExamples: Sorghastrum nutans
careTips: Water when top 2 inches dry; drought-tolerant once established. Full sun essential. Adapts to most soils including clay. No fertilizer needed. Golden-bronze plume-like seed heads in fall. Tall (4-7 ft). Beautiful winter interest. Cut back in late winter before new growth.

description: Graceful, cascading grass with gold or green variegation; thrives in shade.
commonExamples: Hakonechloa macra
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist. Partial to full shade preferred; bleaches in full sun. Rich, well-draining soil. Fertilize in spring. Cut back in late winter. Slow-growing. Golden forms need some light for color.

description: Fuzzy, silver-gray foliage that feels like lamb's wool; purple flower spikes in summer.
commonExamples: Stachys byzantina
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun preferred; needs good drainage. Drought tolerant. Avoid overhead watering—fuzzy leaves rot when wet. Remove flower stalks to maintain compact foliage. Divide when center dies out.

description: Grass species maintained as lawns, require regular mowing and maintenance for healthy growth.
commonExamples: Cynodon dactylon (Bermuda grass), Festuca (Fescue, Tall fescue), Lolium (Ryegrass, Perennial ryegrass), Poa (Kentucky bluegrass), Zoysia (Zoysia grass)
careTips: Frequent deep watering (1-1.5 inches per week, 2-3 times per week). Water early morning (before 10am) to reduce evaporation and prevent disease. Avoid shallow frequent watering which encourages shallow roots. Full sun to partial shade depending on grass type. Fertilize 3-4 times per year with lawn fertilizer. Mow regularly at appropriate height for grass type. Aerate annually. Overseed in fall for cool-season grasses. Research specific grass type for exact requirements. Evergreen; reduce watering in winter when growth slows.

description: Also known as: Lilyturf. Shade-tolerant evergreen groundcover with grass-like foliage and spikes of purple or white flowers followed by dark berries.
commonExamples: Liriope muscari (Big blue lilyturf), L. spicata (Creeping lilyturf), L. muscari 'Variegata'
careTips: Water regularly during establishment; drought-tolerant once mature. Full sun to deep shade—extremely adaptable. Tolerates a wide range of soils. Fertilize in spring with balanced fertilizer. Mow or cut back old foliage in late winter before new growth emerges. Divide clumps every few years. Deer resistant. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Native prairie grass with blue-green summer foliage turning orange-red in fall; compact, drought tolerant.
commonExamples: Schizachyrium scoparium
careTips: Water when top 1-2 inches dry; very drought-tolerant once established. Full sun essential. Well-draining, lean soil—rich soil causes floppy growth. Never fertilize. Stunning mahogany-red fall and winter color with fluffy white seed heads. Cut back in late spring. Named 2022 Perennial Plant of the Year.

description: Tall ornamental grass with silvery plumes and arching foliage; can be invasive.
commonExamples: Miscanthus sinensis (Maiden grass)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun preferred. Tolerates most soils. Fertilize in spring. Cut back in late winter before new growth. Choose sterile cultivars to avoid seeding. Some cultivars invasive—check local regulations.

description: Low-growing evergreen groundcover with fine, dark green grass-like foliage, including the dramatic black-leaved variety used as an accent in modern gardens.
commonExamples: Ophiopogon japonicus (Mondo grass, Dwarf lilyturf), O. planiscapus 'Nigrescens' (Black mondo grass)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist during establishment; moderately drought-tolerant once mature. Partial shade preferred; tolerates full shade. Moist, well-drained soil with organic matter. Fertilize in spring with balanced fertilizer. Very low maintenance once established. Slow to fill in but forms dense mats over time. Black mondo grass needs some morning sun to maintain dark color. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Evergreen groundcover in the Buxaceae family with glossy leaves, excellent for shady areas and erosion control.
commonExamples: Pachysandra terminalis (Japanese spurge, Japanese pachysandra), P. procumbens (Allegheny spurge, Mountain pachysandra)
careTips: Water regularly during establishment (first year), then reduce to weekly. Prefer consistently moist but well-drained soil. Partial to full shade preferred. Fertilize in spring with balanced fertilizer. Prune to control spread if needed. Excellent for shady areas. Glossy evergreen leaves. Spreads by rhizomes. Excellent for erosion control. Evergreen; reduce watering in winter when growth slows.

description: Ornamental grass with bottlebrush flower plumes; arching foliage in green, burgundy, or variegated.
commonExamples: Pennisetum alopecuroides
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun preferred. Well-draining soil. Fertilize in spring. Cut back in late winter. Drought tolerant. Perennial in mild climates; treat as annual in cold zones. Avoid invasive P. setaceum.

description: Ornamental grass with airy pink to purple clouds of flowers in fall; drought tolerant, striking display.
commonExamples: Muhlenbergia capillaris
careTips: Water when top 1-2 inches dry; drought-tolerant once established. Full sun for best flowering. Well-draining soil; tolerates sand and clay. Light spring fertilizer optional. Spectacular cotton-candy pink flower plumes September-November. Cut back in late winter. Low-maintenance ornamental grass.

description: Fine-textured native prairie grass with fragrant fall blooms; forms neat mounds, excellent for borders.
commonExamples: Sporobolus heterolepis
careTips: Water when top 2 inches dry; very drought-tolerant once established. Full sun essential. Well-draining, lean soil. Never fertilize. Fine-textured arching foliage with delicate seed heads that smell like buttered popcorn or cilantro. Golden-orange fall color. Extremely long-lived (100+ years). Cut back in late spring.

description: Low, mat-forming succulents with small leaves; yellow or pink flowers, drought-tolerant.
commonExamples: Sedum acre, S. kamtschaticum
careTips: Water when soil is dry; very drought tolerant. Full sun preferred. Poor, well-draining soil OK. Fertilize sparingly. Excellent for rock gardens and green roofs. Propagate by division. Tolerates neglect.

description: Native prairie grass with oat-like flowers arranged along one side of the stem; state grass of Texas.
commonExamples: Bouteloua curtipendula
careTips: Water sparingly; extremely drought-tolerant once established. Full sun essential. Well-draining, lean soil including rocky or sandy. Never fertilize. Named for oat-like seeds that hang to one side of the stem. State grass of Texas. Short (18-30 in.) warm-season grass. Excellent for native meadows.

description: Low-growing shade groundcover with whorls of bright green leaves and tiny white star-shaped spring flowers. Dried leaves have sweet vanilla-hay scent; traditional flavoring for May wine.
commonExamples: Galium odoratum (Sweet woodruff, Waldmeister)
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist. Full shade to partial shade — one of the best groundcovers for deep shade. Spreads by runners; can become vigorous in ideal conditions. Shear back after flowering if needed. Minimal fertilizer required. Extremely cold-hardy. Deer and rabbit resistant. Mildly toxic in large quantities — safe as culinary herb in moderation.

description: Also known as: Panicum. Tall native prairie grass with airy flower panicles; blue-green or red cultivars; important biofuel crop.
commonExamples: Panicum virgatum
careTips: Water when top 1-2 inches dry; drought-tolerant once established. Full sun essential. Adapts to most soils including clay and wet areas. No fertilizer needed. Upright growth (3-6 ft) with airy seed heads. Excellent winter interest. Cut back in late winter. Deep roots prevent erosion.

description: Evergreen groundcover in the Apocynaceae family with glossy leaves and spring flowers, can be invasive.
commonExamples: Vinca minor (Common periwinkle, Lesser periwinkle), V. major (Bigleaf periwinkle, Greater periwinkle)
careTips: Water regularly during establishment, then reduce to weekly. Drought tolerant once established. Well-drained soil preferred. Partial shade to full shade preferred. Fertilize in spring with balanced fertilizer. Prune to control spread if needed. Glossy evergreen leaves. Spring flowers. Spreads by runners. Can be invasive - check local regulations. Evergreen; reduce watering in winter when growth slows.

description: Also known as: Chinese spinach. Heat-tolerant leafy green and grain crop in the Amaranthaceae family; nutritious leaves and edible seeds, thrives in summer heat.
commonExamples: Amaranthus spp. (Chinese spinach)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun preferred. Drought tolerant once established. Fertilize regularly during growing season. Harvest young leaves for greens; seeds for grain. Mulch to retain moisture.

description: Also known as: Rocket, Roquette. Fast-growing leafy green in the Brassicaceae family with peppery flavor, also known as rocket or roquette.
commonExamples: Eruca sativa (Arugula, Rocket, Roquette), E. vesicaria (Wild arugula), Diplotaxis tenuifolia (Perennial wall rocket)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Consistent moisture prevents bitterness and bolting. Water at base. Full sun to partial shade. Prefer cooler temperatures - plant in spring or fall. Fertilize every 3-4 weeks with balanced fertilizer. Harvest leaves when young for best flavor. Fast-growing. Peppery flavor. Can bolt in heat - provide shade in summer. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Edible leaves and stems of the beet root; nutritious, quick-growing, and harvested before or alongside the root.
commonExamples: Beta vulgaris (Beet greens, Beet tops)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Full sun to partial shade. Fertile, well-drained soil. Fertilize every 3-4 weeks. Harvest outer leaves when 4-6 inches; inner leaves continue growing. Both greens and roots edible.

description: Also known as: Pak choi. Leafy green vegetable in the Brassicaceae family, fast-growing and mild-flavored, popular in Chinese cuisine.
commonExamples: Brassica rapa subsp. chinensis (Bok choy, Pak choi, Chinese cabbage), 'Shanghai', 'Joi Choi', 'Mei Qing Choi'
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Consistent moisture prevents bitterness and bolting. Water at base. Full sun to partial shade. Prefer cooler temperatures - plant in spring or fall. Fertilize every 3-4 weeks with balanced fertilizer. Harvest whole heads or individual leaves. Fast-growing. Can bolt in heat - provide shade in summer. Watch for cabbage worms. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Leafy vegetables in the Brassicaceae family, form tight heads, prefer cool weather.
commonExamples: Brassica oleracea var. capitata (Cabbage), green, red, savoy varieties, 'Golden Acre', 'Red Express'
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Consistent moisture important for head formation. Well-drained, fertile soil preferred. Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize every 3-4 weeks with nitrogen-rich fertilizer. Harvest when heads are firm and reach desired size. Prefer cool weather - plant in spring or fall. Can be stored for months. Watch for cabbage worms. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Also known as: Chinese flowering cabbage. Leafy green vegetables in the Brassicaceae family, popular in Chinese cuisine with tender stems and small yellow flowers.
commonExamples: Brassica rapa var. parachinensis (Choy sum, Chinese flowering cabbage, Cai xin)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Consistent moisture important. Well-drained, fertile soil preferred. Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize every 3-4 weeks with nitrogen-rich fertilizer. Harvest whole plant or individual leaves. Prefer cool weather - plant in spring or fall. Popular in Chinese cuisine. Fast-growing. Can bolt in heat. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Also known as: Collards. Leafy green vegetable in the Brassicaceae family, cold-hardy and can overwinter in mild climates.
commonExamples: Brassica oleracea var. viridis (Collard greens, Collards), 'Georgia', 'Vates', 'Champion'
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Consistent moisture ensures tender leaves. Water at base. Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize every 3-4 weeks with nitrogen-rich fertilizer. Harvest outer leaves regularly to encourage new growth. Cold-hardy - flavor improves after frost. Can overwinter in mild climates. Watch for cabbage worms and aphids. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Edible greens from the common dandelion; slightly bitter, nutritious, best when young. Roots and flowers also edible.
commonExamples: Taraxacum officinale (Dandelion leaves)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun for tender leaves. Harvest young leaves before flowers for milder flavor. Blanch by covering to reduce bitterness. Wild or cultivated; ensure no pesticide use.

description: Also known as: Frisée. Curly-leaved chicory in the Asteraceae family; slightly bitter, crisp leaves for salads. Distinct from escarole (broad-leaved).
commonExamples: Cichorium endivia (Curly endive, Frisée)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist. Full sun to partial shade. Prefer cool weather; plant spring or fall. Fertilize every 3-4 weeks. Blanch by covering heads 1-2 weeks before harvest for milder flavor. Harvest when leaves reach desired size.

description: Also known as: Broad-leaved endive. Broad-leaved chicory in the Asteraceae family; milder than curly endive, with flat, tender leaves for salads and cooking.
commonExamples: Cichorium endivia var. latifolia (Broad-leaved endive)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist. Full sun to partial shade. Prefer cool weather; plant spring or fall. Fertilize every 3-4 weeks. Blanch inner leaves for milder flavor. Harvest outer leaves or whole head. Less bitter than curly endive.

description: Also known as: Chinese broccoli, Kai-lan, Chinese kale. Chinese broccoli in the Brassicaceae family with thick stems and small flower heads, essential in Chinese cuisine.
commonExamples: Brassica oleracea var. alboglabra (Gai lan, Chinese broccoli, Kai-lan, Chinese kale)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Consistent moisture important. Well-drained, fertile soil preferred. Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize every 3-4 weeks with nitrogen-rich fertilizer. Harvest when flower buds are just forming. Both stems and leaves are edible. Prefer cool weather. Essential in Chinese cuisine. Watch for cabbage worms. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Cold-hardy leafy green in the Brassicaceae family, flavor improves after frost, can overwinter in mild climates.
commonExamples: Brassica oleracea var. acephala (Kale), curly kale, Lacinato (Dinosaur kale, Tuscan kale), Red Russian kale
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Consistent moisture ensures tender leaves. Water at base to avoid wetting leaves. Mulch around plants to retain moisture and keep leaves clean. Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize every 3-4 weeks with nitrogen-rich fertilizer. Harvest outer leaves regularly to encourage new growth. Flavor improves after frost. Can overwinter in mild climates. Watch for cabbage worms and aphids. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Vegetables grown primarily for their edible leaves. Many are cool-season crops that bolt in heat. Quick to harvest and ideal for successive planting.
commonExamples: Lactuca sativa (Lettuce), Spinacia oleracea (Spinach), Brassica oleracea (Kale), Beta vulgaris (Swiss chard), Eruca vesicaria (Arugula)
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist — water every 1-2 days in warm weather. Mulch to retain moisture and keep roots cool. Partial shade to full sun — most prefer cooler conditions and bolt (go to seed) in heat. Fertilize every 2-3 weeks with nitrogen-rich fertilizer for lush leaf growth. Harvest outer leaves first (cut-and-come-again) for continuous production. Succession plant every 2-3 weeks for ongoing harvest. Best grown in spring and fall — provide shade cloth in summer. Ready in 30-60 days depending on variety. Research specific vegetable for exact requirements.

description: Fast-growing leafy greens in the Asteraceae family, prefer cooler temperatures and can bolt (flower) in heat.
commonExamples: Lactuca sativa (Lettuce), butterhead, romaine, leaf lettuce, and crisphead varieties
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (daily watering may be needed in hot weather). Consistent moisture prevents bitterness and bolting (premature flowering). Water at base to avoid wetting leaves which can cause disease. Partial shade in hot climates helps prevent bolting. Fertilize every 2-3 weeks with nitrogen-rich fertilizer. Harvest outer leaves regularly or cut whole head. Fast-growing - ready in 45-60 days. Prefer cooler temperatures - plant in spring and fall. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Heat-loving vining herb in the Basellaceae family; succulent leaves and stems. Thrives in summer when true spinach bolts.
commonExamples: Basella alba (Ceylon spinach, Malabar spinach)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist. Full sun. Trellis or support for vining habit. Fertilize every 3-4 weeks. Harvest young leaves and shoot tips. Heat-tolerant; grows when other greens struggle. Red-stemmed variety (B. alba 'Rubra') ornamental.

description: Japanese mustard green in the Brassicaceae family; feathery, serrated leaves with mild peppery flavor. Popular in salads and stir-fries.
commonExamples: Brassica rapa var. nipposinica (Japanese mustard, Mizuna)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Full sun to partial shade. Prefer cool weather; plant spring or fall. Fertilize every 3-4 weeks. Cut-and-come-again harvest. Fast-growing; ready in 40-50 days. Mild flavor; can bolt in heat.

description: Leafy green vegetables in the Brassicaceae family with peppery flavor, fast-growing and cold-hardy.
commonExamples: Brassica juncea (Mustard greens, Mustard spinach, Indian mustard), 'Southern Giant Curled', 'Red Giant', 'Tendergreen'
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Consistent moisture ensures tender leaves. Water at base. Full sun to partial shade. Prefer cooler temperatures - plant in spring or fall. Fertilize every 3-4 weeks with nitrogen-rich fertilizer. Harvest outer leaves regularly. Fast-growing. Peppery flavor. Cold-hardy. Can bolt in heat. Watch for cabbage worms and aphids. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Also known as: Chinese cabbage, Wombok, Pe-tsai. Chinese cabbage in the Brassicaceae family with elongated, barrel-shaped heads, essential in Chinese cuisine.
commonExamples: Brassica rapa subsp. pekinensis (Napa cabbage, Chinese cabbage, Wombok, Pe-tsai), 'Michihili', 'Blues', 'Rubicon'
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Consistent moisture important for head formation. Well-drained, fertile soil preferred. Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize every 3-4 weeks with nitrogen-rich fertilizer. Prefer cool weather - plant in spring or fall. Harvest when heads are firm. Essential in Chinese cuisine. Can bolt in heat. Watch for cabbage worms. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Succulent annual in the Portulacaceae family; fleshy leaves high in omega-3. Often foraged as a weed; cultivated for salads and cooking.
commonExamples: Portulaca oleracea (Common purslane)
careTips: Drought tolerant; water when soil is dry. Full sun. Poor soil acceptable. Harvest stems and leaves when young. Self-sows; can become weedy. Tangy, slightly lemony flavor. Popular in Mediterranean and Asian cuisines.

description: Also known as: Chioggia, Treviso, Castelfranco. Chicory in the Asteraceae family with bitter, wine-red leaves; forms compact heads. Essential in Italian cuisine; bitterness mellows when grilled or roasted.
commonExamples: Cichorium intybus var. foliosum (Chioggia, Treviso, Castelfranco)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist. Full sun. Prefer cool weather; flavor improves after frost. Fertilize every 3-4 weeks. Harvest when heads are firm. Cold temperatures deepen red color. Blanch some varieties for sweeter flavor.

description: Cool-season leafy green in the Amaranthaceae family, bolts quickly in heat, best grown in spring and fall.
commonExamples: Spinacia oleracea (Spinach), smooth-leaf and savoy (crinkled) varieties
