Fertilize in early spring with fruit tree fertilizer. Prune in late winter/early spring. Many varieties need cross-pollination - plant compatible varieties. Thin fruit for larger plums. Harvest when fully colored and slightly soft. Requires winter chill. Reduce watering when dormant in winter.

description: Deciduous fruit trees in the Lythraceae family with jewel-like seeds, drought-tolerant once established.
commonExamples: Punica granatum (Pomegranate), 'Wonderful', 'Eversweet', 'Ambrosia', dwarf varieties
careTips: Deep soak weekly during growing season. Drought tolerant once established. Mulch around base. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize in early spring with balanced fertilizer. Prune to maintain shape. Self-fertile. Harvest when fully colored and makes metallic sound when tapped. Can be grown in containers. Requires hot summers for best fruiting. Deciduous; reduce or withhold watering when leaves drop in fall.

description: Also known as: Pummelo, Shaddock. Large citrus fruits in the Rutaceae family, largest citrus fruit, popular in China and Southeast Asia.
commonExamples: Citrus maxima (Pomelo, Pummelo, Shaddock), 'Chandler', 'Reinking'
careTips: Deep soak regularly during growing season. Well-drained soil essential. Full sun essential. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with citrus fertilizer. Prune to maintain size. Self-fertile. Harvest when fully yellow and fragrant. Largest citrus fruit. Require warm climates - protect from frost. Popular in China and Southeast Asia. Evergreen; reduce watering in winter when growth slows.

description: Cactus in the Cactaceae family with edible pads and sweet, colorful fruits (tunas), drought-tolerant.
commonExamples: Opuntia ficus-indica (Tuna fruit)
careTips: Water very sparingly - soak soil thoroughly then allow to dry completely before watering again; in winter, suspend watering almost entirely. Full sun essential (8+ hours daily). Fertilize once in spring with a dilute cactus fertilizer or low-nitrogen blend. Do NOT mulch - prickly pear needs bare, fast-draining soil and mulch retains too much moisture causing rot. Use tongs and thick gloves when harvesting fruit (tunas), as both fruit and pads have glochids (tiny barbed spines). Extremely drought and heat tolerant once established. Pads can be rooted simply by setting a cut pad on dry soil. Non-toxic to pets; glochids can cause mechanical irritation.

description: Deciduous tree in the Rosaceae family with aromatic golden pomes, must be cooked - ideal for preserves.
commonExamples: Cydonia oblonga
careTips: Water regularly during the first few years to establish; mature trees are moderately drought tolerant. Full sun essential for best fruit production (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize in early spring with a balanced fruit tree fertilizer. Prune in late winter to maintain an open, vase-shaped canopy - quince fruits on the tips of new growth, so avoid heavy heading cuts. Fruit is too hard and astringent to eat raw but becomes beautifully fragrant and turns rosy-pink when cooked into preserves, membrillo paste, or poached. Very ornamental with large pink-white spring blossoms. Susceptible to fire blight - prune affected branches 12 inches below infection. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Tropical fruit tree producing clusters of hairy red or yellow fruits with translucent, sweet, lychee-like flesh inside—the name comes from the Malay word for hair.
commonExamples: Nephelium lappaceum (Rambutan, Hairy lychee, Chom chom)
careTips: Water regularly; keep soil consistently moist, especially during flowering and fruiting. Full sun for best fruit production. Very high humidity (80%+) essential—strictly tropical, no frost tolerance. Deep, well-draining, organically rich acidic soil (pH 5.0-6.5). Fertilize quarterly with balanced fertilizer; increase potassium during fruiting. Trees are either male or female—plant both for pollination or choose grafted hermaphrodite varieties. Can grow 15-25 meters; choose grafted dwarf cultivars for smaller spaces. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Also known as: Red raspberry. Perennial cane fruits in the Rosaceae family, produce fruit on second-year canes (floricane) or first-year canes (primocane) depending on variety.
commonExamples: Rubus idaeus (Red raspberry), R. occidentalis (Black raspberry), R. leucodermis (Blackcap raspberry), summer-bearing and everbearing varieties
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (weekly deep watering). Water at base to avoid wetting fruit. Mulch around plants to retain moisture and suppress weeds. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize in early spring with balanced fertilizer. Prune according to type - summer-bearing: remove fruited canes after harvest; everbearing: can be pruned for one or two crops. Support canes with trellis. Harvest when fully colored and easily detaches. Replace plants every 8-10 years. Deciduous varieties: reduce watering when dormant in winter.

description: Also known as: Garden strawberry. Low-growing perennial berry plants in the Rosaceae family, produce runners for propagation.
commonExamples: Fragaria × ananassa (Garden strawberry), June-bearing, everbearing, and day-neutral varieties
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Water at base to avoid wetting fruit which can cause rot. Mulch with straw or pine needles to keep berries clean and prevent soil contact. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize in early spring and after harvest with balanced fertilizer. Remove runners first year to encourage fruiting; allow runners second year to propagate. Harvest when fully red. Replace plants every 3-4 years. Research variety type (June-bearing, everbearing, day-neutral) for exact requirements. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Cultivar of watermelon in the Cucurbitaceae family with sweet yellow or orange flesh instead of red.
commonExamples: Citrullus lanatus (Yellow flesh cultivar)
careTips: Water deeply and consistently, providing 1-2 inches per week - critical during fruit development to prevent cracking and hollow heart. Full sun essential (8+ hours daily); needs long, hot growing season. Fertilize at planting with balanced fertilizer, then switch to a low-nitrogen, high-potassium formula when vines begin to flower. Give vines plenty of room to sprawl (6-10 feet in each direction) or train on a strong trellis with sling support for fruit. Ripe when the tendril nearest the fruit turns brown and dry, and the ground spot turns creamy yellow. Mulch heavily with straw to suppress weeds and keep fruit off wet soil. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Also known as: Sweet basil. Annual culinary herb in the Lamiaceae family with aromatic leaves, essential in Mediterranean and Asian cuisines.
commonExamples: Ocimum basilicum (Sweet basil, Genovese basil), O. basilicum 'Purple', O. tenuiflorum (Holy basil, Tulsi), Thai basil
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Water at base to avoid wetting leaves. Well-drained soil essential. Full sun preferred (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize every 3-4 weeks with balanced fertilizer. Pinch flowers immediately to prolong leaf production. Harvest regularly by pinching tips to encourage bushy growth. Very sensitive to cold - plant after last frost. Annual - replant each season.

description: Also known as: Bay leaf. Evergreen tree in the Lauraceae family with aromatic leaves used in soups, stews, and Mediterranean cooking. Can be grown as a container tree or shaped hedge.
commonExamples: Laurus nobilis (Bay leaf)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun preferred. Fertilize regularly during growing season. Harvest leaves as needed; dry before storing. Mulch to retain moisture. Mildly toxic to pets if ingested.

description: Also known as: Starflower. Annual herb in the Boraginaceae family with edible blue flowers and cucumber-flavored leaves. Used in salads, drinks, and as a companion plant for tomatoes and squash.
commonExamples: Borago officinalis (Starflower)
careTips: Water moderately, allowing soil to dry slightly between waterings - borage is fairly drought tolerant once established. Full sun to partial shade (6+ hours daily). Fertilizing is generally unnecessary; borage thrives in poor to average soil and excess nitrogen produces leggy growth with fewer flowers. Sow seeds directly outdoors as borage has a long taproot and resents transplanting. Self-seeds prolifically - deadhead to control spread, or allow it to naturalize. Harvest young leaves (older leaves become prickly) and blue star-shaped flowers for salads and garnishes. Non-toxic to pets; flowers and young leaves are edible.

description: Also known as: Green cardamom. Spice plant in the ginger family with aromatic seeds used in cooking and chai.
commonExamples: Elettaria cardamomum (Green cardamom, True cardamom), Amomum subulatum (Black cardamom)
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist. High humidity. Partial shade. Warm temperatures. Harvest seed pods when green and before splitting. Tropical perennial.

description: Perennial herb in the Lamiaceae family with gray-green leaves. Known for attracting cats; leaves can be used in tea or as a calming herb for humans.
commonExamples: Nepeta cataria (Catnip)
careTips: Water moderately, allowing soil to dry between waterings - catnip is drought tolerant and prefers not to sit in wet soil. Full sun to partial shade (4-6 hours daily). Fertilize sparingly or not at all; rich soil and heavy feeding reduce the essential oil concentration that gives catnip its potency. Cut back by one-third after the first flush of flowers to encourage a second bloom. Be aware that cats will roll in, chew, and crush the plants - consider a protective cage if growing for harvest. Spreads by both runners and self-seeding; contain in pots or harvest frequently to control. Non-toxic to pets; the nepetalactone compound is safe and acts as a stimulant for cats.

description: Herb in the Asteraceae family with daisy-like flowers used for soothing tea. German chamomile is annual; Roman chamomile is perennial. Both have apple-scented foliage.
commonExamples: Matricaria chamomilla (German chamomile)
careTips: Water regularly but lightly, keeping soil slightly moist - chamomile has shallow roots but does not like soggy soil. Full sun to partial shade (4-6 hours daily). Fertilizing is generally unnecessary and can reduce flower production and essential oil concentration. Sow seeds on the soil surface (they need light to germinate) in spring or fall. Harvest flower heads when petals begin to fold back from the center, typically in the morning after dew has dried. German chamomile is annual and self-seeds freely; Roman chamomile is a low-growing perennial useful as a fragrant ground cover. Non-toxic to pets; may cause reactions in those with ragweed allergies.

description: Cool-season annual herb in the Apiaceae family with delicate anise- and parsley-like flavor. Essential in French fines herbes. Best in spring and fall; bolts in heat.
commonExamples: Anthriscus cerefolium (French parsley)
careTips: Water regularly to keep soil consistently moist - chervil bolts quickly if stressed by drought. Partial shade is essential, NOT full sun; chervil is one of the few herbs that actually prefers and needs shade, especially in warm climates. Fertilize lightly once a month with a balanced liquid fertilizer. Sow seeds directly outdoors in early spring or late summer/fall, as chervil dislikes transplanting and heat. Best treated as a cool-season crop; it bolts rapidly in temperatures above 75°F (24°C). Harvest outer leaves regularly, cutting stems at the base. Flavor is delicate and lost when cooked - add fresh at the end. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Also known as: Nira. Perennial herbs in the Amaryllidaceae family with flat leaves and garlic flavor, essential in Chinese cuisine.
commonExamples: Allium tuberosum (Chinese chives, Garlic chives, Gow choy, Nira)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Well-drained soil preferred. Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize monthly with balanced fertilizer. Harvest by cutting leaves at base. Divide every 3-4 years. Perennial - returns each year. Garlic flavor. Essential in Chinese cuisine. Can be grown in containers. Edible white flowers. Herbaceous perennials die back; reduce watering when dormant.

description: Perennial herbs in the Amaryllidaceae family with hollow, grass-like leaves, easy to grow.
commonExamples: Allium schoenoprasum (Chives), common chives
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Well-drained soil preferred. Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize monthly with balanced fertilizer. Harvest by cutting leaves at base. Divide every 3-4 years. Perennial - returns each year. Easy to grow. Can be grown in containers. Edible purple flowers. Reduce watering in winter when growth slows.

description: Also known as: Coriander, Chinese parsley. Annual herb in the Apiaceae family, leaves (cilantro) and seeds (coriander) are both used, bolts quickly in heat.
commonExamples: Coriandrum sativum (Cilantro, Coriander, Chinese parsley)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Consistent moisture prevents bolting. Well-drained soil preferred. Full sun to partial shade. Prefer cooler temperatures - plant in spring or fall. Fertilize every 3-4 weeks with balanced fertilizer. Harvest leaves regularly. Bolts quickly in heat - provide shade in summer or plant in fall. Annual - replant each season. Seeds (coriander) can be harvested when brown.

description: Perennial herb in the Boraginaceae family with large hairy leaves. Traditionally used externally for bruises and sprains. Contains pyrrolizidine alkaloids—do not ingest; mild toxicity to pets.
commonExamples: Symphytum officinale
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun preferred. Fertilize regularly. Use as compost activator or mulch. Do not consume internally. Mildly toxic to pets when ingested.

description: Annual herbs in the Apiaceae family with feathery leaves and seeds, both leaves and seeds are used.
commonExamples: Anethum graveolens (Dill), 'Bouquet', 'Fernleaf', 'Mammoth'
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Well-drained soil preferred. Full sun essential. Fertilize every 3-4 weeks with balanced fertilizer. Harvest leaves regularly. Harvest seeds when brown. Can bolt in heat - plant in spring or fall. Both leaves and seeds are used. Attracts beneficial insects. Annual - replant each season.

description: Annual herb in the Amaranthaceae family with a pungent, medicinal flavor. Traditional in Mexican bean dishes to reduce gas. Used sparingly due to strong flavor.
commonExamples: Dysphania ambrosioides (Mexican tea)
careTips: Water sparingly, allowing soil to dry between waterings - epazote is drought tolerant and actually produces more aromatic oils under slightly dry conditions. Full sun preferred (6-8 hours daily). Fertilizing is unnecessary; epazote thrives in poor, well-draining soil and excessive nutrients reduce flavor intensity. Self-seeds very aggressively and can become weedy - deadhead before seeds mature or grow in containers. Use leaves sparingly in cooking, as the flavor is very strong and the plant contains toxic compounds (ascaridole) that are harmful in large quantities. Harvest young leaves, which are milder than mature foliage. Toxic to pets in large quantities; contains ascaridole which is harmful if ingested in excess.

description: Tall, feathery herb with an anise-like flavor used in Mediterranean cooking, producing edible fronds, seeds, pollen, and a crunchy bulb in the Florence variety.
commonExamples: Foeniculum vulgare (Sweet fennel, Common fennel), F. vulgare var. azoricum (Florence fennel, Finocchio), F. vulgare 'Purpureum' (Bronze fennel)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist; water regularly in hot weather. Full sun essential—at least 6 hours daily. Medium humidity fine. Deep, well-draining, fertile soil. Fertilize at planting with compost; side-dress with balanced fertilizer mid-season. Do not plant near dill—they cross-pollinate and produce poor-flavored seeds. Hill soil around Florence fennel bulbs to blanch them. Attracts swallowtail butterfly caterpillars. Mildly toxic to pets in large amounts.

description: Rhizomatous herbs in the Zingiberaceae family, essential spice in Chinese cuisine, can be grown from store-bought rhizomes.
commonExamples: Zingiber officinale (Ginger), common ginger, young ginger
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist but not waterlogged. Well-drained, rich soil preferred. Partial shade preferred - avoid direct hot sun. Fertilize monthly with balanced fertilizer. Plant rhizome pieces with eyes pointing up. Harvest when leaves die back (8-10 months). Can be grown in containers. Essential spice in Chinese cuisine. Rhizomes can be harvested partially. Reduce watering in winter when growth slows.

description: Also known as: Tulsi. Annual herb in the Lamiaceae family, sacred in Hinduism. Aromatic leaves with clove-like flavor used in Thai cuisine and Ayurvedic medicine. Different from sweet basil.
commonExamples: Ocimum tenuiflorum (Tulsi, Holy basil)
careTips: Water regularly to keep soil evenly moist but not waterlogged - holy basil likes consistent moisture but is more drought tolerant than sweet basil. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize every 3-4 weeks with a balanced organic fertilizer; avoid heavy nitrogen which reduces the aromatic essential oil content. Pinch flower buds to prolong leaf harvest, though the purple flowers are also edible and attractive to pollinators. Unlike sweet basil, holy basil (tulsi) has a more clove-like, peppery flavor and is traditionally used in Thai stir-fries and Ayurvedic teas rather than Italian cuisine. Grows as a perennial in tropical zones but is treated as an annual in temperate climates. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Culinary herbs grown indoors, require good drainage and regular harvesting to encourage bushy growth.
commonExamples: Ocimum basilicum (Basil, Sweet basil), Mentha (Mint, Spearmint, Peppermint), Thymus (Thyme), Rosmarinus (Rosemary), Petroselinum (Parsley)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist but well-drained. Allow top inch to dry slightly between waterings. Avoid waterlogged soil - excellent drainage essential. Bright indirect to direct light (4-6 hours daily minimum). Medium humidity (40-50%) is fine. Fertilize monthly with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Harvest regularly to encourage bushy growth - pinch tips. Pinch flowers to prolong leaf production. Repot annually. Research specific herb for exact requirements.

description: Beloved aromatic herb with silvery-green foliage and fragrant purple flower spikes prized for culinary use, essential oils, sachets, and ornamental garden borders.
commonExamples: Lavandula angustifolia (English lavender, True lavender), L. stoechas (French lavender, Spanish lavender), L. x intermedia (Lavandin, Grosso lavender)
careTips: Drought-tolerant once established; water deeply but infrequently, allowing soil to dry between waterings. Full sun essential—at least 6-8 hours daily. Low humidity preferred; good air circulation prevents fungal disease. Well-draining, slightly alkaline soil (add lime to acidic soils). Avoid rich fertilizer—lean soil concentrates fragrance. Prune after flowering by cutting back one-third; never cut into old wood. Mildly toxic to pets if ingested in large quantities.

description: Perennial herb in the Lamiaceae family with lemon-scented leaves. Used in tea, salads, and desserts. Spreads readily; can be invasive. Attracts bees.
commonExamples: Melissa officinalis (Lemon balm)
careTips: Water regularly to keep soil evenly moist, but lemon balm is quite forgiving of occasional drought once established. Full sun to partial shade (4-6 hours daily); some afternoon shade in hot climates prevents leaf scorching. Fertilize sparingly - once or twice per season with compost or dilute balanced fertilizer is sufficient. Warning: lemon balm spreads extremely aggressively by both runners and self-seeding; grow in containers or use root barriers to prevent it from taking over the garden. Harvest frequently by cutting stems back to a leaf node, which keeps plants bushy and delays flowering. Cut the entire plant back by half in midsummer to rejuvenate growth. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Perennial grasses in the Poaceae family with lemony flavor, popular in Asian cuisine, can be grown in containers.
commonExamples: Cymbopogon citratus (Lemongrass, West Indian lemongrass), C. flexuosus (East Indian lemongrass)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Well-drained, rich soil preferred. Full sun preferred. Fertilize monthly with nitrogen-rich fertilizer. Harvest outer stalks at base. Divide every 2-3 years. Perennial in warm climates - treat as annual in cold. Can be grown in containers. Lemony flavor. Popular in Asian cuisine. Reduce watering in winter when growth slows.

description: Tall perennial herb in the Apiaceae family with celery-like flavor. Leaves, stems, and seeds used in soups and stocks. Often grown as a substitute for celery.
commonExamples: Levisticum officinale
careTips: Water regularly to keep soil consistently moist - lovage is a moisture-loving plant with deep roots. Full sun to partial shade (4-6 hours daily); appreciates afternoon shade in hot climates. Fertilize in early spring with compost or balanced fertilizer; lovage is a vigorous perennial that benefits from rich soil. Be prepared for its size - lovage grows 4-6 feet tall and should be placed at the back of the herb garden. Cut flower stalks before they bloom to direct energy into leaf production, unless saving seed. All parts are edible with an intense celery-like flavor: use leaves in soups and stews, hollow stems as savory straws, seeds as a spice, and roots as a cooked vegetable. Non-toxic to pets; may cause photosensitivity in some animals with heavy consumption.

description: Also known as: Sweet marjoram. Tender perennial herb in the Lamiaceae family with a sweeter, milder flavor than oregano. Essential in Greek and Middle Eastern cooking. Often grown as annual in cold climates.
commonExamples: Origanum majorana (Sweet marjoram)
careTips: Water moderately, allowing the top inch of soil to dry between waterings - marjoram prefers slightly drier conditions than most herbs and is susceptible to root rot in wet soil. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize lightly every 4-6 weeks with a dilute liquid fertilizer; over-feeding diminishes the delicate sweet aroma. Harvest before flowers open for the strongest flavor by cutting stems back to a leaf pair. Tender perennial (hardy only to about 30°F/-1°C); in cold climates grow as an annual or bring containers indoors for winter. Often confused with oregano but has a sweeter, milder, more floral flavor. Excellent for drying - hang bundles upside down in a warm, airy spot. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Perennial herbs in the Lamiaceae family with aromatic leaves, can be invasive, spreads by runners.
commonExamples: Mentha spicata (Spearmint), M. × piperita (Peppermint), M. suaveolens (Apple mint), M. × villosa (Apple mint)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Prefer consistently moist but well-drained soil. Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize monthly with balanced fertilizer. Harvest regularly to control growth. Very invasive - grow in containers or use barriers to contain. Spreads by runners. Can be grown indoors or outdoors. Perennial but may die back in winter. Reduce watering in winter when growth slows.

description: Also known as: Wild marjoram. Perennial herbs in the Lamiaceae family with pungent leaves, essential in Mediterranean cuisine.
commonExamples: Origanum vulgare (Oregano, Wild marjoram), O. vulgare subsp. hirtum (Greek oregano)
careTips: Water when soil is dry (every 1-2 weeks once established). Well-drained soil essential. Drought tolerant once established. Full sun preferred (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize sparingly in spring. Harvest regularly by cutting stems. Pinch flowers to prolong leaf production. Perennial - may need protection in very cold climates. Flavor intensifies when dried. Reduce watering in winter when growth slows.

description: Also known as: Curly parsley. Biennial herbs in the Apiaceae family, most commonly used as annual, curly and flat-leaf varieties.
commonExamples: Petroselinum crispum (Curly parsley), P. crispum var. neapolitanum (Flat-leaf parsley, Italian parsley)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Well-drained soil preferred. Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize every 3-4 weeks with balanced fertilizer. Harvest outer leaves regularly to encourage new growth. Biennial but usually grown as annual. Flat-leaf has stronger flavor. Can be grown indoors. Very common culinary herb. Mildly toxic to pets in large amounts. Reduce watering in winter when growth slows.

description: Vigorous aromatic herb with dark green leaves edged in purple and a strong, cooling menthol flavor used in teas, desserts, cocktails, and herbal remedies.
commonExamples: Mentha x piperita (Peppermint), M. x piperita 'Chocolate' (Chocolate mint), M. x piperita citrata (Orange mint)
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist; never let it dry out. Partial sun to partial shade—4-6 hours of sun ideal. Medium humidity fine. Rich, moisture-retentive soil. Fertilize monthly with balanced liquid fertilizer during growing season. Extremely invasive—always grow in containers to prevent spreading. Pinch tips regularly to promote bushy growth and prevent flowering. Harvest frequently; flavor is best just before flowering. Mildly toxic to pets (menthol can cause gastrointestinal upset).

description: Also known as: Garden sage. Perennial herbs in the Lamiaceae family with gray-green leaves, drought-tolerant once established.
commonExamples: Salvia officinalis (Common sage, Garden sage), 'Berggarten', 'Purple', 'Tricolor'
careTips: Water when soil is dry (every 1-2 weeks once established). Well-drained soil essential. Drought tolerant once established. Full sun preferred. Fertilize sparingly in spring. Harvest leaves regularly. Prune to maintain shape. Perennial - may need protection in very cold climates. Strong flavor - use sparingly in cooking. Reduce watering in winter when growth slows.

description: Also known as: Summer savory. Herb in the Lamiaceae family with peppery, thyme-like flavor. Summer savory is annual; winter savory is perennial. Traditional in bean dishes and stuffings.
commonExamples: Satureja hortensis (Summer savory)
careTips: Water moderately, allowing soil to dry slightly between waterings - savory prefers lean, well-drained conditions similar to other Mediterranean herbs. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize sparingly or not at all; poor to average soil actually intensifies the peppery, thyme-like flavor. Summer savory (Satureja hortensis) is an annual with a milder flavor; winter savory (S. montana) is a hardy perennial with a stronger, more pungent taste. Harvest summer savory before flowering for best flavor; winter savory can be clipped year-round. Both types make excellent companion plants for beans and are traditionally used in bean dishes to aid digestion. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Annual herb in the Lamiaceae family with a mint-basil flavor. Green and red varieties used in Japanese, Korean, and Vietnamese cuisine. Essential for sushi and banchan.
commonExamples: Perilla frutescens (Shiso, Japanese perilla)
careTips: Water regularly to keep soil consistently moist but not waterlogged. Full sun to partial shade (4-6 hours daily); some afternoon shade in hot climates prevents wilting and bitterness. Fertilize every 3-4 weeks with a balanced liquid fertilizer at half strength. Pinch growing tips regularly to encourage bushy growth and delay flowering. Available in green and red (purple) varieties - red shiso is used for coloring umeboshi and shiso juice, while green shiso is preferred fresh for sushi, sashimi, and rice wraps. Self-seeds freely and can become weedy if allowed to go to seed; deadhead or harvest before seed set. Direct sow after last frost as shiso resents transplanting. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Also known as: Garden sorrel. Perennial herb in the Polygonaceae family with tangy, lemony leaves from oxalic acid. Used in soups, salads, and sauces. French sorrel has milder flavor.
commonExamples: Rumex acetosa (Garden sorrel)
careTips: Water regularly to keep soil evenly moist - sorrel's flavor becomes excessively sour and leaves turn tough in dry conditions. Full sun to partial shade (4-6 hours daily); benefits from afternoon shade in hot climates. Fertilize lightly in spring with compost or balanced fertilizer; too much nitrogen encourages excessive leaf growth with reduced flavor. Remove flower stalks promptly to prolong leaf harvest and prevent the plant from going to seed. A hardy perennial that returns reliably each spring and can be harvested for many years from the same clump. Leaves contain oxalic acid giving the signature tangy flavor - avoid consuming in very large quantities or if prone to kidney stones. Non-toxic to pets in small amounts; large quantities may cause issues due to oxalic acid.

description: Tender perennial herb in the Asteraceae family. Leaves are intensely sweet—used as natural sugar substitute. Native to Paraguay; needs warm, frost-free climate.
commonExamples: Stevia rebaudiana (Stevia)
careTips: Water regularly to keep soil consistently moist but well-drained - stevia does not tolerate drought well, nor does it like sitting in water. Full sun to partial shade (6+ hours daily). Fertilize every 2-3 weeks during the growing season with a balanced fertilizer at half strength; avoid high-nitrogen formulas which dilute the sweet flavor. Pinch growing tips regularly to encourage bushy growth and more leaf production. Harvest leaves before flowering for maximum sweetness; once the plant blooms, leaves become less sweet and may turn bitter. Tender perennial hardy only to about 40°F (4°C); grow as an annual in cold climates or overwinter indoors. Leaves can be dried and ground into powder for a natural sweetener. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Perennial herb in the Asteraceae family with anise-like flavor. French tarragon is the culinary standard; propagated by division. Essential in béarnaise and fines herbes.
commonExamples: Artemisia dracunculus (French tarragon)
careTips: Water moderately, allowing soil to dry slightly between waterings - French tarragon prefers lean, well-drained conditions and will develop root rot in heavy, wet soil. Full sun to partial shade (6+ hours daily); tolerates light afternoon shade. Fertilize sparingly, once or twice per season with dilute balanced fertilizer; rich soil diminishes the distinctive anise flavor. French tarragon does NOT produce viable seed and must be propagated by root division or cuttings - if you see tarragon seeds for sale, they are Russian tarragon which has inferior flavor. Divide plants every 3-4 years in spring to maintain vigor. Harvest regularly to encourage new growth; flavor is strongest just before flowering. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Evergreen shrub whose leaves produce black, green, oolong, and white tea.
commonExamples: Camellia sinensis (Tea plant, Tea shrub), C. sinensis var. assamica
careTips: Acidic soil (pH 4.5-5.5). Partial shade in hot climates. Avoid hard frost. Harvest young leaves (two leaves and a bud). Prune to encourage bush growth.

description: Also known as: Garden thyme. Perennial herbs in the Lamiaceae family with small aromatic leaves, drought-tolerant once established.
commonExamples: Thymus vulgaris (Common thyme, Garden thyme), T. citriodorus (Lemon thyme), T. serpyllum (Creeping thyme)
careTips: Water when soil is dry (every 1-2 weeks once established). Well-drained soil essential. Drought tolerant once established. Full sun preferred (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize sparingly in spring. Harvest regularly by cutting stems. Can be grown as groundcover or in containers. Perennial - may need protection in very cold climates. Reduce watering in winter when growth slows.

description: Rhizomatous herbs in the Zingiberaceae family, related to ginger, popular spice and natural dye.
commonExamples: Curcuma longa (Turmeric), common turmeric
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist but not waterlogged. Well-drained, rich soil preferred. Partial shade preferred. Fertilize monthly with balanced fertilizer. Plant rhizome pieces. Harvest when leaves die back (8-10 months). Can be grown in containers. Related to ginger. Popular spice and natural dye. Requires warm climate - protect from frost. Reduce watering in winter when growth slows.

description: Perennial herb in the Polygonaceae family with spicy, cilantro-like flavor. Essential in Vietnamese pho and salads. Not a true coriander; thrives in warm, moist conditions.
commonExamples: Persicaria odorata (Rau ram)
careTips: Water frequently and abundantly - Vietnamese coriander is a semi-aquatic plant that thrives in consistently wet to boggy conditions and will wilt rapidly if allowed to dry out. Partial shade to full shade (3-5 hours of sun daily); unlike most herbs, it prefers shade and its leaves scorch in intense direct sun. Fertilize every 2-3 weeks with a balanced liquid fertilizer during the growing season. An excellent cilantro substitute in hot climates since it does not bolt in heat. Propagates effortlessly from stem cuttings placed in water. Grows as a spreading ground cover in tropical areas; in temperate zones, bring containers indoors before frost as it is not frost hardy. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Prized in Japanese cuisine for its pungent, sinus-clearing flavor. Notoriously difficult to grow — requires cool, shady, humid conditions with clean running water.
commonExamples: Eutrema japonicum (syn. Wasabia japonica; Wasabi, Japanese horseradish)
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist — grows naturally along mountain stream beds. Cool shade essential; cannot tolerate heat above 20°C or direct sun. Very high humidity required. Extremely slow growing — takes 18-24 months to produce a usable rhizome. Non-toxic.

description: Perennial legume in the Fabaceae family. Major forage crop for hay and grazing. Nitrogen-fixing; deep roots. Also grown for sprouting.
commonExamples: Medicago sativa (Alfalfa)
careTips: Full sun. Well-drained, neutral to alkaline soil. Drought tolerant once established. Harvest hay at 10% bloom. Inoculate seed with rhizobia.

description: Pseudo-cereal in the Amaranthaceae family. Gluten-free grain; seeds high in protein. Drought tolerant. Ancient crop of the Americas.
commonExamples: Amaranthus cruentus
careTips: Full sun. Well-drained soil. Warm-season crop. Harvest when seed heads dry and seeds rattle. Thresh when fully dry.

description: Annual grass in the Poaceae family. Cereal grain for malt, feed, and food. Spring and winter types. Tolerates cooler climates than wheat.
commonExamples: Hordeum vulgare (Barley)
careTips: Full sun. Well-drained soil. Cool-season crop. Harvest when heads bend and kernels hard. Two-row and six-row varieties.

description: Pseudo-cereal in the Polygonaceae family. Gluten-free; fast-growing cover crop. White flowers attract pollinators. Short season (70–90 days).
commonExamples: Fagopyrum esculentum (Buckwheat)
careTips: Full sun. Any well-drained soil. Sow late spring to midsummer. Harvest when most seeds brown (lower seeds may shatter). Good green manure.

description: The tropical tree whose seeds are fermented and processed to produce chocolate, cocoa butter, and cocoa powder—one of the world's most economically important crops.
commonExamples: Theobroma cacao (Cacao, Chocolate tree), T. cacao Criollo group, T. cacao Forastero group, T. cacao Trinitario group
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist but not waterlogged; sensitive to both drought and standing water. Partial shade preferred—naturally an understory tree. Very high humidity (80%+) essential. Rich, well-draining acidic soil (pH 5.0-6.5). Fertilize monthly with balanced fertilizer during growing season. Flowers and fruits grow directly from the trunk (cauliflory). Needs temperatures above 18°C year-round. Theobromine in all parts is toxic to pets.

description: Also known as: Rapeseed. Oilseed crop in the Brassicaceae family. Low-erucic-acid rapeseed for edible oil and biodiesel. Yellow flowers. Spring and winter types.
commonExamples: Brassica napus (Canola, Rapeseed)
careTips: Full sun. Well-drained soil. Cool-season crop. Harvest when pods dry and seeds rattle. Swath or direct combine when ready.

description: Also known as: Manioc, Yuca, Tapioca. Tropical root crop and staple food for over 800 million people worldwide. Produces starchy tuberous roots used for flour, tapioca, and animal feed.
commonExamples: Manihot esculenta (Cassava, Manioc, Yuca, Tapioca)
careTips: Plant stem cuttings in well-drained soil after last frost. Full sun required. Water regularly during establishment, then drought-tolerant once established. Harvest roots 8-12 months after planting. Must be properly processed (soaked, fermented, or cooked) before eating to remove cyanogenic compounds. Prefers sandy loam. All raw parts toxic — must be processed before consumption.

description: Annual legume in the Fabaceae family. Desi and kabuli types. Nutrient-dense pulse; drought tolerant. Cool-season crop.
commonExamples: Cicer arietinum (Chickpea)
careTips: Full sun. Well-drained, neutral soil. Inoculate with rhizobia. Harvest when pods dry and rattle. Allow plants to dry before threshing.

description: Perennial legume in the Fabaceae family. Forage and cover crop. Nitrogen-fixing; pink flowers. Short-lived perennial (2–3 years).
commonExamples: Trifolium pratense
careTips: Full sun to partial shade. Well-drained soil. Inoculate seed. Harvest hay at early bloom. Good for rotation and soil building.

description: Low-growing perennial legume commonly used as a ground cover, living mulch, and forage crop. Fixes nitrogen in the soil. Attractive to pollinators with white flower heads.
commonExamples: Trifolium repens (White clover, Dutch clover), 'New Zealand White', 'Ladino' (giant white clover)
careTips: Water occasionally — quite drought tolerant once established. Full sun to partial shade. Adapts to most soil types. Self-seeding and spreading. Tolerates mowing and foot traffic. Often used as a lawn alternative or companion plant. Non-toxic.

description: Also known as: Arabian coffee. The glossy-leaved tropical shrub that produces the world's most popular beverage, also grown as an attractive houseplant with fragrant white flowers and red cherry-like fruits.
commonExamples: Coffea arabica (Arabica coffee, Arabian coffee), C. arabica 'Nana' (Dwarf coffee plant)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist but not soggy; water when top 2 cm dries. Bright indirect light—scorches in direct sun. High humidity (60%+) preferred; mist regularly. Rich, well-draining, acidic soil (pH 6.0-6.5). Fertilize every 2 weeks spring through summer with balanced acidic fertilizer. May produce fragrant white flowers and red berries indoors after 3-5 years. Prefers cool nights (15-18°C). All parts except the beans are toxic to pets (caffeine).

description: Annual grass in the Poaceae family. Grown for grain, silage, and ethanol. Distinguish from sweet corn; field corn harvested when kernels dry.
commonExamples: Zea mays (Corn)
careTips: Full sun. Rich, well-drained soil. Plant after soil warms. Heavy feeder—nitrogen critical. Harvest when husks dry and kernels hard (dent stage).

description: Annual shrub in the Malvaceae family. Grown for fiber (lint) and seed oil. Warm-season; needs long frost-free period. Upland and Pima types.
commonExamples: Gossypium hirsutum (Cotton)
careTips: Full sun. Well-drained soil. Warm-season crop. Harvest when bolls open and lint fluffs. Defoliate before pick for cleaner harvest.

description: Annual legume in the Fabaceae family. Drought and heat tolerant. Black-eyed pea, crowder types. Grown for dried peas and forage.
commonExamples: Vigna unguiculata (Cowpea)
careTips: Full sun. Well-drained soil. Warm-season. Harvest dry beans when pods brown and rattle. Bush and vining types available.

description: Annual legume in the Fabaceae family. Broad bean; cool-season crop. Large seeds for drying or fresh use. Some avoid raw—contains vicine.
commonExamples: Vicia faba (Fava bean)
careTips: Full sun. Cool-season—plant early spring or fall. Inoculate with rhizobia. Harvest green pods when plump or dry beans when pods brown.

description: Annual in the Linaceae family. Grown for fiber (linen) and seeds (linseed oil, omega-3). Blue flowers. Cool-season crop.
commonExamples: Linum usitatissimum (Flax)
careTips: Full sun. Well-drained soil. Plant early spring. Harvest when seed capsules brown (90–110 days). Fiber types pulled when flowering.

description: Fast-growing annual crop cultivated for thousands of years for its strong fibers, nutritious seeds, and versatile industrial applications including textiles, rope, paper, and building materials.
commonExamples: Cannabis sativa (Industrial hemp, Fiber hemp, Seed hemp)
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist during seedling stage; once established, moderate watering every 3-5 days. Full sun essential—at least 6 hours daily for optimal growth. Medium humidity fine. Deep, well-draining, nutrient-rich soil (pH 6.0-7.0). Heavy nitrogen feeder during vegetative growth; switch to phosphorus-potassium at flowering. Plant after last frost when soil reaches 10°C. Grows very fast—3-4 meters in one season. Non-toxic (industrial hemp contains negligible THC).

description: Perennial climbing vine in the Cannabaceae family. Cone-like flowers (strobiles) used in beer brewing. Dies back in winter; regrows from rhizomes.
commonExamples: Humulus lupulus (Hops)
careTips: Full sun. Well-drained soil. Provide tall support (15–20 ft). Toxic to dogs—causes dangerous fever. Harvest cones when papery and aromatic (late summer).

description: Annual legume in the Fabaceae family. Small lenticular seeds—red, green, brown. High protein pulse. Cool-season; drought tolerant.
commonExamples: Lens culinaris (Lentil)
careTips: Full sun. Well-drained soil. Cool-season crop. Harvest when pods dry and seeds rattle. Low-growing; combine or hand harvest.

description: Annual grass in the Poaceae family. Proso (common) millet and others. Gluten-free grain; drought tolerant. Short season (60–90 days).
commonExamples: Panicum miliaceum (Millet)
careTips: Full sun. Well-drained soil. Warm-season. Harvest when seed heads dry. Birds love it—harvest promptly when ripe.

description: Annual legume in the Fabaceae family. Small green beans for sprouting, dals, and noodles. Warm-season; drought tolerant.
commonExamples: Vigna radiata (Mung bean)
careTips: Full sun. Well-drained soil. Warm-season. Harvest dry beans when pods turn dark and rattle. Also grown for sprouts.

description: Oilseed and condiment crop in the Brassicaceae family. Brown, yellow, oriental mustard. Seeds for oil and spice. Cool-season.
commonExamples: Brassica juncea (Mustard)
careTips: Full sun. Well-drained soil. Cool-season. Harvest when pods dry and seeds rattle. Can be used as cover crop or green manure.

description: Annual grass in the Poaceae family. Cereal for oatmeal, feed, and hay. Cool-season; tolerates wetter soils than wheat. Spring and winter types.
commonExamples: Avena sativa (Oats)
careTips: Full sun. Tolerates heavy, moist soil. Cool-season crop. Harvest when panicles golden and kernels in hard-dough stage. Good nurse crop.

description: Annual legume in the Fabaceae family. Nuts develop underground (geocarpy). Valencia, Spanish, Virginia types. Warm-season; needs sandy soil.
commonExamples: Arachis hypogaea (Peanut)
careTips: Full sun. Light, sandy, well-drained soil. Warm-season. Harvest when foliage yellows; dig before frost. Cure 2–3 weeks before storage.

description: Also known as: Red gram, Gandules. Drought-hardy tropical legume widely grown in South Asia, Africa, and the Caribbean for its protein-rich seeds used in dal, soups, and stews.
commonExamples: Cajanus cajan (Pigeon pea, Red gram, Arhar dal, Toor dal, Gandules)
careTips: Drought-tolerant once established; water moderately during flowering and pod development. Full sun essential—at least 6 hours daily. Medium humidity fine. Tolerates poor soils—as a legume, it fixes nitrogen and actually improves soil fertility. Minimal fertilizer needed; too much nitrogen promotes leaves over pods. Can grow as an annual or short-lived perennial in frost-free areas. Pods can be harvested green or dry. Excellent intercrop companion. Non-toxic to humans and animals.

description: Pseudo-cereal in the Amaranthaceae family. Gluten-free; complete protein. Tolerates salinity and drought. Rinse seeds to remove saponins.
commonExamples: Chenopodium quinoa (Quinoa)
careTips: Full sun. Well-drained soil. Cool-season; frost tolerant. Harvest when seed heads dry and seeds rattle. Rinse before cooking.

description: Also known as: Canola. Major oil crop producing bright yellow flower fields across temperate regions. Seeds yield cooking oil (canola oil) and animal feed; also used for biodiesel production.
commonExamples: Brassica napus (Rapeseed, Canola), B. rapa (Field mustard, Turnip rape)
careTips: Sow in early spring or fall depending on variety (spring or winter type). Full sun required. Water regularly during flowering for best seed set. Harvest when pods turn brown. Prefers well-drained, fertile soil. Winter varieties need cold period for vernalization. Self-pollinating but benefits from bee activity. Non-toxic.

description: Annual grass in the Poaceae family. Staple grain grown in flooded paddies (lowland) or upland. Short-grain, long-grain, and aromatic varieties.
commonExamples: Oryza sativa (Rice)
careTips: Full sun. Lowland rice needs flooded fields or constant moisture. Upland rice tolerates drier conditions. Harvest when panicles golden and grains hard.

description: Annual grass in the Poaceae family. Cereal for bread, whiskey, and feed. Winter rye is cold-hardy cover crop. Tolerates poor soil.
commonExamples: Secale cereale (Rye)
careTips: Full sun. Tolerates poor, acidic soil. Winter rye planted fall. Harvest when heads golden. Excellent cover crop for biomass.

description: Annual oilseed in the Asteraceae family. High-heat cooking oil; once used for saffron-like dye. Drought tolerant. Spiny varieties deter birds.
commonExamples: Carthamus tinctorius
careTips: Full sun. Well-drained soil. Drought tolerant. Harvest when plants dry and seeds loosen. Oil and confection types available.

description: Annual in the Pedaliaceae family. Seeds for oil and tahini. Drought and heat tolerant. Capsules shatter when ripe—harvest carefully.
commonExamples: Sesamum indicum (Sesame)
careTips: Full sun. Warm, well-drained soil. Warm-season. Harvest when lower capsules brown—plants mature unevenly. Non-shattering varieties available.

description: Annual grass in the Poaceae family. Grain, syrup, forage, and biofuel. Drought tolerant. Grain, sweet, and broomcorn types.
commonExamples: Sorghum bicolor (Sorghum)
careTips: Full sun. Well-drained soil. Warm-season. Harvest grain when heads hard and red; syrup when stalks sweet. Frost-sensitive.

description: Annual legume in the Fabaceae family. Major protein and oil crop. Edamame (green), tofu, oil, feed. Nitrogen-fixing.
commonExamples: Glycine max (Soybean)
careTips: Full sun. Well-drained soil. Warm-season. Harvest when pods dry and beans rattle. Inoculate with rhizobia. Rotate with corn.

description: Root vegetable grown commercially for sugar production. Produces a large white conical root with up to 20% sugar content; accounts for about 30% of world sugar production.
commonExamples: Beta vulgaris subsp. vulgaris (Sugar beet)
careTips: Direct sow seeds 2cm deep after last frost, spacing 15cm apart. Full sun required. Keep soil consistently moist during root development. Harvest after 90-100 days when roots are 7-10cm diameter. Prefers loose, well-drained soil free of rocks. Fertilize at planting with balanced fertilizer. Cool-season crop; best in spring or fall. Non-toxic.

description: Perennial grass in the Poaceae family. Tropical crop for sugar and ethanol. Tall canes store sucrose. Ratoons (regrowth) for multiple harvests.
commonExamples: Saccharum officinarum (Sugarcane)
careTips: Full sun. Tropical—frost kills. Plant stem cuttings (setts). Harvest when canes mature (12–24 months). Needs abundant water and heat.

description: Annual in the Asteraceae family. Confection (snack) and oil types. Oil types have small black seeds; high in linoleic acid.
commonExamples: Helianthus annuus (Sunflower)
careTips: Full sun. Well-drained soil. Warm-season. Harvest when back of heads yellow and seeds dry. Protect from birds with bags or netting.

description: Perennial vine in the Convolvulaceae family, grown as annual. Starchy tuber roots; not a potato. Orange, white, purple flesh. Warm-season.
commonExamples: Ipomoea batatas (Sweet potato)
careTips: Full sun. Light, sandy soil. Warm-season. Plant slips. Harvest before frost when roots reach size. Cure 1–2 weeks for storage.

description: Annual grass in the Poaceae family. Tiny gluten-free grain; staple in Ethiopia. Drought tolerant. Seeds minuscule—harvest carefully.
commonExamples: Eragrostis tef
careTips: Full sun. Well-drained soil. Warm-season. Harvest when seed heads dry. Cut and cure in field; thresh carefully—seeds easily lost.

description: Annual herb in the Solanaceae family. Leaves contain nicotine; grown for commercial tobacco. Ornamental Nicotiana species differ. Not for consumption.
commonExamples: Nicotiana tabacum (Tobacco)
careTips: Full sun. Well-drained soil. Water regularly. Toxic to pets—nicotine in all plant parts. Keep away from animals and children.

description: Annual grass in the Poaceae family. World's major cereal crop. Bread wheat (T. aestivum) and durum. Spring and winter types by planting season.
commonExamples: Triticum aestivum (Wheat)
careTips: Full sun. Well-drained soil. Winter wheat planted fall; spring wheat in spring. Harvest when heads golden and kernels hard (combine or cut when dry).

description: Bean sprouts from adzuki beans. Crunchy, mild, nutty. Harvest in 4–6 days. Rinse 2–3× daily.
commonExamples: Vigna angularis
careTips: Soak seeds 8-12 hours. Rinse 2-3× daily; drain thoroughly. No light needed during sprouting. Harvest in 3-5 days when tails are 1-2 inches. Sweet, nutty flavor. No fertilizer needed. Rich in protein, fiber, and folate.

description: Classic delicate sprouts from alfalfa seeds. Mild flavor; harvest in 5–7 days. Rinse 2–3× daily.
commonExamples: Medicago sativa
careTips: Soak seeds 4-8 hours. Rinse 2× daily; drain well. Keep in dark first 3 days, then move to indirect light for greening. Harvest in 5-7 days. Mild, nutty flavor. No fertilizer. Rich in vitamins K and C. Store refrigerated up to 5 days.

description: Colorful microgreens from amaranth. Pink or green; mild. Harvest at first true leaves (7–12 days).
commonExamples: Amaranthus spp.
careTips: Sow on moist medium; mist to keep damp. Do not cover seeds (need light to germinate). Bright indirect light once sprouted. Mist 1-2× daily. Harvest in 8-12 days. Vibrant magenta stems with mild, earthy flavor. Rich in protein and lysine.

description: Peppery microgreens from arugula seeds. Fast-growing. Harvest at first true leaves (7–10 days).
commonExamples: Eruca vesicaria
careTips: Sow on moist medium; press gently. Mist 1-2× daily. Bright indirect light. Harvest in 7-10 days at first true leaves. Spicy, peppery flavor—milder than mature arugula. No fertilizer. Fast growing; great for beginners. Rich in vitamins A and K.

description: Aromatic microgreens from basil. Intense flavor. Harvest at first true leaves (10–14 days).
commonExamples: Ocimum basilicum
careTips: Soak seeds 2-4 hours (mucilaginous coating). Sow on moist medium. Mist 1-2× daily. Bright indirect light; warm conditions (20-25°C). Harvest in 10-16 days. Concentrated basil aroma. Slow germinator—be patient. Rich in polyphenols.

description: Vibrant red-stemmed microgreens from beet. Earthy, sweet. Harvest at first true leaves (10–14 days).
commonExamples: Beta vulgaris
careTips: Soak seed clusters 8-12 hours. Sow on moist medium, press in. Mist 1-2× daily. Bright indirect light. Harvest in 10-14 days. Stunning ruby-red stems with earthy, sweet flavor. Each 'seed' produces multiple sprouts. Rich in iron and betalains.

description: Mild mustard-like microgreens from broccoli raab. Harvest at first true leaves (8–12 days).
commonExamples: Brassica rapa var. ruvo
careTips: Sow on moist medium; mist to keep damp. Bright indirect light. Harvest in 7-10 days at cotyledon stage. Slightly spicy, broccoli-like flavor with a hint of mustard. No fertilizer. Rich in sulforaphane and vitamins A and C.

description: High-sulforaphane sprouts from broccoli seeds. Nutritious; harvest in 4–6 days. Rinse 2–3× daily.
commonExamples: Brassica oleracea var. italica
careTips: Soak seeds 6-8 hours. Rinse 2× daily; drain thoroughly. Keep dark first 3 days, then bright indirect light. Harvest in 5-7 days. Mild, slightly spicy. One of the richest food sources of sulforaphane—a potent antioxidant. Store refrigerated.

description: Nutty sprouts from buckwheat groats. Hulled for eating. Harvest when 1–2 in (3–5 days).
commonExamples: Fagopyrum esculentum
careTips: Soak seeds 15-30 minutes only (over-soaking causes mushiness). Rinse 2× daily; drain very well. Bright indirect light for greening. Harvest in 7-10 days. Mild, lettuce-like flavor. Remove hulls before eating. Rich in rutin and complete protein.

description: Fine, feathery microgreens from carrot. Slow to germinate. Harvest at first true leaves (14–21 days).
commonExamples: Daucus carota
careTips: Sow on moist medium; press in. Keep moist—mist 2× daily. Bright indirect light. Slow germinator; harvest in 14-18 days. Concentrated carrot flavor; wispy, feathery tops. Patience required—one of the slower microgreens. Rich in beta-carotene.

description: Strong cilantro flavor in microgreen form. Harvest at first true leaves (12–14 days).
commonExamples: Coriandrum sativum
careTips: Gently crush seed husks before soaking 8-12 hours. Sow on moist medium. Mist 1-2× daily. Bright indirect light. Harvest in 14-21 days. Full cilantro aroma; slow germinator. Each husk produces 2 plants. Rich in vitamins A and K.

description: Mild, delicate sprouts similar to alfalfa. Harvest in 5–7 days. Rinse 2–3× daily.
commonExamples: Trifolium spp.
careTips: Soak seeds 4-8 hours. Rinse 2× daily; drain well. Keep dark first 3 days, then move to indirect light. Harvest in 5-7 days. Mild, fresh, slightly sweet flavor. Tiny and delicate. No fertilizer. Rich in isoflavones and vitamins A and C.

description: Peppery, fast-growing sprouts. Harvest in 5–7 days. Can grow on paper towel.
commonExamples: Lepidium sativum
careTips: Sow on moist paper towel or medium; seeds stick when wet (mucilaginous). Mist 1-2× daily—do not rinse. Bright indirect light. Harvest in 5-7 days. Peppery, tangy flavor. One of the fastest and easiest microgreens. Rich in vitamins A, C, and K.

description: Aromatic dill flavor. Harvest at first true leaves (10–14 days).
commonExamples: Anethum graveolens
careTips: Sow on moist medium; press gently. Mist 1-2× daily. Bright indirect light. Harvest in 14-21 days at cotyledon stage. Concentrated dill flavor—excellent with fish and eggs. Slow germinator; requires patience. Rich in antioxidants.

description: Aromatic, slightly bitter sprouts. Curry-like. Harvest in 4–6 days. Rinse 2× daily.
commonExamples: Trigonella foenum-graecum
careTips: Soak seeds 8-12 hours. Rinse 2× daily; drain well. Keep dark. Harvest in 3-5 days. Slightly bitter, maple-like flavor; popular in Indian cuisine. Quick and easy to grow. Rich in iron, protein, and soluble fiber.

description: Nutritious microgreens; mild cabbage flavor. Harvest at first true leaves (8–12 days).
commonExamples: Brassica oleracea var. acephala
careTips: Sow on moist medium; press gently. Mist 1-2× daily. Bright indirect light. Harvest in 8-12 days. Mild, slightly sweet—less bitter than mature kale. Purple or green varieties. No fertilizer. Rich in vitamins A, C, K, and calcium.

description: Mild, sweet allium flavor, gentler than onion sprouts. Harvest at first true leaves (10–14 days).
commonExamples: Allium ampeloprasum
careTips: Soak seeds 8-12 hours. Sow on moist medium; keep damp. Mist 1-2× daily. Bright indirect light. Harvest in 12-14 days. Delicate onion-leek flavor, milder than mature leeks. Thin, elegant garnish. Rich in folate and vitamin K.

description: Bean sprouts from lentils. Earthy. Harvest in 3–5 days. Soak 8 hrs first.
commonExamples: Lens culinaris
careTips: Soak seeds 8-12 hours. Rinse 2-3× daily; drain thoroughly. Keep dark. Harvest in 3-5 days when tails are 1/2-1 inch. Mild, slightly sweet, earthy. Best cooked lightly or added to stir-fries. Rich in protein, iron, and folate.

description: Mild, mustard-like Japanese green. Harvest at first true leaves (8–12 days).
commonExamples: Brassica juncea var. japonica
careTips: Sow on moist medium; press gently. Mist 1-2× daily. Bright indirect light. Harvest in 7-10 days. Mild, peppery mustard flavor with serrated leaves. Japanese green; popular in salad mixes. Fast grower. Rich in vitamins A and C.

description: Classic Asian bean sprouts. Crunchy; harvest when 2–3 in (4–6 days). Rinse 2–3× daily.
commonExamples: Vigna radiata (Mung bean sprouts)
careTips: Soak seeds 8-12 hours. Rinse 2-3× daily; drain thoroughly. Keep dark for thick, white sprouts. Harvest in 3-5 days. Crisp, mild, slightly sweet. Staple in Asian cuisine—stir-fries, pho, spring rolls. Rich in vitamin C and protein.

description: Spicy, pungent microgreens. Red or green. Harvest at first true leaves (6–10 days).
commonExamples: Brassica juncea
careTips: Sow on moist medium; press gently. Mist 1-2× daily. Bright indirect light. Harvest in 7-10 days. Spicy, horseradish-like kick—among the most flavorful microgreens. Yellow, brown, or red varieties. Fast grower. Rich in vitamins A, C, and K.

description: Mild onion-flavored sprouts with a gentle allium bite. Harvest at first true leaves (10–14 days). Pre-soak seeds before planting.
commonExamples: Allium cepa
careTips: Soak seeds 8-12 hours. Sow on moist medium; keep damp. Mist 1-2× daily. Bright indirect light. Harvest in 10-14 days when 3-4 inches tall. Mild onion flavor; excellent garnish for soups and salads. Thin and elegant. Rich in quercetin and vitamin C.

description: Young pea plants grown from seeds, harvested for tender shoots and leaves. Quick-growing microgreen with sweet pea flavor.
commonExamples: Pisum sativum (Pea shoots, Pea tendrils)
careTips: Soak seeds 12-24 hours. Sow densely on moist medium. Water daily; drain well. Bright indirect light for greening. Harvest in 10-14 days by cutting above first node—may regrow for second harvest. Sweet, fresh pea flavor. Excellent in salads and stir-fries. Rich in vitamins A and C.

description: Spicy, colorful. Fast-growing. Harvest at first true leaves (6–10 days).
commonExamples: Raphanus sativus
careTips: Sow on moist medium; press gently. Mist 1-2× daily. Bright indirect light. Harvest in 5-8 days. Spicy, peppery crunch. One of the fastest and easiest microgreens to grow. Red-stemmed varieties are visually striking. Rich in vitamins A, B, C, E, and K.

description: Nutty, tender sprouts from sesame seeds. Harvest when 1–2 in (4–6 days). Rinse 2× daily. Hulled seeds preferred.
commonExamples: Sesamum indicum
careTips: Soak seeds 4-8 hours. Rinse 2× daily; drain well. Keep in dark. Harvest in 3-5 days. Mild, nutty sesame flavor. Small and delicate. Rinse thoroughly to remove seed coats. Rich in calcium, iron, and healthy fats.

description: Mint-basil flavored microgreens from shiso (perilla). Green or red. Harvest at first true leaves (10–14 days).
commonExamples: Perilla frutescens
careTips: Sow on moist medium; press gently—seeds need light. Mist 1-2× daily. Bright indirect light; warm conditions. Harvest in 14-21 days. Complex flavor—minty, basil-like with anise notes. Green or purple varieties. Slow germinator. Prized in Japanese cuisine.

description: Large bean sprouts from soybeans. Crunchy; cook before eating. Harvest when 2–3 in (4–6 days). Rinse 2× daily.
commonExamples: Glycine max (Soybean sprouts)
careTips: Soak seeds 12 hours. Rinse 2-3× daily; drain thoroughly. Keep dark and weighted for thick sprouts. Harvest in 4-6 days. Mild, bean-like flavor; best cooked (blanched or stir-fried). Staple in Korean cuisine (kongnamul). Rich in protein, isoflavones, and vitamin C.

description: Young seedlings harvested within 1-3 weeks of germination. Sprouts are grown in water only; microgreens are grown on a thin layer of soil or growing medium. Nutrient-dense and easy to grow indoors year-round. Popular mixes combine varied flavors, colors, and textures.
commonExamples: Broccoli sprouts, Alfalfa sprouts, Sunflower microgreens, Pea shoots, Radish microgreens, Wheatgrass, Mixed microgreen blends
careTips: Mist or water lightly 1-2 times daily to keep seeds and growing medium moist. Never let dry out, but avoid standing water which causes mold. Bright indirect light preferred (a windowsill or grow light). Good air circulation essential to prevent mold and damping off. No fertilizer needed — seeds contain all necessary nutrients. Use clean, food-safe containers and fresh seeds. Harvest sprouts in 3-7 days, microgreens in 7-14 days. Rinse sprouts twice daily. Succession sow every few days for continuous harvest.

description: Nutty, crunchy sunflower sprouts. Use hulled seeds. Harvest when 1–2 in (7–10 days).
commonExamples: Helianthus annuus (Sunflower sprouts, Sunflower microgreens)
careTips: Soak seeds 8-12 hours. Sow on moist medium; cover 2 days for germination. Mist 1-2× daily. Bright indirect light once sprouted. Harvest in 7-12 days when cotyledons are fully open. Nutty, crunchy flavor. Rich in protein, vitamin E, and healthy fats. Remove hulls before eating.

description: Mild brassica; spoon-shaped leaves. Harvest at first true leaves (8–12 days).
commonExamples: Brassica rapa var. rosularis
careTips: Sow on moist medium; press gently. Mist 1-2× daily. Bright indirect light. Harvest in 7-10 days. Mild, creamy mustard flavor with rounded spoon-shaped leaves. Asian green; excellent in salad mixes. Fast grower. Rich in vitamins A, C, and calcium.

description: Mild, slightly peppery. Harvest at first true leaves (8–12 days).
commonExamples: Brassica rapa
careTips: Sow on moist medium; press gently. Mist 1-2× daily. Bright indirect light. Harvest in 7-10 days. Mild, slightly spicy, turnip-like flavor. Fast and reliable grower—good for beginners. Rich in vitamins A, C, and K.

description: Peppery, nutrient-dense sprouts from the aquatic watercress plant. One of the oldest known leaf vegetables. Rich in iron, calcium, and vitamins K and C. Harvest in 5-7 days. Keep constantly moist—watercress naturally grows in shallow running water.
commonExamples: Nasturtium officinale
careTips: Mist 2× daily—keep constantly moist; watercress is semi-aquatic. Bright indirect light. Harvest in 5-7 days. Peppery, slightly bitter flavor. Can grow on wet paper towel without soil. Rich in iron, calcium, and vitamins K and C. One of the oldest known leaf vegetables.

description: Juiced or chewed; nutrient-dense. Harvest when 6–8 in (7–10 days). Second cut possible.
commonExamples: Triticum aestivum (Wheat sprouts)
careTips: Soak seeds 8-12 hours. Sow on moist medium or coconut coir. Water 1-2× daily; avoid waterlogging. Bright indirect light, 18-22°C. Harvest at 6-7 inches (7-10 days) by cutting above the root. Juice fresh for maximum nutrition—rich in chlorophyll, vitamins A, C, E, and minerals.

description: Ornamental flowering bulbs in the Amaryllidaceae family, include edible onions and ornamental varieties.
commonExamples: Allium (Ornamental onion), A. giganteum (Giant allium), A. cristophii (Star of Persia), A. 'Purple Sensation', A. sphaerocephalon (Drumstick allium)
careTips: Keep soil moist during growth and flowering. Allow to dry after foliage dies back. Plant bulbs in fall. Full sun preferred. Well-drained soil essential. Fertilize when shoots emerge. Ornamental varieties have large, spherical flower heads. Naturalize well. Allow foliage to die back naturally. Deterrent to many pests. Perfect for borders and cut flowers. Bulbs go dormant after flowering; reduce watering when foliage dies back.

description: Also known as: Hippeastrum. Large flowering bulbs in the Amaryllidaceae family, popular for indoor winter forcing, can rebloom with proper care.
commonExamples: Hippeastrum (Amaryllis), various colors and cultivars, single and double varieties
careTips: Keep soil moist during active growth and flowering. Reduce watering after flowering as foliage dies back. For forcing: plant in fall, keep in cool dark place until shoots appear, then move to bright light. For outdoor: plant in spring in warm climates. Bright indirect to direct light. Fertilize monthly during active growth. Can rebloom with proper dormancy care. Large, showy flowers. Perfect for holiday displays.

description: Also known as: Poppy anemone. Spring-blooming tuberous perennials. Anemone blanda (early) and A. coronaria (poppy). Plant in fall; dormant after flowering.
commonExamples: Anemone coronaria (Poppy anemone)
careTips: Keep moist during growth and bloom. Full sun to partial shade. Plant tubers in fall. Reduce watering when foliage dies back. Allow foliage to yellow before removing. Toxic to pets.

description: Plants that grow from underground storage organs (bulbs, corms, tubers, rhizomes). Many are spring-flowering and require a winter chilling period.
commonExamples: Tulipa (Tulip), Narcissus (Daffodil), Crocus, Hyacinthus (Hyacinth), Lilium (Lily), Allium
careTips: Water moderately during active growth — keep soil moist but not waterlogged. Reduce watering as foliage yellows and dies back after flowering. Do not cut foliage until fully brown — leaves feed the bulb for next year. Plant at depth of 2-3 times bulb height. Full sun to partial shade depending on species. Fertilize at planting and again when shoots emerge in spring with balanced bulb fertilizer. Lift and store tender bulbs before frost in cold climates. Many spring bulbs need a winter chill period to bloom. Research specific species for exact requirements.

description: Also known as: Arum lily. Tuberous aroid with elegant spathe flowers in white, pink, or dark cultivars. Grown as houseplant or garden bulb; goes dormant after bloom.
commonExamples: Zantedeschia spp. (Calla, Arum lily)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist during growth and flowering. Reduce watering when foliage yellows; allow dormancy. Bright indirect light indoors; full sun to partial shade outdoors. Well-draining soil. Fertilize monthly during active growth. Toxic to humans and pets if ingested; causes mouth and throat irritation.

description: Also known as: Common camas, Small camas. Native North American bulb producing tall spikes of starry blue, purple, or white flowers in late spring—historically an important food source for Indigenous peoples.
commonExamples: Camassia quamash (Common camas, Small camas), C. leichtlinii (Great camas, Large camas), C. leichtlinii 'Alba' (White camas)
careTips: Water regularly during spring growth and flowering; allow to go dry after foliage dies back in summer (summer dormant). Full sun to partial shade. Medium humidity fine. Prefers moist, moisture-retentive clay or loam soil that dries out in summer—perfect for seasonal wet meadows. Minimal fertilizer needed; top-dress with compost in fall. Plant bulbs in fall, 10-15 cm deep. Naturalizes beautifully in lawns and meadows. Leave foliage to die back naturally. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Tender rhizomatous bulbs with bold foliage and tropical flowers. Summer bloomer; lift before frost or mulch in zone 8+.
commonExamples: Canna × generalis (Canna lily)
careTips: Full sun. Rich, moist soil. Water regularly in summer. Fertilize monthly. Lift rhizomes after frost; store dry over winter. Replant in spring.

description: Early spring bulb with blue star flowers. Naturalizes well. Plant in fall. Dormant after bloom.
commonExamples: Chionodoxa forbesii
careTips: Full sun to partial shade. Well-drained soil. Plant bulbs in fall. Keep moist during growth; reduce when foliage dies. Allow foliage to yellow naturally. Toxic to pets.

description: Early spring flowering bulbs in the Iridaceae family, among first flowers to bloom, naturalize well.
commonExamples: Crocus vernus (Spring crocus), C. chrysanthus (Golden crocus), C. sativus (Saffron crocus), C. tommasinianus (Tommasini's crocus)
careTips: Keep soil moist during growth and flowering (spring). Allow to dry naturally after foliage dies back. Plant bulbs in fall (6-8 weeks before ground freezes). Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize when shoots emerge. Among first flowers to bloom in spring. Naturalize well - will spread over time. Allow foliage to die back naturally. Perfect for naturalizing in lawns or under trees. Bulbs go dormant after flowering; reduce watering when foliage dies back.

description: Fall-blooming crocus. Red stigmas yield saffron spice. Dormant summer; leaves appear spring, flowers fall.
commonExamples: Crocus sativus (Saffron)
careTips: Full sun. Well-drained soil. Water when leaves present (spring) and during bloom (fall). Harvest stigmas when flowers open. Dry before storing. Mildly toxic to pets—may cause GI upset.

description: Tuberous perennials with heart-shaped leaves. Florist cyclamen blooms winter; goes dormant in summer. Cool temperatures essential.
commonExamples: Cyclamen persicum (Florist's cyclamen)
careTips: Bright indirect light. Cool (60–68°F). Water when soil dry; avoid crown. Reduce watering when leaves yellow (summer dormancy). Resume when new growth appears. Toxic to pets.

description: Also known as: Jonquil. Spring-blooming bulbous perennials in the Amaryllidaceae family, planted in fall, naturalize well and are deer-resistant.
commonExamples: Narcissus (Daffodil, Jonquil), N. pseudonarcissus (Wild daffodil), trumpet, large-cupped, small-cupped, double, and miniature varieties
careTips: Keep soil moist during growth and flowering (spring). Allow to dry after foliage dies back. Plant bulbs in fall (6-8 weeks before ground freezes) with pointed end up, 4-6 inches deep. Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize when shoots emerge and after flowering with bulb fertilizer. Allow foliage to die back naturally - don't cut until yellow. Naturalize well and multiply over time. Deer and rodent resistant. Excellent for naturalizing in lawns and gardens. Bulbs go dormant after flowering; reduce watering when foliage dies back.

description: Also known as: Garden dahlia. Tender tubers with showy summer flowers. Thousands of cultivars. Lift before frost; store dry over winter.
commonExamples: Dahlia pinnata (Garden dahlia)
careTips: Full sun. Rich, well-drained soil. Water regularly; stake tall varieties. Deadhead for continuous bloom. Lift tubers after frost; store in cool, dry place. Toxic to pets.

description: Fragrant spring corms. Plant in fall (mild climates) or spring. Tubular flowers in many colors. Tender—lift in cold zones.
commonExamples: Freesia × hybrida
careTips: Full sun. Well-drained soil. Plant corms 2 in deep. Keep moist during growth. Reduce when foliage yellows. Lift and store in cold-winter areas. Toxic to pets.

description: Also known as: Snake's head. Spring bulbs with nodding, checkered or crown-shaped flowers. Snake's head (F. meleagris) and crown imperial. Plant in fall.
commonExamples: Fritillaria meleagris (Snake's head)
careTips: Full sun to partial shade. Moist, well-drained soil. Plant bulbs on side (hollow crown). Keep moist during growth. Dormant after flowering. Toxic to pets.

description: Also known as: Garden gladiolus. Summer flowering bulbs in the Iridaceae family with tall spikes of colorful flowers, excellent for cut flowers.
commonExamples: Gladiolus × hortulanus (Garden gladiolus), various colors and sizes, dwarf and standard varieties
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist during growth and flowering (summer). Plant corms in spring after last frost. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize when shoots emerge and during flowering. Stake tall varieties. Lift corms in fall in cold climates and store over winter. Allow foliage to die back before lifting. Excellent for cut flowers. Plant in succession for continuous blooms. Bulbs go dormant after flowering; reduce watering when foliage dies back.

description: Fragrant spring flowering bulbs in the Asparagaceae family, can be forced indoors or grown outdoors.
commonExamples: Hyacinthus orientalis (Common hyacinth, Dutch hyacinth), various colors and cultivars
careTips: Keep soil moist during growth and flowering. Allow to dry after foliage dies back. Plant bulbs in fall (6-8 weeks before ground freezes). Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize when shoots emerge. Very fragrant flowers. Can be forced indoors with pre-chilling. Naturalize slowly. Allow foliage to die back naturally. Perfect for spring borders and containers. Bulbs go dormant after flowering; reduce watering when foliage dies back.

description: Hybrid spring bulb with slender stems and elegant flowers in blue, purple, white, or yellow. Plant in fall for spring bloom; goes dormant after flowering.
commonExamples: Iris × hollandica (Dutch iris)
careTips: Plant bulbs in fall, 4–5 inches deep. Full sun. Well-drained soil essential. Water during spring growth and bloom; allow foliage to yellow before cutting back. Fertilize when shoots emerge. Bulbs go dormant in summer—no watering needed. Suitable for beds, borders, and cut flowers. Toxic to pets.

description: Also known as: Lily. Bulbous perennial flowering plants in the Liliaceae family with showy trumpet-shaped or recurved flowers, many are fragrant.
commonExamples: Lilium (Lily, Easter lily, Oriental lily, Asiatic lily), L. longiflorum (Easter lily), Oriental hybrids, Asiatic hybrids, L. candidum (Madonna lily)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist during growth and flowering (spring-summer). Allow to dry slightly after flowering. Well-drained soil essential - avoid waterlogged conditions. Full sun to partial shade depending on species. Fertilize when shoots emerge and after flowering with bulb fertilizer. Plant bulbs in fall or early spring. Mulch to keep roots cool. Remove spent flowers but leave foliage until yellow. Divide bulbs every 3-4 years. Many are fragrant. Research specific type for exact requirements. Bulbs go dormant after flowering; reduce watering when foliage dies back.

description: Early summer lily with upright, unscented flowers. Cold hardy. Plant in fall or spring. Multiply by scales or division.
commonExamples: Lilium (Asiatic hybrids)
careTips: Full sun. Well-drained soil. Plant bulbs 4–6 in deep. Keep moist during growth. Stake if needed. Toxic to cats.

description: Also known as: Compact calla. Compact Zantedeschia with smaller spathes. Colors include pink, yellow, orange. Toxic to pets.
commonExamples: Zantedeschia rehmannii (Compact calla)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Light requirements vary by species. Fertilize during growing season. Toxic to humans and pets if ingested; causes mouth and throat irritation.

description: Fragrant late-summer lilies. Large, often spotted flowers. Stargazer and Casablanca types. Toxic to cats.
commonExamples: Lilium Oriental hybrids (Oriental lily), 'Casa Blanca' (White fragrant), 'Stargazer' (Pink spotted), 'Muscadet' (White spotted)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Light requirements vary by species. Fertilize during growing season. Highly toxic to cats; can cause kidney failure. Mildly toxic to humans if ingested.

description: Orange Turk's-cap lily with black spots. Lilium lancifolium. Naturalizes; can spread. Toxic to cats.
commonExamples: Lilium lancifolium (Tiger lily)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Light requirements vary by species. Fertilize during growing season. Highly toxic to cats; can cause kidney failure. Mildly toxic to humans if ingested.

description: Early spring bulb with grape-like blue flowers. Naturalizes aggressively. Plant in fall. Dormant after bloom.
commonExamples: Muscari armeniacum (Grape hyacinth)
careTips: Full sun to partial shade. Well-drained soil. Plant bulbs in fall. Keep moist during growth. Allow foliage to yellow. Can spread—contain if desired.

description: Shamrock-like bulbs with triangular leaves. Purple or green. Can go dormant in summer. Often grown as houseplant.
commonExamples: Oxalis triangularis (Bulbous oxalis)
careTips: Bright indirect light. Water when soil dry. Reduce when leaves die back (dormancy). Resume when new growth appears. Toxic to pets in large amounts.

description: Spring tuber with layered, rose-like flowers. Soak tubers before planting. Plant in fall (mild) or spring. Dormant after bloom.
commonExamples: Ranunculus asiaticus (Persian buttercup)
careTips: Full sun. Well-drained soil. Soak tubers 4 hrs before planting. Keep moist during growth. Reduce when foliage yellows. Lift in cold zones. Toxic to pets.

description: Tuberous perennial producing exquisite, densely layered paper-thin petals in warm shades of yellow, orange, red, pink, and white; a favorite for spring bouquets.
commonExamples: Ranunculus asiaticus (Persian buttercup), R. asiaticus 'Tecolote' series, R. asiaticus 'Amandine' series, R. asiaticus 'Butterfly' series
careTips: Soak dried tubers (claw-side down) for 3-4 hours before planting. Water regularly during active growth to keep soil evenly moist but never soggy. Full sun to light shade in hot climates; prefers cool spring temperatures (10-20°C) for best blooms. Well-drained soil is critical — tubers rot in wet conditions. Fertilize every 2 weeks during growth with balanced liquid fertilizer. Stop watering when foliage yellows after blooming; lift tubers in cold zones (below zone 8) and store dry. Toxic to pets — all parts contain protoanemonin.

description: Early spring bulb with blue bell flowers. Siberian squill naturalizes well. Plant in fall. Dormant after bloom.
commonExamples: Scilla siberica (Siberian squill)
careTips: Full sun to partial shade. Well-drained soil. Plant bulbs in fall. Keep moist during growth. Reduce when foliage dies. Allow leaves to yellow naturally. Toxic to pets.

description: One of the earliest spring bulbs, often blooming through snow. Dainty nodding white flowers with green markings appear from late winter to early spring.
commonExamples: Galanthus nivalis (Common snowdrop), G. elwesii (Giant snowdrop), G. 'Sam Arnott', G. plicatus
careTips: Plant bulbs in fall, 7-10cm deep and 7cm apart. Moist, well-drained soil during growing season; tolerate summer dormancy dry-out. Partial shade under deciduous trees is ideal — they bloom before leaves emerge. Do not remove foliage until it yellows naturally. Best divided 'in the green' (while still in leaf) after flowering. Naturalizes well in lawns and woodland. Mildly toxic if ingested.

description: Highly fragrant summer bulb. White tubular flowers. Tender—lift before frost. Used in perfumery.
commonExamples: Agave amica (Polianthes tuberosa)
careTips: Full sun. Well-drained soil. Plant when soil warm. Water regularly. Stake if needed. Lift tubers after frost; store dry. Replant in spring. Mildly toxic to pets—may cause GI upset.
