description: Spring-blooming bulbous perennials in the Liliaceae family, planted in fall for spring flowers, many varieties available.
commonExamples: Tulipa (Tulip), T. gesneriana (Garden tulip), single early, double early, triumph, Darwin hybrid, parrot, and fringed varieties
careTips: Keep soil moist during growth and flowering (spring). Allow to dry after foliage dies back. Plant bulbs in fall (6-8 weeks before ground freezes) with pointed end up, 6-8 inches deep. Full sun preferred. Fertilize when shoots emerge and after flowering with bulb fertilizer. Allow foliage to die back naturally to feed bulbs - don't cut until yellow. Many varieties are treated as annuals in warm climates. Research variety type for exact requirements and bloom time. Bulbs go dormant after flowering; reduce watering when foliage dies back.

description: Plants that grow fully or partially submerged in water, include floating, submerged, and emergent types.
commonExamples: Nymphaea (Water lily), Nelumbo (Lotus, Sacred lotus), Eichhornia (Water hyacinth), Pistia (Water lettuce)
careTips: Fully submerged or floating in water - no soil watering needed. Maintain water quality - clean, oxygenated water essential. Full sun to partial shade depending on species. Fertilize with aquatic plant fertilizer tablets placed in soil or water. Remove dead leaves and flowers regularly. Control algae growth. Some species are invasive - check local regulations. Water depth varies by species. Research specific plant for exact requirements. Perfect for ponds and water gardens. Aquatic; winter care varies by Hardiness Zone.

description: Also known as: Duck potato. Aquatic pond plant (Sagittaria)—not the houseplant Arrowhead plant (Syngonium). Arrow-shaped leaves; grows in shallow water or pond edges. Edible tubers (duck potato).
commonExamples: Sagittaria latifolia (Duck potato)
careTips: Shallow water (2–12 in) or saturated soil. Full sun. Plant in pond margin or container. Divide when crowded. No soil watering—plant in water.

description: Plants adapted to constantly wet or waterlogged soil, ideal for water gardens and pond edges.
commonExamples: Cyperus papyrus (Papyrus, Egyptian paper reed), Canna (Canna lily), Iris pseudacorus (Yellow flag iris), Sagittaria (Arrowhead)
careTips: Keep soil constantly moist or waterlogged - never allow to dry out. Can grow in shallow water (up to 6 inches). Full sun to partial shade depending on species. Fertilize monthly during growing season with aquatic plant fertilizer. Ideal for water gardens and pond edges. Some species spread aggressively - contain with barriers. Remove dead foliage. Research specific plant for exact requirements. Adapted to constantly wet conditions. Aquatic; winter care varies by Hardiness Zone.

description: Emergent wetland plants in the Typhaceae family, grow in shallow water or wet soil, can be invasive.
commonExamples: Typha latifolia (Common cattail, Broadleaf cattail), T. angustifolia (Narrowleaf cattail), T. domingensis (Southern cattail)
careTips: Grow in shallow water (6-12 inches) or constantly wet soil. Never allow to dry out. Full sun preferred. Fertilize sparingly if at all. Spreads aggressively by rhizomes - contain with barriers or grow in containers. Remove seed heads to prevent spread. Can be invasive - check local regulations. Perfect for pond edges and water gardens. Provides wildlife habitat. Aquatic; winter care varies by Hardiness Zone.

description: Tiny floating plants. Rapid spread; provides shade and filtration. Can be invasive. Often used in aquariums and small ponds.
commonExamples: Lemna minor (Common duckweed)
careTips: Floats on still water. Full sun to partial shade. No planting—add to water surface. Control spread; remove excess. Provides habitat for tiny aquatic life.

description: The largest water lily in the world, with circular floating pads up to 3m in diameter that can support the weight of a child. White flowers bloom at night.
commonExamples: Victoria amazonica (Giant water lily), V. cruziana (Santa Cruz water lily), V. 'Longwood Hybrid'
careTips: Requires large warm pool or pond with still, warm water (25-32°C). Full sun essential for pad development. Heavy feeder — fertilize heavily with aquatic plant tablets. Grown as annual in temperate climates; start seeds in warm water in late winter. Each pad lives about 2 weeks before being replaced by a new one. Protect from wind. Non-toxic.

description: Aquatic plants grown indoors in water containers or hydroponic setups.
commonExamples: Dracaena sanderiana (Lucky bamboo), Pothos in water, Philodendron in water, Spider plant in water
careTips: Keep roots submerged in water at all times. Change water weekly to prevent stagnation and algae growth. Use filtered or distilled water to avoid mineral buildup. Bright indirect light preferred. Add liquid fertilizer monthly at quarter strength. Clean container monthly. Some plants can transition from soil to water. Perfect for hydroponic setups or decorative water containers. Research specific plant for exact requirements. Aquatic; winter care varies by Hardiness Zone.

description: Also known as: Sacred Lotus, Indian Lotus. Aquatic perennial with iconic round leaves and showy flowers rising above the water. Edible roots (lotus root), seeds, and leaves widely used in Asian cuisine. Spiritual significance in many cultures.
commonExamples: Nelumbo nucifera (Lotus, Sacred lotus, Indian lotus), various colors and sizes
careTips: Grow in shallow to deep water (6-24 inches). Never allow to dry out. Full sun essential. Fertilize with aquatic plant fertilizer tablets. Plant tubers in spring. Beautiful flowers bloom above water. Edible roots (lotus root), seeds, and leaves. Can be invasive - contain with barriers. Important in Chinese culture and Buddhism. Requires water garden or pond. Aquatic; winter care varies by Hardiness Zone.

description: Tall marginal aquatic. Egyptian papyrus grows in shallow water or wet soil. Dramatic upright stems with fluffy tops.
commonExamples: Cyperus papyrus (Egyptian papyrus)
careTips: Shallow water or saturated soil. Full sun. Tropical—protect from frost. Can grow in submerged pots. Fertilize occasionally in growing season.

description: Emergent aquatic plants in the Pontederiaceae family with spikes of blue flowers, ideal for pond margins.
commonExamples: Pontederia cordata (Pickerelweed, Pickerel rush)
careTips: Grow in shallow water (up to 12 inches) or constantly wet soil. Never allow to dry out. Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize monthly during growing season with aquatic plant fertilizer. Spreads by rhizomes - may need containment. Remove spent flowers to prevent self-seeding. Perfect for pond margins and water gardens. Attracts pollinators. Provides wildlife habitat. Aquatic; winter care varies by Hardiness Zone.

description: Cyperus (umbrella plant) for water gardens. Stems topped with umbel leaf whorls. Thrives in saturated soil or shallow water.
commonExamples: Cyperus alternifolius (Umbrella papyrus)
careTips: Shallow water or saturated soil. Full sun to partial shade. Keep roots wet. Tropical—protect from frost. No soil watering—grown in water.

description: The world's largest water lily with enormous circular pads up to 3 meters across that can support a child's weight, producing spectacular night-blooming white-to-pink flowers.
commonExamples: Victoria amazonica (Amazon water lily, Royal water lily), V. cruziana (Santa Cruz water lily), V. 'Longwood Hybrid'
careTips: Fully aquatic—grow in still, warm water at least 60 cm deep. Full sun essential—at least 8 hours daily for pad development. Very high humidity (naturally provided by water). Rich, heavy clay-loam pond soil topped with gravel. Feed heavily with aquatic plant fertilizer tablets pushed into soil monthly. Water temperature must stay above 20°C—grown as annual in temperate climates. Pads have sharp spines underneath. Flowers open white at night, turn pink by morning, then close and submerge. Non-toxic.

description: Floating aquatic with fragrant white flowers. Aponogeton blooms spring and fall. Submerged planting; leaves float.
commonExamples: Aponogeton distachyos
careTips: Plant in 6–18 in water. Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize with pond tabs. Can go dormant in hot summer. Flowers float on surface.

description: Floating aquatic with purple flowers. Highly invasive—illegal in some areas. Provides shade and filtration. Check local regulations.
commonExamples: Eichhornia crassipes (Floating water hyacinth)
careTips: Floats on still water. Full sun. No planting—add to surface. Remove excess to control spread. Illegal in many US states—check before growing.

description: Iris species adapted to wet conditions, grow in shallow water or boggy soil, ideal for water gardens.
commonExamples: Iris laevigata (Japanese water iris), I. pseudacorus (Yellow flag iris), I. versicolor (Blue flag iris)
careTips: Grow in shallow water (up to 6 inches) or constantly wet, boggy soil. Never allow to dry out. Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize monthly during growing season with aquatic plant fertilizer. Divide every 3-4 years to maintain vigor. Remove dead foliage. Perfect for pond edges and water gardens. Some species can be invasive - check local regulations. Aquatic; winter care varies by Hardiness Zone. Toxic to pets—rhizomes especially; keep away from pets.

description: Floating rosettes resembling lettuce. Spreads rapidly. Invasive in warm climates. Provides shade. Check local regulations.
commonExamples: Pistia stratiotes
careTips: Floats on still water. Full sun. No planting—add to surface. Control spread; remove excess. Illegal in some areas. Tropical—frost kills. Toxic to pets—keep away from pets.

description: Classic floating aquatic. Leaves and flowers float on surface. Plant in pots at pond bottom. Hardy and tropical types.
commonExamples: Nymphaea spp. (Water lily)
careTips: Full sun. Plant in soil at 6–18 in depth. Use aquatic pots. Fertilize with pond tabs. Remove yellow leaves. Trim roots when repotting. Mildly toxic to pets—may cause GI upset if ingested.

description: Also known as: Pinguicula. Carnivorous plants in the Lentibulariaceae family with sticky leaves that trap insects, include temperate and tropical species.
commonExamples: Pinguicula moranensis (Mexican butterwort), P. agnata, P. gigantea (Giant butterwort), P. vulgaris (Common butterwort), P. esseriana
careTips: Constant moisture with distilled or rainwater ONLY - never tap water. Keep in tray of water (1-2 inches deep). Bright indirect light preferred. High humidity (60-70%+) preferred. Use only sphagnum peat moss or specialized carnivorous plant soil. Don't fertilize - they get nutrients from insects. Temperate species require dormancy; tropical species do not. Sticky leaves trap small insects. Research specific species for exact requirements.

description: Plants that attract, trap, and digest insects and other small prey. Adapted to nutrient-poor boggy conditions with high humidity and acidic, low-nutrient soil.
commonExamples: Dionaea muscipula (Venus flytrap), Drosera (Sundew), Nepenthes (Tropical pitcher plant), Sarracenia (North American pitcher plant), Pinguicula (Butterwort)
careTips: Use only distilled, rainwater, or reverse-osmosis water — minerals in tap water damage or kill carnivorous plants. Keep soil consistently moist; many prefer the tray method (sitting in 1 inch of water). Use nutrient-free soil (pure peat or sphagnum with perlite — never potting mix). Bright light essential (4-6 hours direct sun or strong grow lights). High humidity (50-80%) preferred. Never fertilize through soil. Do not trigger traps for fun — wastes plant energy. Many temperate species require winter dormancy (cool, reduced light). Research specific genus for exact requirements.

description: Also known as: Darlingtonia. Unique carnivorous plant in the Sarraceniaceae family native to California and Oregon, requires cool conditions.
commonExamples: Darlingtonia californica (Cobra lily, California pitcher plant, Darlingtonia)
careTips: Constant moisture with distilled or rainwater ONLY - never tap water. Keep in tray of water (1-2 inches deep). Prefer cool conditions - avoid heat. Bright indirect to direct light. High humidity (60%+) preferred. Use only sphagnum peat moss or specialized carnivorous plant soil. Don't fertilize - they get nutrients from insects. Require dormancy period in winter. Unique cobra-like appearance. Very challenging to grow outside native range.

description: Popular tropical sundew from South Africa, easy to grow and forgiving of beginners. No dormancy required. Produces tall flower stalks and abundant sticky dew.
commonExamples: Drosera capensis (Cape sundew)
careTips: Constant moisture with distilled or rainwater ONLY - never tap water. Keep in tray of water (1-2 inches deep). Bright indirect to direct light (6-8 hrs ideal). High humidity (50-70%) preferred. Use only sphagnum peat moss or specialized carnivorous plant soil. Don't fertilize - they get nutrients from insects. No dormancy needed. One of the easiest carnivorous plants to grow.

description: Tropical pitcher plants (monkey cups) from Southeast Asia with hanging pitcher traps. Highlanders and lowlanders have different temperature needs.
commonExamples: Nepenthes spp. (Tropical pitcher plant, Monkey cups)
careTips: Constant moisture with distilled or rainwater ONLY - never tap water. Water when top of medium feels dry; avoid waterlogging. Bright indirect to filtered light. High humidity (60-80%+) essential - often grown in terrariums. Use only sphagnum moss or specialized carnivorous plant mix. Don't fertilize - they get nutrients from insects. No dormancy. Research highlander vs lowlander requirements for your species.

description: Carnivorous plants with modified leaves forming pitcher-shaped traps, include temperate and tropical species.
commonExamples: Sarracenia (North American pitcher plant), Nepenthes (Tropical pitcher plant, Monkey cups), Darlingtonia (Cobra lily)
careTips: Constant moisture with distilled or rainwater ONLY - never tap water. Keep in tray of water (1-2 inches deep). Bright indirect to direct light depending on species. High humidity (60-70%+) preferred. Use only sphagnum peat moss or specialized carnivorous plant soil. Don't fertilize - they get nutrients from insects. Temperate species require dormancy; tropical species do not. Fill pitchers with water if they dry out. Research specific species for exact requirements.

description: Also known as: Trumpet pitcher. North American pitcher plants native to boggy regions. Upright or hooded pitchers trap insects. Require winter dormancy. Can be grown outdoors in zones 6-9.
commonExamples: Sarracenia spp. (North American pitcher plant, Trumpet pitcher)
careTips: Constant moisture with distilled or rainwater ONLY - never tap water. Keep in tray of water (1-2 inches deep). Bright indirect to full sun (4-6 hrs). High humidity (60%+) preferred. Use only sphagnum peat moss or specialized carnivorous plant soil. Don't fertilize - they get nutrients from insects. Require dormancy in winter (cooler temps, reduced watering). Fill pitchers with water if they dry out.

description: Also known as: Drosera. Carnivorous plants in the Droseraceae family with sticky, dewy leaves that trap insects.
commonExamples: Drosera (Sundew), D. capensis (Cape sundew), D. rotundifolia (Round-leaved sundew), temperate and tropical species
careTips: Constant moisture with distilled or rainwater ONLY - never tap water. Keep in tray of water (1-2 inches deep). Bright indirect to direct light depending on species. High humidity (60%+) preferred. Use only sphagnum peat moss or specialized carnivorous plant soil. Don't fertilize - they get nutrients from insects. Temperate species require dormancy; tropical species do not. Dewy appearance indicates healthy plant. Research specific species for exact requirements.

description: Also known as: VFT. Most famous carnivorous plant in the Droseraceae family, native to North Carolina, requires dormancy and pure water.
commonExamples: Dionaea muscipula (Venus flytrap, VFT)
careTips: Constant moisture with distilled or rainwater ONLY - never tap water (minerals kill them). Keep in tray of water (1-2 inches deep). Reduce watering in winter dormancy but keep slightly moist. Bright indirect to direct light (4-6 hours daily). High humidity (60%+) preferred. Use only sphagnum peat moss or specialized carnivorous plant soil. Don't fertilize - they get nutrients from insects. Require dormancy period in winter (cooler temperatures, reduced light). Don't trigger traps unnecessarily - each trap can only close a few times.

description: Epiphytic plants in the Bromeliaceae family that grow without soil, absorb water and nutrients through their leaves.
commonExamples: Tillandsia (Air plant), T. ionantha (Sky plant), T. xerographica (King of air plants), T. usneoides (Spanish moss), T. stricta, T. brachycaulos
careTips: Soak weekly for 20-30 minutes in room temperature water. Mist 2-3 times per week between soaks. Shake off excess water after soaking - water left in center causes rot. Ensure good air circulation - never keep in closed containers. Bright indirect light preferred. High humidity (50%+) preferred. Fertilize monthly by adding fertilizer to soak water at quarter strength. Grow without soil - mount on wood, rocks, or display in air. Research specific species for exact requirements.

description: Tank bromeliads with colorful central cups that hold water. Leaves form a rosette; flowers emerge from the center. Epiphytic in nature.
commonExamples: Neoregelia spp. (Blushing bromeliad)
careTips: Keep central cup (tank) filled with water - change weekly to prevent stagnation. Water soil when nearly dry. Bright indirect light. High humidity (50%+) preferred. Fertilize monthly by adding diluted fertilizer to tank. Use well-draining orchid or bromeliad mix. Good air circulation. Pup (offset) removal after flowering.

description: Large orchid genus with cane-like stems and sprays of flowers. Many types: nobile (cool rest), phalaenopsis-type (warm), others. Epiphytic.
commonExamples: Dendrobium spp. (Singapore orchid, Cooktown orchid)
careTips: Water when medium is nearly dry (weekly to bi-weekly). Never let sit in water. Bright indirect light - some tolerate more sun. High humidity (50-70%) preferred. Fertilize monthly with orchid fertilizer at quarter strength. Use bark-based orchid mix. Rest period varies by type - nobile needs cool dry rest for blooms. Research specific hybrid for exact cycle.

description: General category for plants that grow on other plants - see specific categories (Orchids, Bromeliads, Air Plants) for detailed care.
commonExamples: Platycerium (Staghorn fern), Tillandsia, Orchids, Bromeliads
careTips: Mist regularly (daily to weekly depending on species). Soak mounted plants weekly for 15-30 minutes. Ensure good drainage - never let sit in water. Bright indirect light preferred. High humidity (50-70%) preferred. Fertilize monthly with diluted fertilizer. Grow without soil - mount on wood, bark, or in specialized epiphyte mix. Good air circulation essential. Research specific plant type for exact requirements - see Orchids, Bromeliads, Air Plants for detailed care.

description: Also known as: Oakmoss. Symbiotic organism (fungus + algae/cyanobacteria) growing on bark, rocks, or soil. Rarely cultivated; use for identification or terrarium accent.
commonExamples: Various lichen species (Reindeer moss, British soldiers, Oakmoss)
careTips: Mist regularly to maintain moisture - lichens absorb from air. High humidity and good air circulation. Bright indirect to low light depending on species. Do not fertilize. Display on bark or rocks. Very slow growth. Difficult to cultivate outside natural habitat - most are wild-collected for display.

description: Non-vascular bryophytes that require constant moisture and high humidity, absorb water through leaves.
commonExamples: Sheet moss, Sphagnum moss (Peat moss), Fern moss, Cushion moss, Haircap moss
careTips: Mist daily or multiple times per day to maintain constant moisture. Never allow to dry out completely - even brief drying can kill moss. High humidity (80%+) essential - use terrarium or enclosed space. Bright indirect to low light preferred; direct sun dries moss quickly. Use distilled or rainwater - tap water minerals can harm moss. Acidic conditions preferred. Perfect for terrariums and moss gardens. Very challenging to maintain outside natural habitat.

description: Epiphytic orchids with spray-like flower stems, often yellow "dancing lady" blossoms. Includes many intergeneric hybrids (Oncostele, etc.).
commonExamples: Oncidium spp. (Dancing lady orchid)
careTips: Water when medium is nearly dry (weekly to bi-weekly). Never let sit in water. Bright indirect light - more light than Phalaenopsis. High humidity (50-70%) preferred. Fertilize monthly with orchid fertilizer at quarter strength. Use bark-based orchid mix. Good air circulation. Pseudobulbs store water - slight wrinkling is normal between waterings.

description: Large family of epiphytic and terrestrial plants in the Orchidaceae family, many are popular houseplants with specific care needs.
commonExamples: Phalaenopsis (Moth orchid), Cattleya, Dendrobium, Oncidium, Paphiopedilum (Lady's slipper), many genera and species
careTips: Water when potting medium is nearly dry (weekly to bi-weekly). Never let sit in water. Bright indirect light preferred - avoid direct sun. High humidity (50-70%) preferred. Fertilize monthly with orchid fertilizer at quarter strength. Use specialized orchid potting mix (bark, sphagnum moss). Repot every 2-3 years. Good air circulation essential. Many species are epiphytic. Research specific genus for exact requirements.

description: Also known as: Lady's slipper orchid. Terrestrial orchids prized for their distinctive pouch-shaped lip that traps pollinating insects, with blooms in rich earth tones, greens, and dramatic spotted or striped patterns.
commonExamples: Paphiopedilum maudiae (Maudiae slipper orchid), P. delenatii (Vietnamese slipper orchid), P. rothschildianum (Gold of Kinabalu orchid), P. insigne
careTips: Keep potting mix evenly moist but never soggy; water when top layer feels slightly dry. Medium indirect light—no direct sun; mottled-leaf types tolerate lower light than plain-leaf types. High humidity (60%+) essential. Use fine-grade bark orchid mix with perlite and sphagnum; they are terrestrial, not epiphytic like most orchids. Fertilize weakly every 2 weeks with balanced orchid fertilizer (flush monthly to prevent salt buildup). Do not mist water into the pouch—causes rot. Repot every 1-2 years when medium breaks down. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Epiphytic fern in the Polypodiaceae family that can survive extreme drought by curling up and appearing dead.
commonExamples: Pleopeltis polypodioides (Resurrection fern, formerly Polypodium polypodioides)
careTips: Mist regularly (2-3 times per week). Soak mounted plants weekly for 15-30 minutes. Can survive drought by curling up - will revive when watered. Bright indirect light preferred. High humidity (50-70%) preferred. Fertilize monthly with diluted fertilizer. Grow without soil - mount on wood or bark. Good air circulation essential. Epiphytic - grows on trees in nature. Very drought tolerant for a fern.

description: Also known as: Graybeard. Air plant (Tillandsia usneoides) that hangs in draping strands. No roots in soil - absorbs moisture through leaves. Grows on trees in Southeast US.
commonExamples: Tillandsia usneoides (Spanish moss, Graybeard)
careTips: Mist or soak 2-3x per week. Can dunk in water 10-20 min weekly. Shake off excess - never leave waterlogged. Bright indirect light. High humidity (50%+) preferred. No soil - hang or drape on branches, driftwood. Good air circulation. Tolerates mild freeze. Do not use copper - it is toxic to Tillandsia.

description: Large, sculptural air plant with silvery curly leaves. Xeromorphic - needs less water than most Tillandsia. Drought tolerant.
commonExamples: Tillandsia xerographica (King of air plants)
careTips: Mist 2-3x per week; soak 1-2x per month for 30-60 min. Shake off excess - water in crown causes rot. Thick leaves mean less frequent watering than other air plants. Bright indirect light. High humidity preferred. No soil - display on wood or in air. Tolerates neglect better than most air plants.

description: Monopodial orchids with strap leaves and large, colorful flowers. Often grown bare-root in baskets or with minimal media. Need high light and humidity.
commonExamples: Vanda spp. (Vanda orchid)
careTips: Water daily to every few days when grown bare-root; when potted, water when nearly dry. Mist roots frequently. Bright light - more than Phalaenopsis. High humidity (60%+) essential. Fertilize weekly at quarter strength. Use coarse bark or grow in slatted basket without media. Good air circulation. Can bloom multiple times per year.

description: Climbing orchid (Vanilla planifolia) that produces the vanilla bean. Grows as a vine; needs support. Tropical, high humidity and warmth. Also grown commercially as one of the world's most valuable spices.
commonExamples: Vanilla planifolia (Vanilla orchid, Vanilla bean), V. tahitensis (Tahitian vanilla), V. pompona (West Indian vanilla)
careTips: Water when medium is nearly dry (2-3x per week when growing). High humidity (80%+) essential - greenhouse or terrarium ideal. Bright indirect to filtered light. Fertilize monthly with orchid fertilizer. Use orchid bark mix. Provide sturdy support for vining growth. Flowers only with maturity (several years) and hand-pollination. Beans develop after pollination.

description: Compact alpine aster with daisy-like flowers in late spring to summer. Cold hardy, suited to rock gardens and alpine troughs.
commonExamples: Aster alpinus (Alpine aster)
careTips: Light watering (every 1-2 weeks). Allow to dry between waterings. Excellent drainage essential - use rocky, gritty mix. Full sun preferred. Drought tolerant once established. Fertilize sparingly in spring. Perfect for rock gardens. Shear after flowering to contain. Alpine; reduce watering when dormant; avoid winter wet.

description: Plants adapted to high-altitude, rocky conditions with excellent drainage, many are drought tolerant.
commonExamples: Saxifraga (Saxifrage), Sempervivum (Hens and chicks), Dianthus (Pinks, Carnations), Gentiana (Gentian), Androsace (Rock jasmine)
careTips: Light watering (every 1-2 weeks). Allow to dry between waterings. Excellent drainage essential - use rocky, gritty soil mix. Avoid waterlogged soil which causes root rot. Full sun preferred. Many are drought tolerant once established. Fertilize sparingly in spring. Perfect for rock gardens. Adapted to high-altitude, rocky conditions. Research specific species for exact requirements. Alpine; reduce watering when dormant; avoid winter wet.

description: Mat-forming alpine perennial in the Brassicaceae family with masses of spring flowers, excellent for rock gardens.
commonExamples: Aubrieta deltoidea (Aubrieta, Rock cress), various cultivars and colors
careTips: Light watering (every 1-2 weeks). Allow to dry between waterings. Excellent drainage essential. Full sun preferred. Drought tolerant once established. Fertilize sparingly in spring. Shear after flowering to maintain shape. Mat-forming habit. Masses of spring flowers. Perfect for rock gardens, walls, and slopes. Very cold hardy. Alpine; reduce watering when dormant; avoid winter wet.

description: Low-growing alpine bellflowers with blue or purple bells. Cold hardy, suited to rock gardens and crevices.
commonExamples: Campanula alpina (Alpine bellflower)
careTips: Light watering (every 1-2 weeks). Allow to dry between waterings. Excellent drainage essential. Full sun to light shade. Fertilize sparingly in spring. Perfect for rock gardens and walls. Very cold hardy. Alpine; reduce watering when dormant; avoid winter wet. Toxic to pets—keep away from pets.

description: Tiny alpine pink with single flowers, often pink or white. Compact cushion form. Cold hardy, ideal for rock gardens.
commonExamples: Dianthus alpinus (Alpine pink)
careTips: Light watering (every 1-2 weeks). Allow to dry between waterings. Excellent drainage essential - alkaline soil preferred. Full sun. Drought tolerant once established. Fertilize sparingly. Shear after flowering. Perfect for rock gardens. Alpine; reduce watering when dormant; avoid winter wet. Toxic to pets.

description: Iconic alpine plant in the Asteraceae family with woolly white flowers, symbol of the Alps, requires excellent drainage.
commonExamples: Leontopodium nivale (Edelweiss, Alpine edelweiss), L. alpinum
careTips: Light watering (every 1-2 weeks). Allow to dry between waterings. Excellent drainage essential - use rocky, gritty soil mix. Avoid waterlogged soil. Full sun preferred. Very drought tolerant once established. Fertilize sparingly if at all. Perfect for rock gardens and alpine gardens. Challenging to grow outside alpine conditions. Symbol of the Alps. Requires cool summers. Alpine; reduce watering when dormant; avoid winter wet.

description: Also known as: Gentiana. Alpine and woodland plants in the Gentianaceae family with intense blue flowers, prefer cool, moist conditions.
commonExamples: Gentiana (Gentian), G. acaulis (Stemless gentian), G. septemfida (Crested gentian), G. sino-ornata (Chinese gentian)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist but well-drained. Prefer cool, moist conditions. Excellent drainage essential. Full sun to partial shade depending on species. Fertilize sparingly in spring. Perfect for rock gardens and alpine gardens. Many species are challenging to grow. Adapted to high-altitude conditions. Research specific species for exact requirements. Alpine; reduce watering when dormant; avoid winter wet.

description: Also known as: Bitterroot. Alpine succulents with rosettes and showy flowers in pink, magenta, or white. Needs sharp drainage; crown must stay dry.
commonExamples: Lewisia cotyledon (Bitterroot, Siskiyou lewisia)
careTips: Water when soil is dry; avoid wetting crown - rot is common. Excellent drainage essential - grow in sloping rock or gritty mix. Full sun to light shade. Plant crown above soil level. Fertilize sparingly. Perfect for rock gardens. Challenging in wet climates. Alpine; reduce watering when dormant; avoid winter wet.

description: Delicate alpine perennials forming rosettes of leaves with clusters of jewel-toned flowers in spring, native to mountain meadows and rocky crevices of Europe and Asia where they endure harsh winters under snow cover.
commonExamples: Primula auricula (Auricula primrose, Bear's ear), P. marginata (Silver-edged primrose), P. hirsuta (Red alpine primrose), P. allionii (Allioni's primrose)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist during spring growth and flowering; reduce watering in summer heat and winter. Partial sun with afternoon shade in hot climates—full morning sun is ideal. Medium humidity fine; good air circulation essential to prevent crown rot. Excellent drainage critical—use gritty, mineral-rich alpine mix (50% grit to 50% compost). Minimal fertilizer; light top-dressing with fine gravel and lean compost in autumn. Protect rosettes from winter wet—an overhead rain cover works well. Grows well in troughs, rock gardens, and alpine houses. Mildly toxic—contact with leaves can cause skin irritation.

description: Also known as: Rockfoil. Diverse alpine genus with cushion, mat, or rosette forms. Flowers in white, pink, or yellow. Many species for rock gardens.
commonExamples: Saxifraga spp. (Rockfoil)
careTips: Light watering (every 1-2 weeks). Allow to dry between waterings. Excellent drainage essential - use rocky, gritty mix. Full sun to partial shade depending on species. Fertilize sparingly. Perfect for rock gardens and walls. Alpine; reduce watering when dormant; avoid winter wet.
